business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m. and, with the concurrence of the Senate, read prayers.

debateinfo.title: TELSTRA (TRANSITION TO FULL PRIVATE OWNERSHIP) BILL 1998

debate.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —Because of the importance of Telstra as a service provider, the political stakes surrounding its privatisation are very high. In the context of this second reading debate I think it is a worthwhile venture to examine Telstra the organisation. It is currently a majority publicly owned corporation that has a life and a culture all of its own. As telecommunications become more profitable, successive governments have relied on dividends returned to the public purse to fund social imperatives—that is, until now.

speech.para: Let us introduce a human factor. Telstra workers have borne the brunt of deregulation and competition, and any innovations in efficiencies that have arisen out of that are a credit to them. Then came privatisation. Suddenly the goals that were being pursued—with considerable pain and 25,000 job losses, I might add—and these achievements were no longer in the public good. Any detail surrounding Telstra's restructuring had to be painfully extracted through their estimates process. I am sure many will recall the names Project Strawman and Project Mercury which were internal plans by Telstra to deconstruct Telstra research laboratories in the first instance and sack over 20,000 workers in the second.

After all the restructuring, all the tension, the reduced investment in R&D, the job losses, the beneficiaries of Telstra's large dividend will be not the Australian public but private shareholders. Out of the hands of many into the hands of a few. The efforts of everyone who has put their time in with Telstra over the years, or Telecom as it was formerly known, are now focused on cold, harsh and dry economic returns. The focus of a privatised Telstra is on how to extract maximum profit for minimum service. Evidence of this comes in the form of complaints about billing and service having risen by almost 40 per cent.

If a customer focus is his weakness, chief executive Frank Blount's strength is to deconstruct a telecommunications company. He brought with him the corporate trends from the late 1980s and has spiced up his life by reincarnating them in Australia. I can picture the four-step plan now. First, sop up all the company loyalty built over many years and refocus it towards a lean, mean corporate machine, ready to compete in the new paradigm of telecommunications. There is some merit in that strategy, although exporting the goodwill of all those Telstra workers leaves a lot to be desired in management practice. Then came the change of government and privatisation raised the stakes.

The second step was this: keep the smile on your face while your workers get sacked, your R&D funding is plundered, your export opportunities are squandered and critical regional projects are dumped. The main game here is the bottom line: tidy up the books. The third step in the plan was to brief the minister, give the doormat the lines and promise to say lots of nice things about him, put him in front of a camera or a Senate estimates committee or his party room, wind him up and let him go.

The fourth step was to deliver massive salary increases to himself and all his senior management mates, sit back and contemplate retirement. There's another job well done, Mr Blount. You have done over another telecommunications company and made lots of shareholders rich. Won't that look good on your CV? Never mind that Australia's telecommunications infrastructure is left as a shadow of its former self. It is not your responsibility any longer.

You may think that I am being unduly harsh on just one participant in this strategy of privatisation, but consider this: corporate trends do not just happen. They do not just miraculously occur overnight. People manage these agendas, they create strategies to forward them and they give them a life of their own. Privatisation of telecommunications carriers around the world is part of that global trend and it is the government that has the responsibility of realising the social and economic value of keeping a carrier in public hands.

This government have failed in their responsibility. It is not surprising that they have, given the leadership void. It is not surprising that the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) does not have the capacity to see that Australia is uniquely placed to show the rest of the world what can be gained from harnessing telecommunications for the betterment of all, be they city dwellers or those in rural communities.

I now turn to an issue that I think is one of great importance and looks at more the cutting edge of telecommunications and future communication services—that being the Internet. I believe that privatisation of Telstra will result in increased prices for access to the Internet. We know already that Telstra have a propensity to discriminate against those in rural and regional areas for access. Only 13 per cent of adults living in non-metropolitan areas use the Internet. That is half of city net users. Looking at it another way, about 2½ million Internet users live in metropolitan areas, while only 516,000 live in rural, regional or remote areas.

The reason for the slow Internet take-up by rural people is due to a combination of overpricing and inadequate services. There have been a number of reports that the high level of rural interest in the Internet is being hampered by the high cost of access. Telstra's own product, Big Pond, charges remote users $7 per hour plus local call access compared with their city rate, which is between 80c and $1.50. I think Ross Wheeler, manager of Albury Local Internet, summed up the situation best when he told a newspaper that his business survives on antipathy and antagonism towards Telstra.

A closer look at Telstra's retail Internet product, Big Pond Business, shows how blatantly they discriminate against rural and regional users. Telstra uses an arbitrary 85-kilometre radius around regional centres to impose a higher charge which they call their rural charge. Regional users themselves have a much larger rate to pay just because they live in the regions. Telstra have been unable to demonstrate the technical need for such higher charging. It has been imposed without any justification, other than an expectation that the market will pay.

This structural and economic disadvantage has fuelled genuine concerns by rural constituents about the impact of a privatised Telstra. For instance, the National Farmers Federation has established a company called Farmwide to provide online facilities to 1,000 farm families. This project was funded through the rural telecommunications infrastructure fund and does have some merit. The project itself has legitimate aims, but why didn't Telstra conduct it straight up? The project did not have to come through the regional bribe drawn out through the last one-third privatisation of Telstra. And that is exactly what the RTIF was: it was a $250 million bribe constructed for the sole purpose of securing votes in this place to allow the passage of the one-third sale of Telstra bill.

Now we are seeing exactly the same tactics being played out, only the government has put $400 million on the table. This shameful bribe is no better than the emotional plea for the $1 billion for the Natural Heritage Trust leading up to the sale of one-third of Telstra, only this time the government is playing on the needs of rural and regional Australia. This is not even a buy for young people and those who care about the environment. It is a buy on the needs of those who are suffering an inadequate service. It is quite interesting to hear John Howard's latest line, `Well, if we don't sell all of Telstra, these people will not get an improved service.'

Let us have a look at the other ways in which these projects could be funded. There is no reason at all that a Telstra in public hands cannot design and manage these projects themselves. That is the value and the beauty of having a corporation such as Telstra in public hands, so they can do exactly these types of projects. But the most telling indictment of Telstra comes from their experience with the ACCC.

Even before this bill came before the Senate, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission was forced to intervene because of alleged anticompetitive conduct in breach of the Trade Practices Act. The issue related to the transfer of data over Internet bandwidth. Telstra have proven once and for all that they are prepared to use the courts to protect their profitability against government regulation. This, more than anything else, shows us why there is folly in the government's plan to reregulate and force Telstra to adhere to a greater level of service for rural and regional customers, or even those in metropolitan Australia. This corporation has shown like every other private corporation around the world that they will use every legal mechanism at their disposal to fight regulations that constrict their ability to make a profit.

At the height of this stand-off between Telstra and the ACCC, Telstra's chief executive warned the government that regulatory changes could endanger plans to privatise Telstra. In other words, he is saying, `Look, Mr Howard, if you want to make so many millions of dollars out of Telstra, you had better not regulate us too harshly.' The blackmail goes both ways. Frank Blount said:

If we have so many conditions tied around this company . . . if it goes too far I think the Government has to decide `can this really be sold?' [and] if they go too far over the line with conditions wanted around the country, [Telstra] will not be able to be floated.
In other words, Telstra is saying, `Do not put restrictions on us that will hamper our profit, because we will take you on or put under threat your plans to privatise.'

Telstra is saying that they are not prepared within their own corporate plan to focus on those in need. And what was Frank Blount's response to all of this? He said that Telstra needed to focus on `delivery of increased shareholder value'. Comments like that should send shivers up the spines of all those sitting opposite, because that is what we are dealing with here. We are dealing with a company that, by its nature as a privatised entity, will not have any choice under Corporations Law but to focus on the interests of their shareholder. That is the nature of beast. When you are living in or existing within that environment, then quite fairly Telstra will have no choice but to conduct themselves in this way.

The greatest weakness of the minister in this portfolio has been his inability to escape the grip of those within the telecommunications industry sector and the minister's adeptness at constructing political arguments to justify the government's acquiescence to the will of the corporate powers within telecommunications has become his trademark. It would be disappointing if this skill were to be interpreted as having a broad understanding of his portfolio.

Minister Alston is incapable of lateral thinking, of stepping outside the corporate agendas which surround his government, and hence the social and economic benefits of exploiting the enabling capability of telecommunications infrastructure has been completely ignored. If there is a vision behind the minister's policy considerations, it will be a shallow reflection of the plans articulated in many a timber-lined boardroom.

When exploring the enabling capacity of telecommunications, one cannot help but turn to Australia's unique character and inherent strengths. Australians have shown a willingness to adopt new technologies—in fact, we are running second in take-up rates of new technologies such as mobile phones and personal computers. There are still some structural inequities with respect to accessing new technologies, including the fact that the less you earn the less likely you are to have access.

With enhanced services, whole communities have the opportunity to improve their knowledge and understanding of the information revolution. Apart from positively confronting the insecurities that accompany such rapid technological changes, this will empower communities and will give them a voice. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is such a pity that there were only three members of the government in the chamber to listen to Senator Lundy's talk, which comprehensively covered the field of argument as to why Telstra should remain in public hands and not be sold across into private hands where the power over its future will remain with the Stock Exchange.

speech.para: Essentially this debate comes down to the disempowerment of the people with regard to telecommunications in the future: it will have been taken out of the hands of their elected representatives and put into the hands of the Stock Exchange. As Senator Lundy pointed out so eloquently, the primary duty becomes one of servicing not the telephone system but the profit line. There will be an obligation to try to increase profitability on behalf of the shareholders, even where it will patently mean a loss for the people who are being serviced by the corporation.

One of the sad things about the way in which this matter is being handled in this place is the fact that, while the Senate is here debating this issue at the demand of the government, Senator Colston and Senator Harradine, who three times gagged debate last night in the Senate, the so-called deal for the bush which the government has struck in its pre-election panic negotiations with the National Party has not been revealed to the Senate. In fact, this morning, somebody in the coffee shop told me that it would be revealed on this morning's John Laws program—and I do not mention that so that ABC viewers can switch across; I recommend that they do not, that they stay right where they are—but whether or not that is the case what sort of democratic process is it that Senator Harradine, the self-proclaimed father of the Senate, is engaged in? He is gagging his own offspring, so to speak. But there it is. He has become a creature of the government, he has become a creature of privatisation, and we are not here engaged—

talk.start.para: —Have you ever voted with anyone but the Labor Party?

—Senators opposite, Mr Acting Deputy President, all two of them, who wanted this debate but have been abandoned by their colleagues, will have their opportunity to speak when I am finished. They should stop interjecting. The fact is that Senator Harradine has become a creature of the government. We are not here in this debate without the government having reck oned that, at the end of it, it will get a positive vote.
—Order! Senator Brown, you recently said that Senator Harradine was a creature of the government. I consider that to be unparliamentary, and I ask you to withdraw, please.
—I will withdraw, if that is your consideration.
—It is not that it is my consideration; I am just asking you to withdraw.

—Yes, and I will do so if that is your consideration. But, Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Harradine has become a person who spends maximal time negotiating behind closed doors with the government. People can work that one out for themselves, whatever ruling is made on my description of him. The reality is that, having sold out the indigenous people of this country with whom he danced only a month or so ago, he is now selling out rural and regional Australia, not least Tasmania. But I will come back to that in a little while.

speech.para: When we look at the process that Senator Harradine and Senator Colston are engaged in here with the government, over the next couple of days we will be seeing a forced debate to get through a bill which the government does not intend to enact in the life of this parliament—in fact, it made a commitment not to. It is a forced debate to get through legislation which the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) promised the nation would not be brought before this parliament at all.

To do that, the government and the Independent senators have had to kick out of the way a long list of other legislation which the nation requires. This legislation will now not get through this parliament before the government takes the nation to an untimely and unnecessary election nearly a year before it has to happen. If ever there was an argument for fixed date elections, this current politicking by the government highlights it.

There is the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill which will not get through the parliament. There are two bills on radiation protection and nuclear safety in Australia, which one would have thought are of great interest to the people in Sydney's southern suburbs, but they will now not get through the Senate because of this turn of events. There is a bill for Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service reform brought by Senator Newman which will now sit on the Notice Paper and disappear.

There is the ANL sale bill brought by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill), which likewise has been kicked aside because of the government's political interest in debating this bill which it has declared will not be enacted. There is an aged care amendment bill, which aged people in this country have a right to expect will be debated in their interest, but it will now not be because the aged are being knocked aside due to this government's political considerations.

There is a national transmission network bill. That comes the closest to the matter in hand, but that too has been kicked aside, as has the Adelaide Airport Curfew Bill 1998 and a bill to do with superannuation called the Workplace Relations Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1997 . All those and many other important matters have been knocked aside by the way in which this legislation was steamrolled into the agenda last night by the government, Senator Harradine and Senator Colston.

When it comes to the impending sale of Telstra, I can do little better than reiterate Senator Margetts's contribution last night where she spoke about the `economic disbenefits' of this move. She said:
It is important to note that the Office of Asset Sales refused to divulge—
to the relevant Senate committee—
crucial figures used in their calculations of the economic benefits—
of the sale of Telstra. She continued:
In particular, it was pointed out in the minority report—
to which Senator Margetts contributed—
that the estimated future dividend flows were not disclosed, on the basis that it would not be in the financial interests of the Commonwealth.
That is, on the basis of cheating by keeping information from the people. Senator Margetts then said:
Obviously, the concepts of transparency, accountability and systematic analysis—
so crucial to Senator Harradine in the past—
were not considered important by the government in this case, despite all the filibustering about the Charter of Budget Honesty.
She went on to say:
At the end of the day, there is no way to definitely determine whether the sale of Telstra will produce net economic benefits.

The government's economic arithmetic bandied about in the press, however, has been strongly disputed. The first error in the government's projections is the calculation in interest savings on government loans. These estimations have been severely questioned. The government calculation of $4 billion worth of savings on interest repayment is more accurately estimated at $2.5 billion per annum. If you stack this interest saving against the ongoing losses, the hope of net economic benefits is nothing to be enthusiastic about.
Senator Margetts continued:

The sale of Telstra will, in fact, generate losses . . . first, public sector savings produced by profits of over $1 billion per annum, either paid into the Commonwealth or used as retained earnings by Telstra to finance investments . . .
That is the current situation. She then said:
Secondly, the loss of franking credits: the government does not claim franking credits but private shareholders, however, are sure to claim those credits.

Professor Quiggin estimates that this will be a cost to revenue of $600 million, rising to $1.8 billion within three years, if Telstra's profits continue to grow at their current rate. Professor Quiggin has estimated that by 2007 Australia would have sustained a loss of $9 billion and beyond that time the loss will increase. For the glory of contributing to the sweet surplus—
that is a much touted government surplus—
Australia will lose a revenue stream that could contribute to any number of socially desirable outcomes in the future.

Consequently, the Greens (WA) are of the belief that the government should heed the warnings that the sale of Telstra is likely to produce a net loss at the current valuation of $40 billion that has been tossed around.

talk.start.para: —Ha!

—The Manager of Government Business laughs at that, Mr Acting Deputy President, but you have to remember that this is a once-off sale of an enormous public asset in circumstances which do not warrant it. If in 10 years from now this government were to be in power in foreseeably much worse economic circumstances than those which currently prevail, what would it do; what would it sell then? Maybe it would look around for someone to buy Parliament House, as is the case in the Northern Territory with even that being privatised. Senator Margetts then told of the response from the government—that is, the minister—to the challenge of Professor Quiggin's figures, and she said:

speech.para: The very warm response that I received from the minister was that, `The last thing I would do is treat Professor Quiggin as any sort of sensible economic analyst on this issue.' The good minister finished his answer with the exceptionally uncompelling evidence that retaining Telstra in public ownership `is simply quite contrary to economic orthodoxy around the world'.

It is economic orthodoxy, economic rationalism, which Senator Margetts has fought ever since entering this place, and sometimes on her own—witness the debate on the World Trade Organisation where the legislation went through under the last Labor government, supported by the opposition parties. It is that economic rationalism which is leading to the rapid widening of the gap between rich and poor, both within this country and between this country and other countries. That is, in itself, a recipe for future social disruption.

Besides the obvious loss in terms of social equity when a very important part of public infrastructure, like Telstra, is sold on the Stock Exchange, we have the then ongoing difficulty, which Senator Lundy pointed to this morning, of the disempowerment of the regional people of Australia. If the regions are having difficulties with getting a fair go now—and we heard Senator Lundy's reference to the appalling discrepancy between rates paid in Albury and those paid in the big cities—how much worse will it be after Telstra has been put into private hands, where the most compelling argument for the future will be about what good it will do to the profit lines.

Senator Lundy outlined the philosophy, as it stands, of the chief executive of Telstra. That let loose will mean that, as we go down the line, the whole aim will be to make Telstra more lean, which means getting rid of more jobs, and more mean, which means the taking of money from the hands of consumers to be put into the hands of Telstra shareholders.

When it comes to the issue of jobs, one has to ask the absent Senator Harradine—I wish he were here; he has brought this debate on—what happened to your promise of gaining great benefits for Tasmania with the first one-third sale of Telstra? Senator Carr, who is here, was able to tell the Senate last night that Senator Harradine's much promised gains for Tasmania have flopped.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish!

—`Rubbish' says Senator Calvert, also from Tasmania, who wants to flood the Liffey River amongst the other crazy projects he has in mind. Senator Carr's figures for employment in Telstra, which were supposed to get special treatment in Tasmania, are that instead of the promised increase of 170 jobs Tasmania has lost 140 jobs—a reduction of 30 per cent in the work force. Between the promised gains and the actuality, Tasmania has been cheated of 310 jobs. Where is the advantage to Tasmania that Brian Harradine, the senator for all things to do with the government—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: under standing order 196, I make the point that this is obviously against the standing order as it relates to hypocrisy. Senator Brown has cost more jobs in Tasmania than any other person in the history of mankind. Under standing order 196, I would ask you to call him to order.
—There is no point of order.
—There is a point of order on the hypocrisy bit, but I will not go into that.
—There isn't.
—You have destroyed more jobs in Australia than any single person. You're probably proud of that. Are you?

—The behaviour of Senator Campbell is typical of the behaviour of the government at the moment. The fact that he can only muster himself plus one other from the government ranks to be here for this debate which has been forced on this place by the government and the contempt with which this government, Senator Harradine and Senator Colston hold this place of elected representatives, and the contempt with which they are handling the electorate, must impress listeners at least as far as the sale of Telstra is concerned.

speech.para: They know that it is a very unpopular move. They know that the people do not believe them when they say that it is going to be good for them. They know that the people are right about that. They are trying to shove this through here in unforecast sitting hours, following a triple gag last night in the Senate, so that that they can get it over and done with and sneak home hoping that nobody has noticed. The appalling thing, as I said earlier today, is that the real information about the government's so-called deal is being announced somewhere else, but not in this place where the debate should be taking place on behalf of the people of this great country of ours.

I was talking about the Tasmanian situation. We had much fanfare with the first one-third sale of Telstra about the benefits—benefits by way of jobs and benefits for the environment—that Senator Harradine was going to bring to Tasmania through the extra $100 million. Where is the accounting for that? Where is the presentation of the Tasmanian package so that it can be analysed and put to the test? Once again, the Tasmanian people have been set up and cheated by a pronounced package that has not brought home the goods. As far as people like Senator Harradine and Senator Calvert are concerned, as I said earlier, the promise of 170 jobs has led to the loss of 130 jobs.

When it comes to the environment, which Senator Harradine was going to look after through the part sale of Telstra, we currently have in Tasmania environmental indices across the board going from bad to worse. In our forest industry there has been a massive contribution to global warming because of Forestry Tasmania's continued burning of rainforests and tall eucalypt forests as they clear-fell in order to put in monocultures of plantations, and an ongoing shedding of jobs. Another 300 jobs are going west at Amcor, for example, as it closes its pulp facility. That is because the Labor and Liberal parties in Tasmania failed to put conditions on handing across the forests through the resource security legislation at state level in 1991 and on the regional forest agreement between John Howard, the Prime Minister, and the Premier of Tasmania last year.

Whether you look at jobs or the environment—it goes way beyond forestry, of course—Tasmania is being made the fall guy for the role that Senator Harradine takes in national politics. He has not just sold out the indigenous people of this country. Through this legislation, he is not just selling out regional and rural Australia. On the evidence we have available, he has sold out his home state of Tasmania so that the power he wields in here could effectively get the government what it wants.

Senator Harradine may feel that he has had some breakthroughs and wins, but when you stand back and look at them it is a rather pathetic self-deception. He has done nothing more than become part of a government apparatus. He was elected to be an independent voice for Tasmania, but he has simply become a rubber stamp for the Howard government and the Liberal-National Party coalition. There has been a breach of promise through the sale of the first one-third of Telstra. We have nothing much more than a slush fund coming out of that as far as the environment is concerned. In the minute or so remaining to me, I want to refer to that.

In this parliament in the last two weeks, after serial questioning, I have unearthed the fact that $12 million of the money earmarked for the environment through the first one-third sale of Telstra, for catchment management of the Murray-Darling Basin and for environmental repairs, has been put into repair of the Hume Dam—capital works. You could argue that that is as environmentally important as upgrading the Hume Highway. It is a massive breach of promise by the Howard government. It is cheating on the people in the Murray-Darling Basin, it is cheating on environmentalists around this country and it is cheating on those people who thought the promise of the sale of the first one-third of Telstra would be kept. When the government comes up with another deal now and says, `Trust us second time around; we cheated you the first time but the second time around surely you will trust us to the ballot box,' how could anybody in the bush accept its word? I would not encourage anybody in the country to do that.

talk.start.para: —John Howard's ideologically driven obsession with selling Telstra does not just threaten a long history of service and access for all Australians, it also heralds more job losses. Telstra is too important to be subjected to the whims of such ideology. The government believes that Telstra is first and foremost a business. It is much more than that: it is a key part of our national infrastructure and the major provider of telecommunications services in a country which, for reasons of its size, demographics and future industry development needs, relies on these services as a lifeline.

speech.para: I just do not buy the government's claims that selling off Telstra turns ordinary mums and dads into shareholders. The truth of the matter is that we are all shareholders in Telstra. We already own it and we all share in the benefits of it. It is vital that Telstra not be sold off so that we can all continue to share in the benefits. The question I want to ask the government is this: how will the sale of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra benefit people in the bush? How will those who do not have shares in Telstra benefit?

It has become increasingly clear that the government's obligations to broader Australia have suffered as a result of this obsession with privatisation and the bottom line. This growing lack of regard for members of our society has already been made blindingly obvious by the behaviour of the banks, which are continuing to close branches across Australia at an alarming rate, even though they have been making record profits. It is Australians living in rural and remote areas who are most directly affected. And it is not just the actual employees of the bank, Telstra office or Medicare office who are affected; it is also their families and the businesses that rely upon their custom which are affected. All of us pay one way or another. The indirect effects can be felt across the country as unemployment continues to rise in regional areas and small businesses close.

This was brought home to me quite recently when the Commonwealth Bank decided to close its branch in Aminya Street, Mansfield, a suburb in Brisbane which has a large number of elderly residents. In fact, over 30 per cent of the residents are aged over 60. Other businesses in the shopping strip relied on the bank's customers for patronage. This included a family business snack bar, which is now on the verge of closing, a Cut Price Deli and a hairdresser. There is an industrial zone close by and the workers there used the bank and the other ancillary businesses nearby. The decision to close this branch has had serious implications for these businesses and for local residents.

This may seem like a small example, but we are talking about real people here. The loss of the bank will be catastrophic in that community. Customers picketed outside the main Brisbane city branch in Queen Street one day a week for several weeks in an attempt to force the bank to change its mind, but they did not succeed. The backlash from members of these communities which are so adversely affected has been savage in some cases, but unfortunately banks are not really accountable to their customers for service obligations, only to their shareholders. Is this what we want to happen to Telstra? I fear that we will see people also protesting the loss of services by Telstra and protesting job losses—but to no avail should Telstra become fully privatised.

It is just this lack of concern for providing a basic customer service that will be the undoing of small businesses and regional economies throughout Queensland. The introduction of the customer service guarantee scheme to compensate customers where service standards are not met has failed to ensure even the maintenance of existing service levels. People are, and should rightly be, concerned about the future implications of a fully privatised Telstra. It is not enough to say that Telstra will continue to meet basic obligations. We know that service standards have slipped as a result of staffing cuts. It is not good enough to say that facilities and rates of service will be maintained. We also need to be able to give assurances that facilities available to city based people will be available to people living in regional and rural areas.

The customer service guarantee under the existing legislation is not working. The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman has pointed out that the majority of complainants contacting the TIO office are not aware of the existence of the customer service guarantee, let alone the specific performance standards set out in that guarantee. The ombudsman's office has been critical of service providers, who he states have been slow to meet their obligations to advise their customers of its existence and of their rights, even though that is one of their obligations. I fail to be convinced that proposed amendments to the act to include large fines for those service providers who do not meet the customer service guarantee will be effective. Out in rural and regional Australia, in many cases it will be cheaper to pay daily credits than to provide the service in a timely manner. How effective really will these fines be in the long term when they clash with the market values of profit maximisation? In reality, it will be impossible for any government to force a privately owned Telstra to meet service obligations, especially in rural and remote areas.

The information age is well and truly upon us. In the future, those with access to information which is provided via a telecommunications system will be the fortunate ones. Those who are information poor and lack quality, affordable access to the services upon which our society increasingly depends will become more and more marginalised.

Australia is a country increasingly divided on so many fronts. The privatisation of Telstra will create two classes of citizens, and those people in the bush will disproportionately feel its effects. People in the bush are already doing it tough. When decent, hardworking Australians deserted the coalition in droves in Queensland recently, that should have been enough to tell you that they are hurting. Election results in Queensland show that it is the coalition which suffered damaging swings against it. The coalition was not listening to what people in the bush need, and they still are not. Has John Howard learnt nothing from this debacle, other than the fact that he should put One Nation last in his own seat of Bennelong?

This is a case of too little, too late. Maybe he should have listened more attentively to the Leader of the National Party in the Senate. The privatisation of Telstra is a key issue upon which the Labor Party and the coalition stand divided. I am proud of that fact. It ranks right up there with the GST. I have faith in our fellow Australians and I do not think they are going to be taken in by the glib promises of the coalition that they will be better off.

The full privatisation of Telstra will disproportionately affect the elderly, people with disabilities and the uneducated—those who are least able to stand up for their rights or to seek redress where their rights have been breached. Telstra's employment levels have declined by about one-third over the last four to five years. This has occurred at the same time that Telstra's before tax profits rose by 26.4 per cent, revenue increased by 13.1 per cent, profit per employee rose 42.2 per cent and labor costs for the period rose 3.7 per cent. Job security and quality of service have suffered as a direct result. And what about foreign ownership? Under John Howard's privatised Telstra, foreign owners will be able to control 35 per cent of the privatised company.

I do not really believe the government's rhetoric that ordinary mums and dads in Australia who own a few shares in Telstra will have any real influence on, or be able to exercise any real control over, Telstra. In addition, if Australia becomes a signatory to the MAI, then current limits on foreign ownership of Telstra may well become illegal. Australia is a small economy. Our geographical size and uneven population distribution make service provision a challenge in some cases. The universal standard obligation exists to ensure that where there are shortfalls in revenue over expenses in rural areas, these will be subsidised by a contribution from carriers to a central pool of funds used to reimburse Telstra, which is the nominated carrier.

The government has not guaranteed an extension to the services offered to rural and regional Australians under the USO. All that has been written into the plan is that a standard telephone service must be accessible in rural and remote areas. There is no guarantee that, as new services come on line, regional, rural and remote subscribers will have access to them. The USO is central to the provision of telecommunications services across the nation on an affordable basis, and universal access to affordable, quality telecommunications services is essential to be able to participate in our society and economy.

As a senator whose constituency includes rural communities, I am very concerned about the disproportionately negative impact that further privatisation will have on people in the bush. This, coupled with the fact that global and national economic reform measures have already disproportionately affected people in the bush, will not be addressed by selling off the major telecommunications carrier in this country. The long-term impact of the privatisation of Telstra must be considered in this context.

I have already alluded to the decline in services and business infrastructure in the bush. This trend is very worrying, but there is some hope that telecommunications services can fill the breach in areas like finance, health, education, trade and commerce. However, for regional Australians to be able to take advantage of this potential, they must have access to the most up-to-date technology and services which are delivered in a timely manner. A nationwide poll conducted by Rural Press and published in The Land newspaper shows that country people do not believe Mr Howard's rhetoric that they will not be disadvantaged by the sell-off.

Of those people who were surveyed, 49 per cent said that they expected services to be worse under a fully privatised Telstra. Sixty-three per cent of people linked their concern about the sale of Telstra with their overall concern about the continuing deterioration of services in the bush. Even the National Farmers Federation does not support it. In a poll released in the Western Australian Farmers Federation, less than one in 10 farmers support the full privatisation of Telstra.

I do not see how the government can guarantee under a privatised Telstra continuing access to timely service and maintenance, a reasonable price for services, equitable common charging regimes, the provision of untimed local calls throughout the network, access to new technology or access to the Internet and data capable connections in the long term. These guarantees cannot be met under a privatised Telstra, which is already struggling to operate as a commercial telecommunications service and under the expectation that it will provide public services at a common cost schedule.

Government claims that the vast bulk of the proceeds of the sale of Telstra will be used to retire existing public debt thereby reducing the Commonwealth's public debt interest liability must be measured against the future loss of earnings arising out of the sale of Telstra. This is a false economy. The opportunity costs of selling off Telstra will be enormous; the benefits will be short term indeed. Given that Telstra's dividends have grown at an average of 15.6 per cent per year, if they were to continue to grow at that rate, the value of the dividends will become greater than the interest saved on public debt by 2002-03.

On this basis, the government cannot justify selling Telstra for either extra spending or tax cuts on an ongoing basis. At best, one-off commitments can be made, but these will have disappeared by the year 2002-03. This is, of course, assuming that Telstra's dividends do not increase in value and that they maintain the average growth rate of 15.6 per cent, which based upon past trends seems very reasonable, if not a little modest.

How can we even think of selling off Telstra when the benefits of doing so will run out by 2002-03? This is unbelievably short-sighted and clearly not in the long-term interests of Australians. Any short-term gains will be at the expense of jobs and employment conditions. The industry development capacity of Telstra will contribute to our telecommunications and electronics industry and to the provision of services to regional Australians.

The Telstra bill inquiry evidence clearly showed that there is a lot of support out there for the retention of parliamentary scrutiny of Telstra and the ministerial power to direct Telstra in the national interest. The choice is quite clear: we can have a world-class telecommunications industry in terms of technology, pricing, quality of service and the capacity to sustain support for national competitive advantage across a wide range of industry sectors, as the government has said, or we can have a privatised Telstra which makes some people rich at the expense of most Australians.

The lack of revenue going into government coffers after the year 2003 does beg some interesting questions, doesn't it? No clear longer-term economic benefits arising out of the proposed sale of Telstra have been established, nor can the interests of competitors or consumers be adequately safeguarded.

Telstra is just too important a part of our national infrastructure to be sold off. If Telstra is fully privatised, I know that it will rank as one of the worst excesses of economic vandalism perpetrated upon the Australian people. In years to come, its sale will be related by economists as one of the reasons why Australia's people and her economy failed to reach their full potential. (Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —In this debate, I am proceeding on the basis that Senator Harradine has agreed to sell Telstra. Therefore, we must move on, accept the numbers and see what we can do to improve matters. But before I do that, I want to comment on the economics of it all. First, I want to comment on the sale price. Eight months after floating, Telstra shares are now valued at $6 a share, which is $11 billion more than the government sold them for. At the time of the sale, numbers of commentators, including James Capel, the stockbrokers, told the government that they were selling Telstra too cheaply. The Australian Democrats persistently told the government that they were selling Telstra too cheaply. I recall Senator Alston and the entire government frontbench mocking the Democrats for doing so. The consequence is that the government has let Australia lose billions of dollars that it could have received. So the first thing to do is to question its judgment and ability on the matter of sale price.

speech.para: The second area I want to cover is this astonishing belief in privatisation. It has variously been described as economic devastation, economic rape and an economically illiterate and incoherent policy. Professor John Quiggin, the Senior Research Fellow in economics at James Cook University in Townsville, in the Australian Financial Review on Thursday, 2 July 1998, had this to say:
The case for privatisation rests on the claim that private owners could achieve efficiency improvements not feasible under public ownership.

By focusing on the dividends from public enterprises, and ignoring their retained earnings, they make it appear that the interest savings arising when privatisation proceeds are used to repay debt are more than the income forgone by the public.

In fact, the reverse is almost invariably the case, partly because the rate of return demanded by private holders of equity is considerably higher than the government bond rate. The illusory fiscal benefits of privatisation have led governments to offer over-generous terms to buyers, particularly when they are upper-income "mums and dads". The total loss to taxpayers from privatisations so far amounts to billions of dollars.
Most economists, including those in State and Federal finance departments, have now recognised the idea of a pot of gold from privatisation as a fallacy.

The work we have done on the sale of Telstra indicates that the total loss to the community from the sale of Telstra, the direct loss, will be $6.5 billion by the year 2006. Frankly, that is appallingly bad economics.

The net economic benefit is, therefore, a result of what I would refer to as flat earth accounting. It is that automatic acceptance of an economic dogma which is outdated and which has been proven persistently to be wrong. It is the Australian Democrats who have persistently and consistently told Australian governments both past and present and the people of Australia that fact. This sale of Telstra will not deliver net economic benefit to Australia. I will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading in the following terms:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:

(a) notes that the following information, requested of the Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing at the hearing of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on 4 June 1998, has not been provided:

(i) a comprehensive balance sheet, or assessment of net present worth, which compares the net Commonwealth financial position, under the two scenarios of selling Telstra and not selling Telstra, including all relevant financial flows, such as, but not necessarily limited to:
(A) the value of Telstra dividends to government foregone;
(B) the value of retained earnings by Telstra;
(C) reduced government debt interest payments;
(D) the costs of the sale of Telstra, such as stockbroker and agents fees, and the costs of government administration of the sale;
(E) the effect of increased taxation foregone, due to the passing of franking credits from government to private ownership;
(ii) separate analyses for the sale of the first third of Telstra and the sale of the remaining two thirds of Telstra; and

(b) resolves that the information identified in paragraph (a) be laid on the table by no later than immediately after Questions Without Notice on the first day of the Spring sittings 1998, unless it is sooner provided to the Committee".
On 4 June 1998, at the estimates hearing of the Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee I asked the Office of Assets Sales to:

. . . please provide a comprehensive balance sheet or an assessment of net present worth which compares the net Commonwealth financial position under two scenarios: selling Telstra and not selling Telstra. Such an assessment should include all relevant financial flows such as, but not necessarily limited to, the value of Telstra dividends to government forgone; the value of retained earnings by Telstra; reduced government debt interest payments; the cost of the sale of Telstra such as stockbroker and agent's fees and the costs of government administration for sale; and the effect of increased taxation forgone due to the passing of franking credits from government to private ownership. Please provide separate analyses along the above lines for the sale of the first one-third of Telstra and the proposed sale of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra.

Mr Acting Deputy President, it will not have passed your attention that that was on 4 June. We are now at 10 July and, surprise, surprise, the government has not yet provided those figures. If it did provide those figures, if it did provide the truth to the Australian public, it would show that this sale of Telstra, on straight accounting, economic and cash flow terms, will deliver a net economic loss to Australia. And that has been the persistent and consistent message of the Australian Democrats, which was mocked by the flat earth economists and the ideologues within the media and on the government benches.

However, I believe we are going to lose that debate, so we should attend to what we can do to make Telstra a far better company, at least for Australians as a whole. The consideration of the future of Telstra, Australia's largest corporation, does allow us an excellent opportunity to instigate cutting edge measures for corporate governance. These remarks are particularly directed to the Labor Party, because I believe the Labor Party should support these measures which would improve the governance of this company. It is our company until they sell it; ours on behalf of the Australian people. As representatives of the Australian people, we still have the option to deal with a company which is owned by all Australians, not just the richest 10 per cent and the fat commission-taking people who enjoy this process so much.

The Australian Democrats have a strong commitment to democratic principles, openness and accountability and believe that Australian company law continues to need reform to ensure Australian corporations conform to these standards. Our greatest concern is with companies that have the greatest impact on our society—public companies. The fundamental issue is that, while public companies are privately administered, they are publicly owned and should therefore be fully accountable to the public or at least to their individual shareholders, who are large sections of the public. The way in which this accountability is advanced and enforced is the responsibility of every democratic government. We think changes are necessary because corporations in the modern world have enormous power over our communities, the environment in which we live, the society in which we live and the fabric of our relationships.

If you do not attend to how these corporations operate you will find that they will do us less good than they otherwise might. If you attend solely to economics it is a bit like making sure somebody is clean and fed but is not nurtured appropriately. The Australian Democrats feel that, in the interests of the public as a whole, matters of accountability and honesty in corporate governance need to come before economics. Economics on its own will damage society unless it is moderated by the principles of justice and democracy.

A comprehensive legislative structure to ensure transparency and accountability in the activities of company management is vital. Shareholders, on whose behalf the directors and senior management are working, must be able to monitor the full extent of the decisions taken by company management and directors and have the opportunity to ensure they comply with best commercial practice as prescribed by the law. I am speaking this way because I accept that, if Senator Harradine has determined to sell Telstra, we must attend to the company.

The peculiar thing about modern companies is that it is often the shareholder who is left behind in matters of power and matters of decision making. Companies worldwide have been taken over by two classes of people. One is the managerial class, the members of which are very often far from entrepreneurial. Most managers in major companies have never had to earn a dollar on their own account: they have always sat on the back of somebody else's money, somebody else's structure, somebody else's company and they are not at all entrepreneurial. They preserve in a guild-like fashion the benefits and the attributes that go with being part of an elite and a class. Unlike nearly every single member of the cabinet, I would remind the Senate I am one of the few people in parliament who have operated at both an international and a local level at the highest level of business and at the lowest level of business, owning and managing my own businesses. I know of what I speak.

Similarly, the directors' class can sometimes be categorised in the same manner. There is a particular person who will find himself—and sometimes herself—repeated on countless companies because of the way the club operates. Directors recommend their succeeding directors and it becomes a kind of mates' class. They, too, operate in a system of power and control which can be to the detriment of shareholders en masse. The average shareholder, in fact, is very little more than simply a paper holder in a company and is as far removed from capitalism as it is really possible to be.

We think there are important elements which have to be attended to in terms of the modern relationship between governments and parliaments representing the people and the powerful interests controlling our economies and affecting our societies and communities. Those interests have to be attended to in terms of much greater democratisation, much greater responsiveness to the community as a whole and much greater concern with public interest. Of course, whilst I am illustrating some of the weaknesses of the system as it is, we must recognise that there are many very good pioneers in companies—pioneering managers, pioneering directors and pioneering entrepreneurs—who operate their companies, their corporations and their enterprises in the public interest and who, in fact, advance the cause of good corporate governance, good corporate management and good relations with the societies out of which they make their profits, their sales and their wealth. Those sorts of people are to be congratulated and encouraged.

The Australian Democrats have led the way on corporate law reform. When Labor and the coalition sought to make no changes to the Company Law Review Bill by signing off a majority report on that basis, the Australian Democrats issued a comprehensive minority report calling for numerous improvements. Our report forced changes to be considered.

When the bill was passed in June 1998, it included the following changes, all prompted by the Australian Democrats' report: companies must now disclose the remuneration of directors and top managers; `whistleblowing' directors can call meetings of members; overseas disclosures must also be made available in Australia; the rights of shareholders to appoint directors are safeguarded; listed companies must give 28 days notice of a meeting of members; performance in relation to environmental legislation must be reported; safeguards against fraudulent lodgment of documents which must be put with the ASIC; proxies can now be sent by fax and the chair must declare all proxies; and directors must declare that financial statements accord with the law.

We are pleased to see these advances to corporate law but there is more to be done. I have gratefully accepted the offer from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell) to have the following referred to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities: compulsory disclosure to shareholders of their privileges and rights; establishment of corporate governance boards to ensure responsible company governance; the introduction of preferential voting for directors; the establishment of an internal audit committee; and a requirement that companies make disclosures in relation to proceedings against them in relation to the Corporations Law and the Trade Practices Act.

Now, with the consideration of the future of Telstra, there is the opportunity to introduce reforms to what is at present our own Australian company, the one that belongs to all Australian people, whom we are here to represent. We want to ensure that Australia's No. 1 company adopts best practice in its corporate structures and processes.

I will be proposing amendments in two areas. The first is the area of corporate governance. Perhaps the most important issue affecting accountability in corporate management is the structure applied by law to corporate governance. This issue embodies the basic conflict that advocating greater accountability raises: whether the shareholders' interests and the public interest are better served by a model that promotes minimum accountability, maximum freedom and lowest cost or by an alternative model which includes maximum accountability, ensuring less opportunity for fraud and mismanagement and greater adherence to best commercial and community practice.

As fundamental principles, the Australian Democrats always favour greater accountability, greater openness, greater transparency, better representation and more democracy. The existing corporate governance structure gives very wide-ranging operational management duties to the main board of directors. They have powers to determine their own remuneration and to appoint and remunerate company auditors, who are supposed to see that they are being honest. They can nominate themselves for re-election, they can initiate changes in the constitution and they can control the conduct of shareholder meetings and voting procedures.

These powers alone create situations where major conflicts of interest, corruption and mismanagement can arise and go unchecked, as the very individuals who may be affected by these things are the ones who are responsible for their management and elimination. Fortunately, it is seldom that corruption and mismanagement does reach that level. Never theless, it has been a danger and it remains a danger.

Clearly, this issue goes to the heart of managerial accountability to shareholders and the public interest. At worst, directors and the managerial elite can evade their full responsibilities to the public interest and to all shareholders. These issues are at the heart of managerial and board accountability.

As a means of improving this situation, the Australian Democrats propose that companies be required to separate the normal business and internal management functions of the board from the governance functions of ensuring openness and accountability. A new governing board, elected directly by shareholders, not shareholding, should exercise these governance functions. The main directors would continue to be elected by shareholding, representing, of course, where the financial weight lies. They would exercise normal main board functions of business and management.

This would have the additional benefits of simplifying and reducing the role, responsibilities and workload of the principal board directors and at the same time increasing their credibility by removing the powers that permit the appearance or reality of a conflict of interest. As a result, directors should be able to make better business management decisions, so improving the company's financial situation and its credibility.

Ultimately, this is about re-establishing the balance of company governance in favour of shareholders rather than management. Why do I stress that with regard to Telstra? Because at the moment it is this parliament which ensures, as far as it can, given the attitude to government, that Telstra delivers appropriate services to the Australian community. Once it is in private hands, by all means the community service obligations and other regulations may contribute to better management by Telstra but, ultimately, the real power will reside in the board and the management. We have to make sure that those people are as representative and thoughtful about accountability and community needs as possible. One way to do that is to make sure that their constitution is appropriately structured. Currently, their constitution is not.

The second area is the democratisation of voting. There is currently a great disparity between the principles of corporate democracy and the rules set out in the Corporations Law governing the internal operations of companies. For example, the existing method of electing company directors on a limited re-election basis allows dominance by control groups and inhibits the likelihood of support being expressed for particular directors. It does not enable minority interests to be heard through more accessible internal procedures, and it forces minority interests to rely on expensive and time consuming formal procedures like the legal system and the ASIC.

To increase the democratisation of company management and operations, the Australian Democrats advocate applying a system of preferential or cumulative voting to the election of directors of listed companies, requiring all directors to be elected annually with each share obtaining as many votes as there are vacancies. The number of directors to be elected would be determined according to the company's constitution. One of the requirements of good company law is that there should be a scheme setting out the steps company management must follow to achieve not only best commercial practice but also best community practice. The scheme should be paired with a comprehensive mechanism to enable shareholders and outsiders to monitor what management is actually doing and, where necessary, require that it comply with the law.

Serious deficiencies exist in the current Corporations Law, even as it has been recently amended and improved, which contribute to the disparity between the rules governing the internal operations of companies and the principles of corporate democracy. The existing method of electing company directors on a limited re-election basis is one such deficiency, allowing dominance by control groups and reducing the possibility of support being expressed for particular directors. This is an aspect of all corporate structures which is to be regretted. It does not enable minority interests to be heard through more accessible internal procedures and it forces shareholders to rely on expensive and time consuming procedures. That should not be the case for the over two million shareholders of Telstra.

A better alternative would be to adapt the system of preferential or cumulative voting for the election of directors of listed companies. This system would require all directors to be elected annually, with each share obtaining as many votes as there are vacancies. It is a system well understood by Australians and would improve corporate governance. The number of directors to be elected would be determined according to the company's constitution, and the law would need to specify that each shareholder is free to distribute their allotment of votes as they see fit to those nominated as directors. This proposal would improve the democratisation of the relationship between Telstra company directors and shareholders. If we are going to lose Telstra, let us at least structure it in the best fashion. (Time expired)(Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —Telstra for decades has played an integral role in the development of this—
—Don't read your speech, George.

—Who's reading it? (Quorum formed) I will commence again. Telstra has played an integral role in the development of this nation, not only by bridging the vast distances between population centres in Australia but also by developing an Australian industry that offers world leading technology in communications. The full privatisation of Telstra will mark a momentous degradation of the Australian communications industry and an upheaval of the sorts of communications services that Australians are entitled to expect. The central issue on any further sale of Telstra will be the effects on rural and regional Australia, not only directly through service provision or further job cuts but also in the way that telecommunications will be provided to regional Australia in the future.

speech.para: The further sale of Telstra has become a central political issue. Regional communications has increasingly become the focus of communications policy. The current conflict within the coalition demonstrates that the Telstra privatisation debate and the growing signs of a political rural revolt have significantly raised the temperature of the regional communications debate but so far it has generated more heat than light.

The argument has followed the well-worn track of public ownership versus private, tinkering with the universal service obligation and increasing subsidies to Telstra to do what it has never done well—that is, to provide compatible rural services. However, this debate will not be resolved until we address the central issue of regional telecommunications. Before building on structures of the past, which have already been demonstrated to be inadequate in meeting the communications needs of rural and regional Australia, we should be seeking to develop an approach that is compatible with the communications systems of the future.

As a publicly owned company, Telstra has a responsibility to the Australian people as a whole. Previously, this responsibility was fulfilled in a number of ways, including a clear obligation and commitment to provide telephone services to all Australians, not only profitable services. Telstra also has a commitment to Australian jobs in direct employment and indirectly through its support and development of secondary industries in Australia. We now have a thriving electronics industry that provides the equipment necessary to run the Telstra network. Efficient telecommunications in all its facets was an integral component of business opportunities and business costs, with increasing reliance on electronic commerce in Australia and throughout the world.

Telstra, as one of the world's largest telecommunication companies, spends a significant amount of money in the course of its operations and development of its business each year. According to its industry development plan:
Telstra plans to spend up to $4.4 billion on capital expenditures and investments in the 1998 financial year.

Traditionally, Telstra has had a significant policy of purchasing locally in order to support Australian industry. This policy has had a particular focus on small and medium sized businesses that supply Telstra from the electronics industry amongst others.

For the last 15 years, Australia has developed a significant electronics industry, the bulk of which has come through supplying to Telstra. Its export contribution to the Australian economy has been lifted from $50 million a year to $1 billion per year, although it has to be said that we are still suffering a growing deficit in this area of trade of in the region of 10 to one. This industry has grown solidly through Telstra and its commitment to supporting Australian industry.

In Telstra's latest industry development plan, however, only a few months after its part privatisation, the tidings are no longer as supportive for the Australian electronics industry. According to its plan:
Differences between global best practice and Australian conditions will not be sustainable. Local industry must meet the same best practice objectives of its offshore competitors.

As a privatised company, Telstra will now place the interests of its shareholders first. The overwhelming factor that will drive Telstra will be profit. The previous success of secondary industries in Australia that have been built with Telstra's support will end. There will be sacrifice for off the shelf solutions which will see our telecommunications industry settle for outdated technology instead of being at its leading edge.

Telstra will now be shopping in the global supermarket for the best bargains it can find when it purchases its equipment. In light of the Asian crisis, with depreciating currencies all around us and numerous countries desperate to earn export dollars, it is easy to see that, through no fault of their own, many Australian companies will be outpriced unfairly by overseas competition. Telstra points to this in its development plan, when it states:

Typically, Telstra's direct spend with Australian SME's has been around 30% of its total spend. This strong support for SME's who offer commercially attractive products and services will continue, but Telstra believes that most of the future opportunities for Australian industry will be in niche market products and services for the regional and world market.

The importance of Telstra to Australian industry is not only represented in its direct economic contribution but also in the essential service that it provides. The success of future Australian industrial development, particularly in rural Australia, depends on the communications service that Telstra will provide.

For regional Australia to successfully compete in business, it is vital that it has the same services as the metropolitan areas in terms of Internet, fax, mobile phone and digital communications. Without regional equality of these services, industry and business in rural Australia will not survive. A privatised Telstra will be focused on the more profitable metropolitan centres and these services will be reluctantly provided to regional Australia, if at all. Perhaps now is the time to rethink our communications model—particularly as it relates to regional and rural Australia—to reassess its adequacy in meeting the communications requirements of regional and rural communities into the future.

The information age is forcing all of us to rethink our assumptions about our society and how it functions. Perhaps this is the opportunity to develop and adopt new and radical solutions for our communications network of the future. Privatisation is not the answer.

Since its part privatisation, Telstra has cut its employment significantly. It announced in September 1996 that it intended to reduce its employee numbers by 22,000 in the 1998-99 financial year. It has already cut more than 17,000 jobs, according to the union that represents Telstra workers. The greatest effect of these job cuts has been felt in rural Australia, firstly, as a loss of desperately needed income to those towns and, secondly, as a severe reduction of service by Telstra in rural areas. The government of Western Australia, in the recent Senate inquiry into the full privatisation of Telstra, submitted that:

It is expected that full privatisation would have some impact on the number of Telstra staff located in non-metropolitan areas. Telstra has already withdrawn many staff previously located outside the major cities, however, it has not yet put in place adequate arrangements for sending staff to country areas when needed as evidenced by the slow response to some telephone system outages.
The slow response in service to rural areas has meant that there are often delays of several weeks both in new connections and to restore faults.

In its current position, Telstra is clearly holding a monopoly stranglehold over the provision of Australian telecommunications services. In this position, it can easily exploit consumers, particularly if it is privately controlled. The government insists that Telstra will be forced to maintain its service levels through the customer service guarantee and the universal service obligation. The explanatory memorandum circulated by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, contends that:

The public interest in telecommunications is protected through the comprehensive community and regulatory safeguards set out in the Telecommunications Act 1997 , the Telstra Corporation Act 1991 and . . . the Trade Practices Act 1974 .

This government contends that there is sufficient regulation already to monitor Telstra and that any further regulation will interfere with the rights of other shareholders in Telstra. The Communications Expert Group, in their submission to the recent Senate committee inquiry, disagree with the confidence of the minister and point out that:
The customer service guarantee is not effective and is currently not being implemented. There are either deficiencies in the promulgation or enforcement of the customer service guarantee.
The Communications Expert Group also highlighted the reality of government's ability to control Telstra as a huge private monopoly. They said:

A major concern is the access that a privatised Telstra will have to legal resources, compared to the legal resources made available to government departments and smaller carriers. The access to legal resources makes the imposition of $10 million fines of doubtful value, as it makes commercial sense to mount a $1 million legal defence which will tie up a department's legal, financial and manpower resources to defeat the charge.
It makes simple economic sense to retain a monopoly in government hands. A private monopoly is clearly able to exploit consumers without the public benefit that government ownership provides.

As a profit driven private monopoly, Telstra will be like any other private company. It will comply with government regulation only when it is forced to comply. Under full privatisation, the government will be waging a never-ending war in the courts if it hopes to enforce Telstra's universal service obligations.

Perhaps the opportunity now prevails to resolve this not by privatisation but by a radical restructure of our telecommunications giant in such a fashion that would ensure it is more responsive and in tune to the community it seeks to serve. For example, in the US, telecommunications companies specialising in rural communications are increasingly common and are growing at a startling rate, with some achieving up to 30 per cent of market share. In Canada, for example, New Brunswick Telecom has been instrumental in providing job opportunities and investment in a rural province.

What matters most in rural Australia is access to world-class outcomes, not only 64-kilobit per second links but also customer service, networked applications, tailored regional pricing packages, technology optimised for regional geography and corporate focus on their needs. The central objective for regional telecommunications must be nothing less than the achievement of parity between regional Australia and the south-east corner of Australia. A radical new approach to the provision of world-class telecommunications to the bush could be the cornerstone for the revitalisation of regional and rural communities.

Even now the government has no understanding of the real issue. The problem is structural and requires a structural solution. Without a structural solution, the options offered by the coalition, such as capital grants schemes or extending the USO, will have a marginal impact at best. The problems with regional telecommunications have been apparent for years—chronic underinvestment and the obsolescence of equipment, the lack of regionalised marketing strategies to drive consumer demand and the physical and psychological distance between regional communities and industry decision makers.

Regional communications are very different from metropolitan communications. Demand characteristics, demographics, optimal technology choices, network geography and levels of competition are all different in regional Australia. The imposition of legacy solutions on these markets cannot deliver the world-class competitiveness that regional businesses and homes desperately need. The solution to the communications service that is provided to regional Australia lies in investment. There has to be a separate approach taken to metropolitan and rural telecommunications within a comprehensive telecommunications framework as defined by government through public debate, not developed haphazardly by the privatised carriers around their boardrooms without being subjected to public scrutiny or forced to show commitment.

The coalition government does not have a comprehensive telecommunications policy at all. Its approach is one of haphazardly placing bandaids on gaping wounds and making policy on the run. This is again clearly demonstrated by the hastily cobbled together political fix with the Nationals to secure their support for the Telstra sell-off. The tragedy is, however, that if we can believe what is being reported, the so-called fix will not address the communications problems in the bush, nor will it save the National's political hide.

Rural and regional Australians are relying ever increasingly on telecommunications services for every part of their personal and business use. Without this service at an equal level and cost it will be isolated. It requires these services before it can be interlinked with metropolitan Australian industry. If it does not have this opportunity it will never be linked to the industrial heartland of Australia that is currently centred on major metropolitan cities.

We have already witnessed the results of the sale of one-third of Telstra by this government. Amongst other problems, the quality and level of service provided by Telstra, particularly in rural areas, has dropped significantly. The proceeds of that sale have been squandered in the already well-documented Natural Heritage Trust fiasco. That has been the largest pork-barrelling exercise that this country has ever seen. In short, the one-third sale of Telstra can only be described as a national disgrace.

The Australian public are entitled to demand more from their government than short-sighted policies and fire sales. If the recent election result in Queensland contains a message for governments it is clearly that Australians are sick and tired of economic rationalism and its effect on communities. There is no valid reason whatsoever, economic or social, to privatise Telstra any further, just as there was no social or economic reason to privatise any part of it in the first place.
