What we need is a serious and comprehensive policy approach on the communications and information industries as a whole. We need to ensure that regional and rural Australia has access to these services on at least an equal basis. The Australian Labor Party has a clear policy on communications that will ensure that rural and regional Australia is not left behind.

We will not be about making decisions on telecommunications in this country, which in many respects will determine the capacity of us as a nation to compete in the global marketplace on an equal footing, based on the political quick fixes that are needed to stitch up a coalition that is in disunity, disharmony and disgrace. We have a telecommunications policy being driven in this country by the desire of a Prime Minister to get a political fix to be able to go to an election within the next four or five weeks with a policy stitched up with the numbers in this Senate to privatise what can be the cornerstone of our competitiveness into the future.

This has nothing to do with any economic rational decision. This has nothing to do with any social commitment to people in the bush. This has nothing to do with bringing rural and regional Australia into the industrial network of this nation. This has everything to do with trying to secure the seats of two or three people on the other side. The strange thing about it is that it will backfire. The one good thing for those of us on this side of the chamber is that when we come back after the next election a lot of your faces will not be there to look at. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 is the legislation that John Howard said we would not see in this parliament, that would not be considered. This legislation is yet another John Howard breach of faith. This legislation before the Senate lacks a mandate. At least half the coalition senators who will be voting on this legislation were elected to the Senate when John Howard said that he would not contemplate in the life of this parliament privatising any more than one-third of Telstra. This breaches yet another John Howard commitment to the electorate.
—Senator Faulkner, you should refer to the Prime Minister as the `Prime Minister' or `Mr Howard'.

—This is a political device that is electorally bankrupt. This is another prime ministerial broken promise. Our communications provider in Australia has become a non-core promise. I recall an interview that John Laws conducted on 23 January 1996 with Mr Howard in Sydney. Mr Laws asked:

speech.para: So you'd sell one-third of Telstra in that first term?
Mr Howard responded:

In that first term one-third of Telstra, no more. Whether we will go further will be something we will make a decision on towards the end of our first term and when we get to the end of that first term, if we decide to sell more, we will put a proposal to the Australian people as part of our policy seeking their support. Now, nothing can be fairer, more open, more explicit, more democratic than that.
This is yet another broken promise, and what a massive broken promise it is.

This government has an ideological obsession to destroy the public ownership of Telstra before the public has had an opportunity to consider the issue. The `For Sale' sign was put up before Mr Howard had the permission of the owners to sell it. You have got to ask yourself why. Why have we got this situation? It is very simple. This is Mr Howard's only chance. He has got to get this legislation through the parliament before the next election, before the annihilation of the National Party in the Senate and the House of Representatives.

You have got to ask yourself what has happened to the National Party in this country. What has happened? Why has there been this evolution from the National Party of John McEwen, Doug Anthony and Ian Sinclair through to the modern National Party of Charles Blunt, Tim Fischer and Ron Boswell? Why has there been this change? You would not have seen John McEwen and Doug Anthony roll over and have their tummies tickled by John Howard or any other Liberal Party leader on a proposition like this. It never happened in the past. Those leaders, in the great tradition of National Party leaders, would at least have stood up to the Liberal Party. But the current National Party has not got the herbs, has not got the bottle, to do it.

There are some members of the National Party in the House of Representatives—Mrs De-Anne Kelly and Mr Bob Katter—who say that they would now cross the floor on the issue of Telstra. Of course, Mrs De-Anne Kelly, the member for Dawson, did not say that at the time the bill was before the House of Representatives. Oh, no. She went along with the pack and voted for the full privatisation of Telstra. I have got to say that Mr Katter was a little more careful. We all know what an unprincipled windbag he is. He was clever enough—

talk.start.para: —Withdraw that!
—Senator Faulkner, you should withdraw that.

—I withdraw that, Mr Acting Deputy President. He was clever enough not to vote at all. Now they say that, if the bill came back to the House, they would cross the floor. But the real action is here in the Senate. The National Party depends on the National Party senators to hold the faith—and what a crew they are depending on! We have Senator Ron Boswell, part of the new Blunt-Boswell-Fischer leadership of the National Party. He is the only man in the history of the National Party in the Senate not to hold a portfolio in a coalition govern ment as Leader of the National Party in the Senate. Even on the occasion when he held a shadow portfolio, when he was part of the shadow cabinet, he became shadow minister without portfolio because he could not make a contribution, because he would not stand up for the bush and because he would not stand up for regional and rural Australia.

speech.para: Look who is behind him: Senator O'Chee. You know what he is like. He puffs himself up full of bombast, pomposity and self-importance. He did that before the last election and, when asked about the distribution of National Party preferences, what did Senator O'Chee say? He said:
That's not going to happen, so there is not going to be one seat, not one seat in Queensland, where so much as one preference of the National Party will be distributed to One Nation.
Did he come in and apologise when National Party preferences elected eight One Nation members?

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is twofold. First, this is utterly irrelevant. Secondly, when did Senator Faulkner apologise to the Baillieus?
—There is no point of order.
—Order! Senator O'Chee!

—Did he come in and apologise when, in eight seats, National Party preferences elected One Nation candidates? Incredibly enough, two of them—Mulgrave and Barambah, I think—were previously held by the National Party, and still National Party preferences elected One Nation candidates.

speech.para: Look at the rest of the team. What about Senator Sandy Macdonald? The first time we even heard of Senator Sandy Macdonald was when he said he would stand up on the issue of Telstra. That was the first time we had ever heard of him. His brief foray into the public limelight was, of course, his last. He is just another patsy for the Liberals. He said he would stand up on Telstra, but that he would never cross the floor.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order: that comment is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.
—I would ask you to withdraw, Senator Faulkner.

—I withdraw it, Mr Acting Deputy President. What about the contribution of Senator Brownhill, the Parliamentary Secretary? At least he has got a frontbench job, unlike the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Boswell. They would not give him a ministry or even a parliamentary secretaryship.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: this speech is amusing, but I am at a loss to find any relevance between frontbench ministerial arrangements and the Telstra privatisation bill which is currently before the chair.
—There is no point of order.

—I looked up Senator Brownhill on the parliamentary database. I found that, in 1998, he made 10 contributions in this chamber. Eight of them, I might say, were tablings and incorporations. He has made two speeches in this calendar year, one of which was of 20 seconds duration. That is the contribution of Senator Brownhill and the National Party in New South Wales.

speech.para: What about Senator Tambling? Senator Tambling is well known. He was elected to the House of Representatives as the member for the Northern Territory, as a Liberal. He joined the Liberal party room in the House of Representatives as a member of the Country-Liberal Party in the Northern Territory. When he came to the Senate he chose to be a member of the National Party. He joined the National Party party room. You could understand why. He thought that was the way to advancement. He thought that, amongst that group of lacklustre, low-life hacks, he had a real opportunity to have a career. He has proved it, hasn't he? He also has now become a parliamentary secretary in the Senate.
Then, of course, there is Senator McGauran, the last member of the National Party team in the Senate, the man that Jeff Kennett—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order. Mr Acting Deputy President, I understand why you would want to give Senator Faulkner a lot of latitude in trying to get to the point, because he has a lot of difficulty, but for five minutes now he has failed to address the bill before the chair. I strongly suggest that this contribution is irrelevant. If it is not, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would be grateful if you could explain how it is relevant to the Telstra privatisation bill.
—There is no point of order, but I would draw Senator Faulkner's attention to the bill before the chair and ask him to address his comments to that bill.

—As I was saying, Mr Acting Deputy President, the fate of this bill is in the hands of all senators. The National Party particularly have been waxing lyrical about how they will stand up to the government on Telstra. I think their record needs to be exposed in this chamber. I mentioned Senator McGauran. Mr Kennett, the Premier of Victoria, put his weights up. He said that he was simply not up to it. The man who, when he entered parliament, found the ringing of the bells so offensive that he actually taped over the speaker system so he could not hear them and consequently missed a whole number of divisions was simply not up to it. This is the standard of the National Party representation in this chamber.

speech.para: The National Party will not stand up to the Liberal Party. The new Blunt-Fischer-Boswell leadership does not compare with the old days of McEwen and Anthony. They will not stand up to the Liberals. They will roll over. They will sell out their rural constituency. The only major political party in this country that will stand up for the bush in the next election on the issue of Telstra will be the Labor Party. We will not let rural Australia down. We will not let the bush down on this issue.

We know by what amount the National Party have betrayed their constituency. Apparently the figure is around $400 million. They have been sold a $400 million pup by Mr Howard. They are stark raving mad to sign up to this deal with Mr Howard and the big end of town. They are crazy from the point of view of their own political survival. They have to have rocks in their head because the bush will not forgive them for what they have done. They should look at what Labor is doing in opposing this act of stupidity on the part of the government.

What the Nationals are doing is leaving themselves open to political replacement on the national political scene by the ultra-rightists of the One Nation party. They are ensuring their own electoral oblivion. The National Party membership and branches know it. The people in regional and rural Australia know it and they are furious about it. They will not cop it from the National Party. What about Margaret Smith, the President of the Country Women's Association, who made it absolutely clear that the bush would be the losers in these issues of privatisation? She said that privatised organisations become beholden to shareholders rather than to clients—shareholders like Senator Parer.

I do not think the CWA is stupid. I think it is right on the ball. It knows what is coming if full privatisation occurs. In the same interview Ms Smith said, `I think it is time the coalition government, and certainly the National Party entity of that coalition, took notice of what we are saying.' They will not do so. There is a deal, signed, sealed, delivered, with the weak reeds of the National Party in the Senate and the House of Representatives and, of course, with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, to sell Telstra.

We had Tim Fischer giving a bad impression of a mobile phone salesman with his announcement on analog and digital phones yesterday, which he admits himself was not predicated on the privatisation of Telstra. We had Mr Fischer and Senator Alston behaving like a couple of spivs at a media conference, waving a replica of a mobile phone around, trying to blind the bush with science. They are not wearing it. They are just not copping what the National Party is saying. You do not have to flog off Telstra to do that. I think the bush knows it. It should be done anyway.

The people of Australia, particularly the bush, will not cop this level of spivery. They are not going to cop a short-term allegedly social benefit package which runs out when the short-term windfall from the sale of Telstra runs out. People want jobs into the next century. They want permanency put back into employment, into country towns, into regional cities. That is what they want. That is what the rural and regional constituency of the National Party are asking of their leadership. They want a publicly owned communications system that delivers to clients—in other words, to them—rather than the Parer-type clan.

What we have seen in this debate is an unprecedented gagging of the Senate on this issue. We saw three gag motions last night successfully moved by the government with the support of Senator Colston, who of course holds a tainted vote in this place, and the support of—

talk.start.para: —He's gone home.

—He has gone home, has he? He was happy enough for us to stay here and debate this and he has gone home himself. Nothing would surprise me with Senator Colston. He is here because Queensland electors elected a Labor senator. It is a tainted vote, bought by Mr Howard and the Liberal Party—

—On a point of order, I think that casts a reflection on a colleague in this chamber who, as we all know, has very great health problems and who may well be seeking some attention for his health problems. On that basis, I suggest it is improper to—
—You don't know what he has gone home for.
—Order! Senator Macdonald is making a point of order.
—In fact, I do, but I am not going to tell you. I am suggesting that it is casting aspersions against a senator who we know is not well.

—On the point of order, I deliberately intended to cast an aspersion on Senator Colston. I said he had a tainted vote and that he was bought by the Howard government. Quite clearly it was an aspersion and intended to be such.
—I think you should withdraw that comment.

—I withdraw it. We have a situation where the Howard government has bought Senator Colston's vote and stitched up a deal with Senator Harradine. This is all over; this issue is all over. Don't be under any illusions—the full privatisation of Telstra is as good as done. The National Party does not have the bottle or the guts to stand up for their constituency. They are going to roll over and let the Liberal Party walk all over them. They are going to vote for the full privatisation of Telstra.

speech.para: There is no-one in the National Party contingent in this chamber who has the courage and intestinal fortitude to stand up to the Liberal Party and Mr Howard. They want to; they would like to be able to. They would like to be able to shake off this aura of weakness that surrounds them, but they will not do it. Sure, Mr Katter, Mrs Kelly and perhaps a few other Nationals might in the House of Representatives, but that will be purely symbolic—the deed is done. It matters in the Senate and they will not stand up. The deal is done with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston. With Senator Colston it was through the buying of this tainted vote to ensure he got the deputy presidency of the Senate. And Senator Harradine, the great democrat—the man who said he would never vote for a gag motion—voted for three in succession last night. A slimy deal has been done in relation to this particular matter.

I am absolutely confident and quite certain that the Telstra privatisation bill will go through. I said it last night and I say it again: it will go through with the Labor Party fighting it every inch of the way. Not only will we fight it in the parliament, but also we will fight it in the election. We will make it a centrepiece of what Labor stands for.

We will not back down and we will make absolutely clear to the Australian people that the only way this bill will not be proclaimed is for a Labor government to be elected. We will ensure that every single person in Australia, particularly those who live outside the major capital cities, understands that commitment from Labor. It will become absolutely clear that the only way that the privatisation of Telstra can be stopped is, of course, to vote Labor.

There is no urgency about this matter. Last night Senator Harradine would not let one Labor member of the Senate actually put a case to argue against the urgency of this bill. They could not put the obvious case that there is no urgency with this bill, because even the government is not planning to proclaim the legislation until after the election.

What they are worried about is the numbers in the Senate after the election. They know the National Party will be wiped out. They are fearful that the government will be wiped out and that they will be replaced with One Nation senators who apparently are opposed to the privatisation of Telstra.

What a sell-out from the government, Senator Colston and Senator Harradine! We want to know what the details of the deal that has been done are. We really do want Senator Harradine for once to come into this chamber, own up and say what has gone on behind closed doors with the government. Forget about his dealings behind closed doors on the native title bill; that has occurred. Tell us the truth for once about Telstra. Own up to what you have done behind closed doors and the deal with Mr Howard. But, rest assured, Labor will never sell out. We will fight it right through and I am confident in the election we will win.

talk.start.para: —I start by quoting the opening lines I made in a speech on 18 October 1996 when the first tranche of the sale of Telstra was being debated. At that time I said:

speech.para: Today we have heard from government senators their usual diatribe about why they should be able to sell a third of Telstra.

There is a big difference between this debate and that debate, because this time we are not hearing from government senators as to why the remainder should be sold off. We are certainly not hearing from National Party senators as to why it should be sold off.

But it is interesting, because we have certainly seen what they have had to say in the media in recent weeks about it and some of their lower house colleagues have a lot to say about it even today. What happened? What bought them off? Why isn't the government here contributing to this debate? Let me tell you, the people of Australia want to know the reasons.

I have a very large quantity of press clippings here that I have accumulated in very recent times from the rural areas of western and northern New South Wales, west of the Great Dividing Range. They are absolutely horrified at the sale of Telstra. They do not approve of the sale of Telstra. If the National Party were reflecting to the coalition forces what people out there were saying, they would be in here speaking very volubly in opposition to the continued sale of the remainder of Telstra.

Telstra should not have been sold in the first place. Why sell an asset that brings in over $1 billion worth of revenue in dividends—revenue that is spent for the good of this country, for schools, for hospitals and for infrastructure? But this government wants to sell the farm. As a letter to the editor in a local paper said, once you sell the farm you are gone. You can only sell the farm once. You cannot sell Telstra two or three times.

What replaces that $1 billion worth of dividends that Telstra has been paying the government and the people of Australia? What happens to the resources and the services that those dividends actually purchase and provide for the people of this country? They will have to find an alternative source. I guess we can all hang onto our hip pockets because it will have to come from there.

Infrastructure does not need to be built and maintained once; it needs continual refurbishment and upgrading. It seems that this government has forgotten that. They are talking about the infrastructure services that they will build with the money from the sale but, once that infrastructure has been built, it will require additional funding to keep the infrastructure current and technologically advanced in areas where we do not have the population and the businesses to ensure that revenue is coming in.

I am sure that Telstra, or the communications companies, will do exactly what the banks have done to us in rural areas where there is not very much service demand, where there is lots of land between individual people or individual services. What will happen? We will be neglected. It will get to be a two-tier service. In the cities, where there is lots of turnover, lots of revenue generated, it will be kept at the absolute peak of performance. But they forget about those of us who live west of the great sandstone curtain. That is what happens: they forget about those who live west of the great sandstone curtain.

It is important to remember, when this government talks about a community service obligation or a universal service obligation, that it will apply to Telstra. But they are only talking in terms of a phone service; they are only talking in terms of the handset and the copper wires that are strung around. They are not talking about alternative technology that is being developed or other technology that Telstra and other telecommunications companies are into providing.

That is something that people in rural areas need to be very conscious of. I think it is something that coalition senators opposite, and particularly National Party senators, need to remember: their universal service obligation is not for the whole raft of Telstra services and telecommunications that they think it is, or for what might happen in the future regarding telecommunications advances that are made. And services and communications advances are being made at a very rapid rate and are improving markedly.

If we do not have access, and if there is no universal service obligation applying, those of us in the bush will have to pay for it, and we will have to pay more because, as there is no USO, it will not get any cross-subsidy. If there is some subsidy from the government, pray, may I ask, where will that money come from? They will not have the dividend stream that they have had with Telstra.

I cannot imagine that a fully privatised Telstra will be any different from any other large business in this country. They will be able to get up to all sorts of dodges. They will want to minimise their tax, and they especially will want to reduce the dividends they are paying. Up to 35 per cent of Telstra can be sold to foreign ownership; 35 per cent of the dividend could be going overseas and not staying in this country. That is another thing that is of grave concern to people. We know that the government is putting a five per cent ceiling on the number of shares that people from overseas can purchase, but it will only require seven large organisations to take up five per cent each to basically control Telstra.

How the devil can the thousands of mums and dads in this country, to whom we are told these shares will be sold, have a shareholders' vote to control the directors? Of course, it will be stacked by the seven from overseas with the 35 per cent. Can you imagine, if a million mums and dads have shares, how many of them will turn up for shareholders' meetings? What venue in this country will you be able to use to hold these people if they all turn up?

talk.start.para: —The same ones that they use for Qantas and BHP.

—As you have just said, the same ones. That means that very few people will turn up. The major investment organisations, the overseas companies and owners will turn up, but not the mums and dads. What control, what input, will the mums and dads of this country have? They might have their 200 shares. They certainly will not have 28,000 shares like some ministers here have. What control and what access will they have regarding future directions? They will have none, because they will have no power. They will get their small dividends each year.

speech.para: But when it comes to this country's future directions, when it comes to the important decisions being made, the mums and dads, the battlers that Mr Howard talks about, will have no power in the boardrooms. Can you imagine someone with 200 shares getting a seat on the board of Telstra in competition with somebody from overseas owning five per cent or one of the major institutional investors in this country? There only needs to be a couple of the major institutional investors ganging together, and what they want they will get. That is the danger and the problem with this legislation.

People need to be reminded that we will be allowing 35 per cent of our telecommunications system, our major one—basically it is a monopoly—as a company to be owned by overseas people, overseas companies. It may be that it is to be owned by as few as seven entities, because five per cent is the maximum percentage of shares they can have. I do not think that is particularly what people in this country want.

talk.start.para: —It still leaves 65 per cent in Australian control.
—You do not seem to understand about control and who has power when holding a certain number of shares. When you have 200 shares as opposed to a five per cent share of the company—
—What about Qantas? How dare you criticise us.

—I know who has the power, and it certainly is not those with the 200 shares. It is absolutely ridiculous. Obviously, those opposite are continuing on with the attitude of arrogance, the born to rule attitude of, `We know best and we'll tell you.' It is absolutely appalling. The government is taking no heed, no cognisance, of what people in rural and regional Australia need.

speech.para: I think it is important to remember community service obligations in rural and regional parts of New South Wales. Let us go back to about the year 1995 and look at a number of those electorates: in Gwydir, there was a cross-subsidy of $13.54 million; in Parkes, there was a cross-subsidy of $15.21 million; in Calare, $3.29 million; in New England, $4.24 million; and in Riverina, $4.06 million. This will be a universal service obligation only when they have to get the money, and it will be for their phone line only, nothing else. It is just not appropriate; it does not make commonsense for the shareholders to want to continue making those sorts of payments.

talk.start.para: —Sue, we know what you're going to say. Why don't you give it a break?

—Why don't you actually say something, Senator Macdonald? Why don't you go out and talk to people in the bush and really listen to them? You are not doing that. It did not help in Queensland with One Nation. We saw what happened there. The coalition got absolutely demolished because they took no notice of the people in the bush.
—I am just trying to save Australia.
—Order, Senator Macdonald. Senator West, just so we can both live through this, try to avoid responding.

—It is important for people to recognise that many, many of those in the bush who comprise the natural constituency of the conservatives are very concerned about this. We have seen comments from groups such as the CWA who have concerns about the creation of a telecommunications underclass, that the government has failed to guarantee a single extension to the services offered to rural and regional Australia under the universal service obligations. For that failure, the government is to be criticised.

speech.para: Written into the universal service plan is that a standard telephone service be accessible. But people in rural areas now want more than a standard telephone service. A standard telephone service will not allow people to expand their businesses. We also hear people talk of there being a push for timed local calls for business; it is an option.

talk.start.para: —He announced it for everybody this morning.
—What will that do? The introduction of these things is the thin end of the wedge.
—It has been announced this morning for everybody, Senator.

—Who is going to pay for it? The pork barrel must be out. There must be an election coming up. They have got the pork barrel going. Some of these guarantees that have been given to various individuals around the place in the last 24 to 48 hours are becoming public. If that were happening in New South Wales, I suspect that ICAC would be taking a very close look at some of them—and I mean that very seriously. I think it ill-behoves people to make some of these promises and to say that they have been given guarantees, with nobody else knowing about them. I suspect that, if this were happening in New South Wales, ICAC would be extremely interested.

speech.para: I have mentioned foreign ownership. As I say, it will take telecommunications out of the hands of the people in the bush, the mums and dads and put it into the hands of those who have larger shareholdings. I do not know why this government has this hang-up that private is more efficient than public. A lot of research is being done on that, and it is not being borne out, but this government does not tend to want to agree with that or even listen to it.

We have also seen in recent times—unless, of course, this got changed too in the last 24 hours—a cut in access to the remote access channel called Reach. This access channel enables television stations to feed their signal down the line to city areas. This will result in less coverage of local events that have national and international significance. This will mean less coverage of those local events on the national media. It will further remove from people in the bush, and remove from city people, knowledge of what is going on out there. It is very, very concerning that this has already started to happen. We know the service to country areas has deteriorated in the last two years. That has been admitted here by the minister, and he says that he will up the fines. But I think on occasions it would be cheaper to pay the fines than actually provide the service.

I would draw the Senate's attention to a street survey undertaken in Parkes. The town of Parkes is not a rabid Labor town; it is a country town. Of seven people surveyed, four were totally opposed to the sale of Telstra, two said yes and one did not care. Those sorts of snapshots of what the feeling of the community is are vitally important.

There are headlines like `The bush will not cop the sale of Telstra', that `Telstra guarantees are being sought'. These guarantees were being sought by National Party candidates. There is `Questions on the Telstra sale'. There are editorial headlines like `Telstra float not as good as it appears'. That was in the Daily Advertiser in Wagga—and that is not some socialist rag, let me tell you, it is a conservative newspaper, but it obviously taps into the feelings and thoughts of its community. The Daily Liberal in Dubbo—well named—`The Telstra carrot a real danger'. These are the sorts of headlines that all the regional and rural New South Wales newspapers in particular are full of. I think it is important that people recognise this situation: people in the bush are very scared and very concerned that they are going to lose out in this situation.

I wait with interest to see some of these plans that they have unveiled today—the old pork barrel gets greased up—and I wonder if it is going to be like the telecommunications infrastructure package that was announced last time. I wait for people to remember that it was a per capita funding worked out on the percentage of each state's population living outside non-capital areas. It took no cognisance of the size of the state. And guess which state got the most money? Guess whose votes changed in here and enabled the legislation to pass? Guess which states got the most money?

In New South Wales, the per capita funding was $15.99. In Victoria, it was $22.21 a head. In Queensland, it was $29.70 a head. In South Australia, it was $67.60; they did quite well. I do not have the Western Australian figures with me. But it is quite obvious that, when the Tasmanians were getting $208.41 per head, the Tasmanian people were doing far better in a much smaller size state than those of us who came from the larger states and the more populous states. It was not a fair distribution of this allocation of money, and I wonder what has happened this time. What has the government got up to this time with its smoke and mirrors to make it appear that this is a wonderful salvation and a wonderful solution for everybody? We have the situation, of course, where the second two-thirds of Telstra was not going to be sold, was it? We now have another promise that has been broken.

Today, we have an outline of a whole lot of promises that the government have made that they are going to deliver on Telstra. Why would we believe that when they have core and non-core promises—they have broken any number of promises—and now they have come out with a whole stack of further promises that are pork barrel type promises? They are the ones that go up in a whiff of smoke and all you get is a very aromatic bacon smell as it burns. That is all that people are going to get. People need to realise that this organisation should remain within the ownership of the people who already own it—the 18 million Australians who already own two-thirds of Telstra. (Time expired)(Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 is about broken promises and about compounding the errors, failures and misrepresentations of the first one-third of Telstra sale and multiplying them threefold by selling the rest. The sale of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra is poor policy. It will enrich the most wealthy 10 per cent of our community while impoverishing the rest. It will exacerbate the service failures in telecommunications by creating an effective private sector monopoly when the current regulatory system is clearly not succeeding in delivering better consumer outcomes. And it will create a huge accountability problem by setting free Australia's largest company—a company twice the size of BHP or the National Australia Bank—whose profitability will depend entirely on its ability to lobby government and resist and restrict the rigours of regulation. On every front, the sale of the rest of Telstra will be a disaster.

speech.para: I cannot believe that a government that prides itself on fiscal rectitude and sound budgeting could present the Telstra sale bill before this parliament and argue that it is good policy. In the heavy and entirely misleading selling of the privatisation of Telstra by a string of ministers, we have been told that the sale will leave Australia debt free in a few years. Yes, if you sell off two-thirds of Australia's biggest company and raise $40 billion, you can retire a lot of debt, but that is not the full picture.

The real question is this: is the amount of debt being retired greater than the value of the company being sold? In Telstra's case, the answer is very clearly no. The value of debt is reflected in the budget by interest. The value of the company is reflected in Telstra's profit stream. No matter which way you want to measure it, within a few years at the very outside the interest savings will be less than the lost profit stream. That means that the budget will be left worse off, not better off, by the sale of the rest of Telstra.

Telstra's profitability is expected to grow sharply in the coming years with profits rising to about 10 per cent a year. This is because its revenues keep rising on the back of its dominant market position. Its multibillion dollar capital spending program is being wound back and its deep and savage retrenchments have reduced costs. A wide range of analysts, including Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, Merrill Lynch, Macquarie Equities and CS First Boston, are all predicting double digit growth for Telstra.

Investment analyst Ord Minnett, for example, is forecasting Telstra's profits will rise from $2.6 billion last year to $3.6 billion by the year 2000. Two-thirds of that is $2.4 billion and that would flow to the government as dividends or as capital gains in terms of retained earnings—but obviously not if Telstra is sold. If Telstra is sold, then this $2.4 billion is lost to government. In the year 2000, at least it will be offset by a $2.4 billion interest saving, but as Telstra's profitability continues to rise the budget black hole continues to grow and grow substantially.

In evidence presented to the Senate inquiry on this bill, economics professor John Quiggin forecast that, assuming modest growth, the budget black hole will rise to $3.3 billion by 2007. I might add that, in assessing the impact of Telstra's sale on public finances, it is essential to look at the reported profit and not just the dividend. This follows the asset pricing theories of Nobel Prize winning economists Miller and Mogdiliani and is cited by various analysts as the most appropriate way of determining the value of an asset.

But the situation is likely to be even worse than that. As Professor Quiggin correctly points out, the privatisation of Telstra also has income tax implications. Privatised companies are generally able to manipulate dividend payouts to deliver dividends which are fully franked, that is, dividends on which the shareholders need pay no more income tax. At present, whilst Telstra pays company tax, its franking credits are not paid out because the government owns the shares. Telstra this year will generate about $500 million in unrefundable franking credits, rising to about $1.2 billion within a decade. Adding the cost of franking tax credits to dividends and retained profits results in a loss to the budget bottom line of $500 million in the year 2000, rising to $4 billion a year by 2006.

These are incredibly big figures. If Peter Costello or John Fahey were facing a budget blow-out in the social security area of up to $4 billion a year within a decade, they would be screaming from the rooftops and we would have all sorts of allegations about black holes and intergenerational equity, and they would be moving to cut entitlements willy-nilly. They have already shown that they are happy to slash and burn in this area. Despite the great yawning hole that Telstra will leave in our public finances, this government continues to promote the sale as somehow financially prudent. It is not. Selling Telstra will mean that, in less than a decade, we will need to cut services across the board by $4 billion just to balance the books. Each year after that, the gap will get worse. What sort of a legacy is that to leave to future generations?

That is just the loss on the remaining two-thirds. If we include the fire sale price at which the first third of Telstra was sold, the loss blows out to cost the government over $1.2 billion in the year 2000, rising to over $6.5 billion by 2006. The Democrats view the price at which the first third of Telstra was sold last year as positively scandalous. Unfortunately, the scandal of it has not set in the public mind yet. People out there do not realise just how much this government ripped off the 90 per cent of Australians who could not afford to take part in the sale.

Let me go through the arguments again. The government set a share price of around $3.35 a share. Within a day of listing, that rose to over $4, delivering a paper profit to shareholders of $2.6 billion, at public expense. Within a month, the publicly funded windfall gain was up to $5 billion. Eight months later, it now stands at over $11 billion and is still rising. Let us make this very clear: this government sold the first third of Telstra for $11 billion less than it was worth, effectively transferring $11 billion of windfall gains from the public ownership by 100 per cent of Australians to the private ownership by 10 per cent of Australians. And they dared call that a successful float.

Let us look at who profited. Within two months of the float, in a massively publicised $7 billion speculative orgy, over a third of Telstra's shares changed hands. Of the 20 largest shareholders lucky enough to be allocated shares, only one did not take the money and run. One of the biggest winners was the largest foreign investor, the Bank of Ireland, which for its one-month investment in Australia made a profit of over $28 million. In fact, most of the foreign investors sold within the first few months, with windfall capital gains of almost $1 billion, again at public expense. If the government had got the pricing of Telstra right, there should not have been such outrageous windfall gains. Months before the float, stockbrokers were valuing Telstra at between $3.70 and $4 a share. So why did the government set a share price that undervalued the float by $3 billion?

I believe that a massive undervaluation will happen again with the sale of the rest of Telstra. Even with the Commonwealth Bank, when 49 per cent of the company had already been floated, the government still got the final price wrong by about $2.8 billion. I have absolutely no confidence that if this sale bill is approved—and it looks like it will be—the next government, whether it be coalition or Labor, will sell Telstra at a price that is fair to the 90 per cent of us who do not own shares in it. I have complete confidence that they will again deliver a huge, publicly subsidised windfall gains to their friends in the finance sector, to the banks, to the foreign investors and to those who can afford to buy in.

The failure to deliver a genuine improvement in public sector finances by selling one third of Telstra is just one of the many pre-election promises that this government has failed to keep on the Telstra sale. Remember the customer service guarantee? It was supposed to guarantee that service levels would be enhanced on what they were under Labor. Well, on every indicator, they have gotten worse. According to the Australian Communications Authority, the percentage of new rural services provided by the agreed date has fallen from 82 per cent in 1996 to just 64 per cent in March this year. The number of faults in rural areas cleared within a day has fallen from 74 per cent to 59 per cent. No wonder the bush is screaming about the prospect of more of Telstra being sold off. The reason for this decline in service is not hard to find. It is there in the 3,000 Telstra jobs lost from rural areas last year. That includes 248 staff in Tasmania and 517 in Queensland. Even the government's minimal promises last time to Senators Harradine and Colston about keeping jobs in Tassie and rural Queensland were not kept.

Then there was the promise to spend the money on the environment. The Natural Heritage Trust Fund, as we all know, was set up, and Senator Harradine got it topped up by $100 million. But then the bulk of its funding was allocated to the primary industries portfolio. The few increases in environment spending within the fund have been offset by reductions in environment programs within the Department of the Environment proper, where the funding has fallen by $70 million a year, or 30 per cent, since this government took office.

talk.start.para: —That is quite untrue, and you know it.

—It is $70 million a year less, Senator, since you took office. So many holes have developed in the NHT bucket that much very valuable funding has gone to projects previously funded by states, local governments, individuals and other organisations.

speech.para: This bill shows a breathless contempt indeed for parliament, and also for the constitutional separation of powers doctrine, by leaving the decision of whether this bill becomes law in the hands of the executive rather than the parliament. This is because the proclamation of whether this bill becomes law is left up to the incoming government. The constitution of Australia is quite clear about who makes the laws, and it is not the cabinet. Section 51 says that the parliament shall have the power to make laws, but this bill gives cabinet—or, more correctly, Executive Council—the power to make laws, and that is not appropriate. If the government wants this bill passed before the election and actionable only if its mandate is proven, then it should recognise that its mandate can be tested only by the parliament, and that parliament consists of two houses: the House of Representatives and the Senate.

Finally, I wish to move to my second reading amendment. We are discussing this bill in a vacuum—blindfolded—because we do not yet have the report from the Australian Communications Authority on how the universal service obligations can be improved. That report is due on 15 August. It is premature to discuss this bill before that date and before we know what legal changes will be needed to deliver service obligations to the public on things like digital services. Let us remember that the government's customer service guarantee has failed to deliver better services under the partly privatised Telstra. Surely this government would want to ensure that they get the regulatory system right this time before they proceed to sell off the rest. My amendment seeks to defer consideration of the bill until after that report is received, and I would hope that any senators genuinely interested in improving Telstra services would want this information before they consider the sale bill any further.

In conclusion, let me state that the government has not a shred of credibility in insisting that this bill be passed now. Every precondition that the government—or, indeed, Independent senators—set on the first float has been breached. The float was a failure in every sense: in terms of public finance, in terms of customer service and in terms of improving competition. The Telstra one-third sale was a monumental mistake and a monumental public policy failure that enriched a few at the expense of the many. This Senate would be compounding folly and failure threefold if it agreed to the sale of the rest of Telstra, and it would be flying in the face of the 62 per cent of Australians who, according to the recent Morgan poll, are stridently opposed to the sale of Telstra. Those National Party senators, who all seem to be missing at the moment—and, indeed, all senators in this place—should take careful note of the overwhelming and growing public opposition to this sale.

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees, you have foreshadowed that amendment, haven't you?
—Yes.

—I rise in this debate to oppose the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 and to support the second reading amendment to be moved on behalf of the opposition that further consideration of this bill be postponed and be an order of the day for the first day of sittings in 1999.

speech.para: One would understand members of the public being bemused by the fact that we are debating a bill which this government has promised will not be put into effect until after the next election. That is the promise this government has put on the record, if it can be believed, so we are debating a bill in circumstances where the Australian people are to exercise their options and vote on this prospect at some time in the future.

One wonders why it is necessary for this government to seek to anticipate the mandate of the Australian people on this issue by pursuing the resolution of this bill in the Senate now. Firstly, it could have waited until the next sittings, which are due to commence on 10 August, but probably, more appropriately, it could have waited until it actually had the mandate of the Australian people, which I do not believe it will get. But, if it is convinced that this measure has the support of the Australian people, why isn't it prepared to wait until the Australian people have had a chance to consider this proposition, fully fleshed out, with all of the detail laid before them, before the next election?

There are a couple of answers to that. The first is the question of what the coalition will confront in terms of the numbers in this place after the next election. If one is to place any credence at all on recent polling on the issue of Senate voting—and I will refer particularly to the Morgan poll finding No. 3099, which was published in the Bulletin on 30 June 1998—the answer is plain to see. The Morgan poll indicates that the Liberal-National Party representation in this place would fall to 32 seats, the Labor position would remain the same or grow, the Democrat position would be nine—

talk.start.para: —Down.
—Not down actually. According to that poll, it would be up.
—This is on a double.
—No, it is on a half Senate, and I invite you to go and look on your computer. You can access this through the Internet, and I can give you the address later if you need to have a look at it.
—Senator O'Brien, address your comments through the chair.

—I am happy to do that if Senator Macdonald is going to be orderly. The Greens' position appears to fall to one, and One Nation would have five to six seats. There is some uncertainty, but clearly the position on that poll is that the representation of the Liberal-National Party in this place will fall to the point where it would face the ALP, the Democrats—if they remain opposed to the sale of Telstra—and the Greens having a majority. Therefore this legislation would not pass.
—And to One Nation.

—Thank you for reminding me about the One Nation position, Senator Macdonald. Their numbers on that poll, even if they joined with the Liberal and National parties, would still not be a majority. The majority of votes would lie with the ALP, the Democrats and the Greens, which are opposed to this particular legislation. That is the information that is on the public record.

speech.para: If we look at the poll recently conducted in Queensland, there is a bit of a different position. Senator Macdonald would probably prefer the Morgan poll result, in terms of the Senate outcome, to the application of the Queensland poll result, because that result would probably see Senator O'Chee maintain his seat but the Liberal Party's representation would be reduced to one. So I am sure Senator Macdonald would prefer the outcome of the Morgan poll to the application of the Queensland poll to—

talk.start.para: —Reduced to two? Two of us are long-term senators. What a stupid thing to say.

—Thank you for correcting me, Senator Macdonald. I was referring to the numbers that come up in the half-Senate election that is coming. Of course the position could be considerably worse. The Liberal-National Party representation in a double dissolution, according to the Morgan poll, would have fallen from 37 down to 28, based on that poll. The Senate is being asked to consider legislation which is not urgent and which the government says it will not proclaim, if the bill is passed, until after the next election—which would see no possibility of this legislation being passed. The government is doing it with a number of senators who would not be returned at the next election were those poll outcomes to be reflected. That is a matter which will concern the Australian people, given that, on this issue, we do not have the detail as to exactly what the government is proposing to do with the proceeds of the sale.

speech.para: We have heard in the past that this measure is to pay off government debt. There have been all sorts of claims made about the position that this government faced when it came into office. Let us contrast that position with the position that the Labor government faced when it came into office in 1983. There have been all sorts of claims about so-called budget black holes. In 1983 the Hawke government was elected. In the budget preceding the election, the then Treasurer had indicated that a proposed deficit for the 1983 budget—this is the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who was then Treasurer—would be in the vicinity of $6 billion. During the campaign, it became known that it was going to blow out to at least $8 billion. What did we find out after the election? We now know that there was not a truthful position presented to the Australian people by the then Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and his Treasurer, Mr Howard.

After Saturday, 5 March, the new Labor government found out that the projected budget deficit for the next year would be in the vicinity of $9.6 billion. This is 1983 dollars. What does that translate to? In today's dollar terms, something in excess of a budget black hole—Mr Howard's budget black hole—of $22 billion. The position that John Howard and Malcolm Fraser, former Prime Minister, left the country in in 1983 was far worse than the position that allegedly applied to the Liberal government when it came to office in 1996.

We are considering this bill in the context that we really do not know the detail of the government's proposal as to what they will do with proceeds of sale if this bill is passed into law, given assent and acted upon. We really do not know. All that we can do is say, `How can we judge the statements of this government and its actions?' How can we transform the promises that this government makes into actions it might take, if it is in the extremely fortunate position of securing government after the next election. The polls at the moment are saying that that is an extremely unlikely eventuality.

We are going to have to rely upon the statements of the Prime Minister. This is the Prime Minister, let me remind you, who, as Treasurer, was responsible for one of the greatest turnarounds in public policy that ever occurred. This is the Prime Minister who, according to newspapers of the day, in 1977, after the budget, described the position of the government as `lies, lies, lies'. What had occurred is this. Tax cuts were promised. People were actually told that they could ring up a certain number and be told what they would get out of those tax cuts. What happened after the election? The next budget took those tax cuts away. So not only do you have to look at the detail of the package, not only do you have to have the opportunity to examine the package in detail and understand exactly what it means, but also you have to be able to accept that this government will act on those promises and not act in the way that it has.

One has only to look at the situation that we now face—the proposal that this government will pursue the introduction of a goods and services tax. That is a tax which the current Prime Minister said would never, ever be introduced. This Prime Minister has said that it was a dead issue and would never, ever be revisited. It is now obviously going to be a key plank in this government's re-election strategy. That is the form of this government in terms of its credibility on promises that it makes. This is a situation which we will carry into the next election. This is the contrast that we will present to the Australian people in relation to this government's promises and its actions. And there are many, many, other issues.

We are starting to see bits and pieces of the detail of the proposed package trickle out. We heard an announcement this morning about untimed local calls. Frankly, I will wait to see the detail on that. There was an announcement the day before about mobile telephone services.

talk.start.para: —The analog that your government shut down.
—Le me tell Senator Macdonald what the Australian Financial Review says about that today. It is on the back page, so you might like to look at it. It says:

speech.para: Take the announcement by the Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer and Communications Minister Richard Alston, which was made with great fanfare in Canberra yesterday about an hour after Blount made his speech.

Admittedly Blount may not have wanted to steal the ministers' thunder, but there was some speculation yesterday that the boys in Canberra had jumped the gun on a Telstra board which is yet to sign off on the technology, even though Government minders rejected this talk.
There is no doubt, however, that the minister got a little over- enthusiastic on the total spend involved.

Alston told reporters that Telstra would spend $426 million upgrading its mobile phone network for the bush. He said $176 million was being spent on the 800 megahertz spectrum and $250 million on the network upgrade.
But what goes next?

talk.start.para: —I don't know; you tell us.
—Senator Macdonald can look it up, too. It continues:

speech.para: What was not said was that Telstra had already spent the $176 million and that was for both the 800 megahertz and the 1800 megahertz spectrum.
What also was not made clear was that the spectrum for remote areas, those which the Government was targeting with its announcement, was only a small portion of the total spend.
Analysts estimate it to be $5 million to $6 million of the total $176 million spent.
That was because Telstra, with its community service obligations, was obliged to bid for the spectrum while its competitors did not.

In other words, this spending in the bush was probably more of an accident to do with the commitments of successive governments to preserving community service obligations—obligations which will be in jeopardy if this legislation passes. But the important point is this: when you cut the gloss away from the announcement made yesterday and when we are given enough detail to analyse it, the gloss falls away.

talk.start.para: —Do you oppose it?

—Of course I am not going to oppose it. It was already committed in substance. It had nothing to do with this package. It had nothing to do with this government's announcements. This article makes it clear that it was a decision of the board which is to do with the community service obligations of Telstra. They are obligations which are maintained without the passage of this bill. It has nothing to do with this bill, but it is being dressed up by this government as a justification for this package.

speech.para: We have very little detail of the announcement today, which is being trumpeted as some great leap forward. Let us wait and see what the detail is. Let us see exactly what comes out of it for rural and regional Australia. There is a lot of scepticism out there. This government will not get away with a glib announcement that some magnificent thing is going to change. People will want to see the detail. They are going to think very carefully about promises that this government makes. They will analyse those commitments in the light of broken commitments that this government has made—whether you go back to the 1977 actions of the current Prime Minister, which were described on the front page of the Illawarra Mercury as `lies, lies, lies' or whether you go to the budget black hole in 1983 where the Hawke Labor government was left with an over $22 billion black hole in today's dollar terms or whether you go to the Prime Minister's commitment that there would never, ever be a GST and that he would not be pursuing it. You can see the contrast on that. The Australian public will look very carefully at this announcement. Certainly the bush will. We have seen the passing of the National Party and Liberal Party vote in some areas to One Nation. That is a reflection of people's lack of confidence in the Liberal Party and the National Party—the coalition. It is about their desire to replace that group with another group of people.

Some of the Liberal Party vote has clearly come to Labor. We expect that there will be a very significant movement to Labor at the next election, particularly in my state of Tasmania. If you look at the most recent polling there, the Liberal Party polling is showing up at about 28 or 29 per cent. That may well be an overstatement of the vote, but I can assure you that in terms of the privatisation issue, the community has overwhelmingly rejected the proposal to privatise any part of the Hydro-Electric Corporation—the Hydro—in Tasmania, if you can believe the myriad opinion polls on the issue. Yet the Liberal government in Tasmania is continuing to pursue that option, irrespective of obvious opposition in the community. At the same time, there is obvious opposition to the privatising of Telstra. But what is this Liberal-National Party coalition doing? They are pursuing it with a bill which they are seeking to pass prior to gaining a mandate from the people on the issue. The reason that they are pursuing it is that they know after the next election they will not have a mandate for it; they will not have the numbers in this place.
Senator Lee suggested that the Labor Party would act on this bill if it were elected in the next election. Let me say very clearly—

talk.start.para: —This will be good.
—I will give you a commitment, Senator Macdonald. We will not act to privatise Telstra on the basis of this bill.
—You said that about the Commonwealth Bank.
—I certainly did not say anything of the sort. I will give you the commitment, and it will be honoured.
—Do you speak for Mr Beazley?

—I speak for Mr Beazley and Labor Party policy. I am repeating exactly what Senator Faulkner said earlier today in this place. The Labor Party will not act upon it. I know that there is a desperation about this and that the government is seeking to say, `You will get this any way so that you may as well vote for us.' People are not going to believe that. We are committed to having Telstra retained in public hands. The infrastructure that Telstra provides to the Australian community is critical. The infrastructure should not be handed to private concerns. It is a key part of Australia's information technology infrastructure. To put it all in private hands would be a travesty. This bill ought to be rejected. (Time expired)

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 12.31 p.m. to 1.15 p.m.

talk.start.para: —I think that, as we enter another debate about selling Telstra, we should reflect on the very recent history of the sell off of one-third of Telstra. I think that the carrots and promises of the government should be examined before we again jump in to sell our most important business. My colleague Senator Lees dealt this morning with the flawed economic arguments for selling such a profitable public asset as Telstra and the hash the government made of the float; the value of the Telstra shares is, I understand, around $10 billion higher than when they were sold.

speech.para: What I want to address today is the extraordinary sweetener that was used by the government to sell one-third of Telstra. Of course, I am referring to the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. This was the sell: the environment would be the winner and unprecedented amounts would be spent on repair, restoration and protection. My colleague Senator Lees rightly called the offer blackmail. She quoted a senior government adviser, who said in Scitech magazine:

We are appalled at the lies and the deception involved in this issue. It is an exercise based on just one thing—finding a way to sell off Telstra. The linkage to the environment is just a sop, designed to cloud the Telstra sale issue and to try to blackmail other parties and the general community into accepting it.

Anyone who looks at the figures can quickly see that the Natural Heritage Trust is a blatant and cynical political fraud. There is simply no way the interest from the $1 billion supposedly to be diverted from the Telstra sale could possibly pay to rectify the enormous environment problems confronting Australia.

And those who closely follow political debate in Australia will soon see the chasm between the proposed Telstra funding and the government's own admissions about the extent of these problems. Several senior ministers including Senator Hill have publicly declared that these problems are already costing us a minimum of $1.5 billion a year and are rapidly getting worse.

Leaving aside, just for a moment, all the short termism associated with the use of the revenue for a five-year program—after which, who knows what will happen to the environment?—we discovered that large amounts of this $1.25 billion have already replaced core environment funding. The minister said over and over again, `This is additional funding.' In the very first sentence of the glossy package which invites community groups to make application for funds, it says:
The Commonwealth will invest an additional $1.25 billion from the Natural Heritage Trust over five years.

It could not be plainer. Again, my colleague Senator Lees warned that the Natural Heritage Trust Fund would be a perfect vehicle for cost shifting. She pointed out the problems with unclear definitions and objectives. She moved amendments designed to eliminate cost shifting by the states, but of course these were not taken up.

The Labor Party tried to make a big deal out of the discovery that 80 per cent of NHT money had gone to coalition electorates—and, indeed, it has. We would have liked to have seen much more interest in repairing and protecting natural environments in urban areas, but by and large community groups in the city have not been so financially affected by the degradation of the environment as have farmers and they have not come forward in such large numbers as landcare groups and the like. So, whilst that is an issue, I do not think it is anything compared with the shonky deal that the government has done in siphoning off funds to projects outside the environment; projects which should be funded by other means and by other governments.

It is very difficult to get figures from the states and local government to determine the level of cost shifting, but there were some spectacular examples in the last round of grants which showed that Natural Heritage Trust funding is now paying for the most basic state and local government works. I will go through some examples: an irrigation drainage system for northern Victoria costing more than $1 million, with no matching dollars from the state government; management strategies for flood prone urban areas; levee banks for Cobram; the Myrtleford breakaway program to stop the Ovens River breaking into Happy Valley Creek; the Leadbeater possum recovery plan, $86,000 to save possums when the state government's approval of logging programs presents the greatest threat to those possums; a flood plain strategy for Myrtleford; and the Nyah Nyah West sewerage system. Also, just the other day Senator Parer admitted that $12 million of Natural Heritage Trust Fund money would be used to repair the Hume Dam.

I am not saying that these are not worthwhile projects—I am prepared to accept that many of them are—but I think we need to ask whether the money should come from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. We have to remember that that was promised for the environment. We need to ask whether these projects should have been funded out of public infrastructure moneys. The point I want to make is that millions of dollars have gone from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, often without any matching dollars from the states, on work which should have been funded in any case.

Most of the projects that I mentioned earlier are in Victoria, and Senators will be aware that the Victorian state government is running a huge surplus. Why should the Commonwealth help Mr Kennett make a hero of himself amongst the business world with his obscene surplus? In case Senator Hill had not noticed, the Victorian government continues to slice away at environment spending in Victoria to the point where there is almost no-one left in the Department of Natural Resources and Energy. I must say that it is just as well that we have a reasonably good landcare network in that state, because they are essentially the only ones left to do anything about fixing up the thousands of hectares in Victoria which have been destroyed by inappropriate farming practices.

Millions of dollars have gone into work on private land. Again, I would not argue that none of this will have good environmental outcomes—I am sure it will—but you do have to wonder about a waste water reuse system for the Bright golf course. You have to ask yourself about the program for perennial pastures, the reclamation of eroding sand dunes for the purposes of cropping in the Mallee, the purchase of pneumatic pruning gear for the Dundas Tablelands and farm drainage at the Wandella catchment. I know that farmers are having a very hard time, but Natural Heritage Trust money was promised for the environment. I repeat the minister's words: `Australia's largest ever environmental rescue effort'. That was his claim.

Leaving aside the questions of cost shifting or whether the money is actually being spent on projects which will have worthwhile, long-term benefits to the environment, I think we need to examine whether the money is additional because that was the key for the government's selling to Senator Harradine, Senator Colston, a lot of people in the conser vation movement and a lot of people out there in the bush the sale of one-third of our most important public asset.

My office asked the Parliamentary Library to take a look at Commonwealth spending on the environment. I will start with 1995-96, Labor's last year of office. The Commonwealth budget for the environment—and this is the budget spending on environment strategies, the EPA, the Australian Heritage Commission, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—was $212 million. In 1996-97, the coalition's first year of government, the core spending dropped to $174 million and then that was topped up with $20 million from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, making a total of $194 million. So that was a drop in overall funding of $18 million and a drop in core funding of $38 million.

In the next year, Natural Heritage Trust funding stepped up to $96 million and core funding dropped back to $160 million. That was a $14 million slice off the previous year. This financial year, 1998-99, the core funding has dropped a further $18 million. So back in 1995-96, the spending was $212 million and this year it is just $143 million. Core spending, in other words, has come down nearly $70 million since the coalition came to government, and that is a drop of about one-third.

The spending on the environment is not additional; it has been used to plug the hole created by cuts to existing spending. The question has to be asked: what happens at the end of 2001 when the money runs out? I simply do not know and I do not get any answers from the government to that question either. There is not much left of the family silver to sell and I do not see this government being prepared to raise taxes for what will be an ongoing and an increasingly serious need to address environment problems and to protect what we have left in this country.

The figures that I quoted are preliminary because, as I said, it is quite a difficult job to find out where the money went and where it came from. These figures were prepared by the Parliamentary Library and I seek leave to table that advice.

talk.start.para: —We will not oppose the tabling of those figures, but I do note that the person who prepared the figures admits that they are simplistic.

—I raise all of this because I want to point out to honourable senators that this government cannot be trusted to deliver on its promises. Whatever it says about spending on telephone services to the bush should be treated with the utmost caution. In fact, I suggest that it should not be believed.

speech.para: It is very interesting to hear the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) saying that part of the money from the sale of the rest of Telstra would be used to provide Australians with a package of socially desirable gifts which we will all feel good about. But the question I ask is: how do we know that this is not just another tall tale and that the package will simply fill a hole left by underspending in schools, hospitals, employment programs and the like? Whatever this package is, I think we can be sure it will be dressed up in all the tinsel in the world and sound like a great deal. Or will it? I think Australians are smart enough to know a core promise when they see one. If the Prime Minister is saying his bundle of goodies is a core promise to do some good out there—additional spending on who knows what at this stage—then I think they will be smart enough to see through the baubles.

I was interested to hear the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, last night talk about giving all Australians local telephone calls at the rates that we are accustomed to in the city. `Everyone will have local call rates,' he said. I would expect this to be small comfort to many people in isolated areas. The number of people who do not have local call rates is quite small and that is because their nearest neighbours are some distance away. These people will still need to call outside their immediate area and to regional centres and to cities much more than those people who live in large built-up areas.

Nevertheless, giving these people local call rates is something the Democrats have been advocating for years. In fact, we have argued that there is absolutely no reason anymore why people in rural and isolated areas should have to pay long distance charges at all. It is completely unfair. We get cheap calls in the city, but they are subsidised by the bush. Here is yet another great by-product of competition. The cost goes down where the market is strongest. Advances in technology are reducing the cost of telecommunications to the city, particularly to businesses, but again people in the country will miss out.

It costs Telstra no more to place a call from Mildura to Melbourne than from North Melbourne to South Melbourne. Distance is no longer a factor in cost. Gone are the days when we had telephone exchanges, which were mostly staffed by women who pushed plugs into holes. Technology has made distance completely irrelevant to the equation. The Democrats have been pointing this out for a long time—ever since I have been in the Senate, at least.

So this offer is no big deal. People in the bush should not be swept away by the prospect of having dual analog and digital services either. We know that the coalition was complicit in getting rid of analog by the year 2000. Senator Macdonald earlier this morning shouted across the chamber, `Labor did that,' as if he had nothing to do it with. I want to point out today that the government has had lots of opportunities to reverse that decision. We have put up amendments time and time again, but the government prefers to sit back and blame Labor for this mistake and votes each of them down.

Mr Fischer could use the revenue from the sale of Telstra to compensate Optus for reversing this decision of Labor which it supported to the hilt at the time, but we know that the Howard government will not do that. Whatever the bait is that comes with the sale of the rest of Telstra, I think we should be wary—Senator Harradine should be very wary. The government has not demonstrated that anyone in Australia will be better off. It is bad policy and Australians should not be hoodwinked by the promise of baubles and beads. Remember the Natural Heritage Trust. Remember the core promises. Remember that this government does not care to be a provider of public services.

talk.start.para: —I rise, as a Labor senator, to oppose the legislation that the Senate is considering, known as the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill, and effectively the sell off by the Australian government of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra. I note today that there are considerably more people in the gallery than would normally be the case. I think that is, in part, because the House of Representatives is not sitting. I draw the attention of those people to the fact that the sell off of Telstra is a very important debate. I also draw the attention of those listening to this broadcast to the fact that it is an example of the contempt that members of the so-called coalition—the National Party and the Liberal Party—have to the sell off of Telstra, despite the vigorous grandstanding we have seen from a number of them over the last week in particular. They have suddenly discovered that it is an issue. They are making a very small contribution to this debate. In fact, there are only two government members in the chamber today. I remind people in the gallery and those who are listening to this broadcast that—

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. First of all, Senator Sherry cannot count and, secondly, he knows—as does everybody—that it is quite improper to make reflections upon the chamber. Senator Sherry should be reminded of that obligation under the standing orders and customs of this place.

—I rise on the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. That was a particularly pompous contribution from Senator O'Chee. With a box full of plums in his mouth he made a completely disorderly point of order. There is no point of order. It was just an attempt to interrupt what, I must say, I thought was an outstanding commencement to a very fine speech. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you not only to rule the point of order out of order but also to ensure that Senator O'Chee behaves in a more orderly way himself and does not take spurious points of order to try to interrupt the flow of debate.
—There is no point of order. The senator is entitled not to reflect on a decision but to criticise a decision of this chamber, as I understand it.

—What we have just seen from Senator O'Chee—he is one of those National Party senators who have been engaging in some vigorous grandstanding and doorstops over the last week, threatening to oppose the sale of Telstra and trying to placate their rural support in the bush, which is rapidly dwindling—was a pathetic attempt by the National Party senator from Queensland to justify their sell-out of regional Australia, which is one of the implications of this piece of legislation.
