speech.para: I wish to deal with two aspects of the legislation: firstly, the financial implications—matters relating to public debt and the budget—and, secondly, the regional impact of the sale with particular reference to my home state of Tasmania. If the bill is passed by the parliament and the Senate and proclaimed after the election, if the Liberal and National parties win that election, the government will lose the capacity to give direction to Telstra. There will be a significant restriction on our capacity as an Australian nation to exercise any significant degree of influence in the vital strategic direction of a national economy—namely, the telecommunications sector—and our ability to ensure that that strategic sector includes all of Australia, not just the major urban centres.

Other speakers in this debate have outlined the importance of Telstra to the nation's economy. A great deal has been made about the effect of the sale of Telstra on the budget bottom line. In my view, it has not been a very accurate assessment of the issues and its implications. The basic argument runs something like this: there will be a benefit to the budget position of the Commonwealth government regarding debt and the bottom line of the budget. Financial commentators are saying that the Commonwealth government might make a further $40 billion on the sale. That in turn will enable it to make a public debt saving, reducing government debt, at a current cost of that debt to the Common wealth of about six per cent. That is a figure of about $2.4 billion per annum.

This should also be judged against a background of Commonwealth government debt being at a reasonable level. One of the furphies in this debate is that Australian government debt levels are nowhere near unsustainable levels, unlike some other states in Australia—South Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. The simplest and totally incorrect assessment is that there is a $2.4 billion saving to the budget. That is obviously wrong because, whilst we will have a saving to the budget, at the same time we lose the dividend, or income stream, from the profits of our current two-thirds ownership of Telstra. In 1997-98, that was $1.2 billion.

So we are not dealing with a static gain of $1.2 billion to the budget. We have to factor in the increasing dividend stream of Telstra over the next few years. If we look at the past increase in dividends from Telstra, we find there has been a steady increase in the dividend—that is, the money paid to the budget from Telstra profits—at the rate of 15 per cent per year. At some point in the future, there will be what is called a crossover, a point when the budget bottom line gets worse because of the loss of an increasing dividend. That will be greater than the gain from the public debt that is reduced as a result of a two-thirds sale of Telstra.

This issue, unfortunately, has not been publicly reported widely or even debated in any significant way. I argue that it is reasonable to expect that Telstra's dividends will continue to increase at the rate that has occurred since corporatisation. In fact, independent analysts are predicting a more rapid increase in profit for Telstra, but let's be conservative and use that figure of 15 per cent that I referred to earlier. The crossover point when the government, that is, the people of Australia, begin to lose money from the revenue to budget—and it is not some far distant point—will occur in the year 2002 or 2003.

We are looking at a point in time four or five years into the future from now when, as a result of the remaining two-thirds sale of Telstra, the Commonwealth government becomes a net loser. Sure, the people who have the money to buy shares in Telstra may make a net gain, depending on the purchase price and the sale price, but the Commonwealth government becomes a net loser in four or five years' time.

When one-third of Telstra was sold enthusiastic privatisers argued—and they continue to argue this on the basis of selling the remaining two-thirds—that it would inject a new private sector approach into Telstra and make it more profitable. It will inject a new element of rigour. Shareholders demand a better return, so it should improve profits and return on investment.

I have never believed that to be true, but if it is, the crossover point—in other words, the increased profitability that should be flowing back to the public purse because of the increase in profit that should come back to the Commonwealth government—is reached at an even earlier period, that is, in three or four years' time. Even if we assume a more modest 10 per cent improvement in profit, that makes a difference to the crossover point. It moves it out to the year 2004 or 2005, that is, six or seven years from now when the Commonwealth would start making a loss.

I would also point out—and I have not gone into this in any detail—that I have not included the loss to government revenue of franking credits on private share ownership. Because, as the shares are sold to the private sector, there is a further loss to government revenue as a consequence of the issues relating to franking credits. It is estimated that will be a further loss to government revenue of $400 million to $500 million a year.
Senator Cooney interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Four to five hundred million dollars a year, Senator Cooney. You can paint a range of different scenarios and different assumptions all based on independent market analysis of the likely profits, and you still get a loss to the bottom line of the budget inside 10 years. In other words, on conservative projections, the Commonwealth will have lost money in 10 years.

speech.para: If this government's intention is to build into long-term expenditure greater expenditure based on the sale of Telstra and/or tax cuts on the basis of an assumption that there is an improved bottom line to the budget, it will not be there in four, five, six or 10 years' time. What do you do after that period of time if you have no other assets to sell? You either have to cut your expenditure or increase your tax or sell some other form of asset. I suspect that the only one remaining will be Australia Post.

I referred earlier to the ending of the government's ability to direct Telstra and that is obviously inevitable once it passes into private hands. This ability to direct Telstra has been vitally important towards ensuring a relatively equitable distribution of technology throughout all of Australia. This is a very important issue for rural and regional Australia.

There are rapid developments in technology. If you are a private shareholder, you will rightly demand the highest return on your investment and you will demand that the investment is made where you will get that highest return from. That will be from the major urban centres. It is probably going to be great for everyone who lives in Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane or Adelaide. But, if you do not live in those major urban centres, the demands of the private shareholders will be, `Don't invest in those areas outside the core, the major urban areas. Don't invest, because it is too costly. We don't get a decent return.'

Inevitably, the core—the major urban centres—will do much better than the non-core or rural and regional areas of Australia in the next five, 10 or 15 years as Telstra invests in new technology. Those same private shareholders will rightly demand the highest possible return. That is not going to come from rural and regional Australia where the cost structures relating to the installation of new technology are much higher.

People in rural and regional Australia, including my home state of Tasmania, understand the implications of this sale of the remaining two-thirds Telstra. There is certainly a growing centralisation of service and movement of jobs to the core, or major urban centres, and a retreat from the non-core centres.

I do not like the terms `core' and `non-core'. That was the glib phrase used by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, when he said he was going to implement certain promises and break others, that is, core promises and non-core promises. Of course, we all remember his commitment that he would not be privatising the rest of Telstra before the next election. Yet here we are today considering legislation to sell off two-thirds of Telstra. Another broken promise from Mr Howard.

We should remind the Senate of the never, ever promise—never, ever a GST and, of course, a further assurance that it will never, ever go up. That is the record of this Prime Minister on Telstra and other related important issues.

We have seen attempts made over the last week by National Party senators. There have been public demands all of a sudden from Senator O'Chee, who is in the chamber, Senator McGauran, Senator Sandy Macdonald, Senator Boswell, who is the leader of the National Party without portfolio in the Senate, and Senator Brownhill—although I do not think I have seen too much from him. We have had doorstops over the last week from senators sounding stern warnings to the Liberal Party that they are not going to cop the sale of Telstra unless rural and regional Australia is looked after.

Of course, they are attempting to justify their position. The National Party has rolled over on this yet again. The doormat of the coalition has been trodden on yet again. The National Party has precious little influence in this government. They have been engaged in a form of grandstanding to justify at least partially their position to their rural and regional constituents.

I think it was rather aptly described as `noise and static' from the National Party. They are not my words; that is the description by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, of the National Party senators—`noise and static at doorstops as they walked in and out of the Senate'. Unfortunately, in this debate `noise and static' is a fairly apt description. That is about the level of technology we are going to have in rural and regional Australia—noise and static over the next 10 to 20 years.

In conclusion, I do want to make some comments about my colleague Senator Harradine from Tasmania. I will pay him at least a partial compliment. I do know him as a fairly competent negotiator in the trade union context. He was always able to drive what I considered to be a fairly hard bargain. But I, as a Tasmanian colleague of Senator Harradine, have to say to him—I do not know whether he is listening to this debate in his room—that we do not know yet the details of the deal that we can only assume he has done with the government to sell the remaining two-thirds of Telstra. On the last occasion, when one-third of Telstra was privatised, it did not stop job losses in Tasmania, it did not guarantee the fundamental upgrading of technology in our telecommunications system that is needed—and not just needed in the next year or two.

You can buy a little bit of time. This government has done the same thing to the National Party. You can buy a little bit of time with $100 million. It sounds like a lot of money, but, when you think about the tens of billions of dollars that are necessary for telecommunications investment, it is not a lot of money in that context. You can buy a little bit of time—a year here, a year there—and that is really all Senator Harradine is doing: buying a little bit of time for Tasmania. I certainly know that, from a regional perspective, from a Tasmanian perspective, in 10 or 20 years—and unfortunately not many politicians do look that far ahead—we will look at Tasmania and other rural and regional areas in this country, we will look back on this point in time on this sale of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra, and I am sure that the relative economic and financial position relating to the telecommunications industry will have gone backwards. Tasmania will have gone backwards.

It is no good just looking at the next six months, the next year or the next two years. We have to look at and make a judgment about where rural and regional Australia will be over the next decade or two. The reality will be that the core areas, the major urban centres, may do well out of the privatisation of Telstra, but the non-core areas—like Tasmania, which Senator Harradine says he represents—will have gone backwards.

Senator Harradine should remember this: it really is down to his vote. That is the reality. If he is going to vote for this government package in the next day or two he should know full well that, as a direct result, he is going to deliver to Tasmania—and to other areas of rural and regional Australia—a relative movement backwards in our financial, economic and employment circumstances for the next 10 to 20 years. I certainly hope that he thinks long and hard about that if he has, in fact, done a deal—as we believe he has—with this government in order to privatise the remaining two-thirds of Telstra.

talk.start.para: —I refer to the second reading speech on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 . As you know, Mr Acting Deputy President Hogg, the second reading speech is the speech made by the minister when the legislation is brought into the chamber. It is a speech that puts the case for the government and explains what the government is on about. It is an interesting second reading speech by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman). In the last paragraph of the first page, it says:

speech.para: We delivered on that promise—
that is, the promise to float a third of Telstra—

resulting in an outstandingly successful public share offer that has been universally applauded in the community, and which was overwhelmingly supported by the ordinary investors—the mums and dads of Australia.

It then goes on to say that about 500,000 people invested in it. It is hardly fair to say that, because a large number of people bought shares, this was universally applauded by the community and the mums and dads of Australia who gathered parts of the shareholdings of this company. I want to concentrate on the next paragraph of the second reading speech, which begins on page 2, which says:

We are again delivering on our promises. We promised that there would be no further sell-down of the Commonwealth interest without the Govern ment first getting a mandate from the people at a Federal Election.
It goes on:

Here is the proof of our words. We have faith in the good judgement of the Australian people. We are spelling out the legislative basis on which a further sale will take place so they can make fully-informed choices at the polls. This Bill clearly provides that, when enacted, the act can only be proclaimed to come into effect on a date after the next Federal Election.

There are two uses of the words `a'—a very short word, but in this context a very significant word. `A' is the shortest word in the English language. The government is saying that they will not sell the rest of Telstra until after a federal election, not necessarily the next federal election.

Following on from that is this: if this bill is passed and becomes an act, before coming into operation it must be proclaimed at some time in the future. It can be proclaimed next year, the year after, five years from now or 10 years from now. What that means is this: suppose the people of Australia say, `Well, look we don't want the sale of Telstra; we're going to vote a Labor government in'—and a very wise choice that would be, I think you would have to agree, Mr Acting Deputy President—`and we will give that Labor government a majority in the House of Representatives,' which means it then becomes the government, `but, in keeping with what has now become the usual situation in the Senate, we will not give it the majority in the Senate.' That means that, although a Labor government has been voted in, it cannot undo this legislation. That legislation remains there to be proclaimed when the next conservative government comes in, which might be 10 years from now.

Mr Acting Deputy President, what is fair about that? This bill has been put forward on the basis that people will have a chance at the next election to say whether or not they want it. But the reality is that it will remain there unproclaimed until the next conservative government comes to office. If at the next election people want to reject this bill but at the same time also want to put a different arrangement of party strengths in the Senate from the arrangement in force in the House of Representatives, they can do nothing about it. Wouldn't it be better and fairer for people to be able to vote on this at the next election and then see what happens in the next parliament, rather than committing to a future parliament the difficulty of having to undo the legislation if it wants to carry out a mandate the people may have given it not to go on with this legislation?

Mr Acting Deputy President, why has the government brought this bill forward now? Why doesn't it promise in the second reading speech that, if defeated in the House of Representatives at the next election, it will agree to undo this legislation? Why doesn't the government do that, instead of saying in the second reading speech:
We promised that there would be no further sell-down of the Commonwealth interest without the Government first getting a mandate from the people at a Federal Election.
I repeat: a federal election—not at the next federal election, but at `a federal election'. So I think there is much to be worried about in the attitude taken by the government in this matter.

I want to comment a little on this: it has been said that the Labor government sold the Commonwealth Bank and the airline—and that is true. It has been said also, `Well, that's the same as this government selling Telstra.' But there is a big difference between selling an airline and a bank and selling Telstra. That point is brought out well in section 69 of the constitution, which states:

On a date or dates to be proclaimed by the Governor-General after the establishment of the Commonwealth the following departments of the public service in each State shall become transferred to the Commonwealth:-
Posts, telegraphs, and telephones:
Naval and military defence:
Lighthouses, lightships, beacons, and buoys:
Quarantine.
Our constitution specifies those four categories of matters as having been assigned to the Commonwealth. Looking at them, they are all matters essential to the good running of the community.

Going from the bottom up, we have quarantine. Of course quarantine is something that should not be privatised. Quarantine guards what comes into the country, making sure that our health and safety are preserved and making sure that our country's stock and plants are not adversely affected. That sort of public service needs to be carried out by the Commonwealth. Lighthouses, lightships, beacons and buoys: again, a concept of a public nature. Naval and military defences: would we privatise naval or military defences? Of course we would not.

Then the first on this list—going upwards of course, but saying them last: posts, telegraphs and telephones. The founding fathers chose to put posts, telegraphs and telephones—that is, the subject matter being dealt with by the Telstra act—together with naval and military defence; lighthouse, lightships, beacons and buoys; and quarantine. Along with customs and excise, which are dealt with in a different part of the constitution, those were very early matters that were taken up by the founding fathers.
When the Australia bill, the forerunner to the constitution, was discussed in Sydney on 6 April 1891, which was a very long time ago, clause 10, right at the start, read as follows:

The control of the following departments of the public service shall be at once assigned to and assumed and taken over by the executive government of the commonwealth, and the commonwealth shall assume the obligations of all or any state or states with respect to such matters, that is to say—
Customs and excise,
Posts and telegraphs,
Military and naval defence,
Ocean beacons and buoys, and ocean lighthouses and lightships,
Quarantine.

The great figure at that meeting was Sir Samuel Griffith, a great Queenslander, as you would know—a person who took on board the fact that posts and telegraphs, the forerunner of the powers that Telstra carries, should be given over to the Commonwealth and looked after by them. Apparently, that great tradition from that great Queenslander is to be ignored, thrown aside, and Telstra is to be privatised.

talk.start.para: —Samuel Griffith preached nothing about privatisation and you know it!

—Senator Abetz says that Sir Samuel Griffith said nothing about privatisation. Of course he said nothing about privatisation—that is the whole point. Senator Abetz bears out exactly what I am saying. Of course Sir Samuel Griffith said nothing about privatisation. It did not occur to him to privatise posts and telegraphs. It occurred to him that that should be taken on by the Commonwealth, by this parliament, by this very executive. That is what he was saying. Senator Abetz is absolutely correct, it bears out the point that Sir Samuel Griffith said nothing about privatisation.

speech.para: The preamble to this bill is going to be a nightmare for a court which may have to look at it to interpret certain sections of the act. The preamble says, among other things:
The high-growth and fast-moving telecommunications sector requires competing carriers to have:
(a) full commercial flexibility, subject to necessary regulatory safeguards . . .

How is a judge going to interpret that? What does it mean for a body to have `full commercial flexibility' and at the same time be `subject to necessary regulatory safeguards'? And the regulatory safeguards are going to be enormous. Can I just demonstrate: the Telecommunications Act 1997 was made necessary by the one-third privatisation of Telstra. This one-third privatisation required a lot more legislation than before. The legislation that attended to Telstra before that was the Telecommunications Act 1991—a much smaller volume than the Telecommunications Act 1997. The privatisation of Telstra will require a lot more legislation to make it work than would be the situation were it to be kept in public hands. I do not mind that, given my background, but it is going to be a very fertile field for lawyers. People are going to have to interpret, as I say, what is meant by:
. . . full commercial flexibility, subject to necessary regulatory safeguards.
The next point in the preamble says:
(b) an ongoing ability to raise the capital needed to meet changing commercial and customer requirements . . .
What does that mean? The preamble continues:
without inhibitions imposed by government ownership.
The next statement is:
In today's highly competitive, global communications environment, it does not make commercial sense, nor is it good public policy, for telecommunications companies to be owned by government.

What is a court to make of that statement? It is simply not a statement of law but a statement of philosophy. Another thing about the second reading speech is that it reads like Norman Lindsay's The Magic Pudding : it promises all sorts of generous portions to all sorts of people.

talk.start.para: —Whose speech was that?

—This is the second reading speech, which I think Norman Lindsay's The Magic Pudding : it promises shareholders abundant riches and promises the users of the services to be provided by Telstra `the best services in the world'. It says government will be able to get out of this and leave it to market forces to make things go well, so market force philosophers are satisfied by that. But then it says it is going to have abundant regulation, so that satisfies the lawyers and those who say that business ought to be regulated.

speech.para: It is interesting that fines of up to $10 million can be imposed upon people who provide telecommunications services. But given the fact, as illustrated by the Patrick company, for example, that you can strip assets, what is to stop a service provider from arranging its affairs, and arranging the companies through which it is going to deliver its services, in such a way that it can fail to carry out the obligations provided by the act and not have the money to pay any fine that is imposed? The second reading speech said:
What we—
that is, the government—
are saying is that the business of government is not to be in business. The business of government is to set the framework within which business operates.
It continues:
Whatever the rhetoric at the time, the incorporation of what is now Telstra under Corporations Law was an explicit recognition that Telstra was and is first and foremost a business.

At that part of the second reading speech the government says, `This is just a business we are dealing with.' Then, when we go to a later part of the speech, we see that it is not simply a business; it is very much a strategic part of Australia's business future. It says:
Telstra has a vital continuing strategic role in the national economy.

On pages 4 and 5 of the speech it is just a business; on page 14 it becomes a body that has a vital continuing strategic role in the national economy, and one that must remain in Australian hands and be controlled by Australians. The government has to make up its mind: is it just a business, or is it the strategic body described later in the speech? The government just has not got this matter thought out, and it is a bad time to be passing legislation such as this.

talk.start.para: —I have to say that this debate on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 is as much about honesty and integrity as it is about the full sale of Telstra.
—Sit down.
—The senator opposite who interjects says, `Sit down.' The reason they want me to sit down is that they know their honesty and integrity on this issue is shot.

speech.para: In commencing, I want to read, particularly for the people in the gallery, who are very interested in the honesty and integrity the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has, a part of the speech he made on 26 March 1996 to the Business Council of Australia. He said:

I am determined that the commitments we made to the Australian people before 2 March are honoured. I do not think any of us can greet with any equanimity the steady decline in respect for our political and parliamentary institutions which has occurred over the past few years.
He went on:
One of the reasons why the respect for our institutions has declined is the way in which promises are too freely made and even more freely repudiated after governments are elected to power.
He went on further and said this:

And, even more important than other benchmarks against which you are entitled to judge us, in three years time you will be entitled to judge us accord ing to the benchmark of whether or not we have honoured commitments made to the people and to the Australian nation before 2 March.

What were those commitments? In respect of the further or full privatisation of Telstra, they were very clearly that it would not occur. You can find any number of references to support that. I suppose one of the very good ones is the following, especially as it is in response to a question from a backbencher. This is the Prime Minister, in response to Mr Andren, on 9 December 1996. The Prime Minister was asked:

Can the Prime Minister clarify the government's position in relation to any further sell-off of Telstra, especially in light of the fact that the people of Australia voted at the last election on the understanding that only part of Telstra would be sold if the coalition formed government?
The Prime Minister replied:

There has been no change to that policy. There will be no change to that policy. No attempt will be made by us in the currency of this parliament to sell anything more of Telstra. If there were in the future—and this is repeating exactly what I said in the past—to be any desire on our part to sell another tranche then we would seek a specific mandate from the Australian people. Nothing could be more transparent, nothing could be more consistent and nothing could be more honest.

I guess a lot of people in this place would have to be thinking to themselves, `Well, what did the Prime Minister really mean?' The Prime Minister was not the only one to make those sorts of commitments. The Leader of the Government in this place, Senator Hill, said on 9 December 1996:

The government has said it will not be attempting to privatise more than one-third of Telstra. That was the policy we took to the last election. It is clear and unambiguous. It remains the case and has just been repeated clearly and unambiguously by the Prime Minister. So, yes, Senator, I can tell you that is the case.
What was the case he was confirming? He was asked by Senator Faulkner:
Can you guarantee, here and now, that the coalition government will not attempt to privatise more than one-third of Telstra?
As I said, Senator Hill answered:
I can tell you that is the case.

If Senator Hill makes a contribution to this debate, which he probably won't, I hope he can actually clarify what he meant at that time. I go to the Minister for Finance and Administration, Mr Fahey, in response to a question from his own backbench, from a member of this coalition government. He was asked a question in relation to any further sale of Telstra, and he said this:
. . . but I can assure all members of the House that the government will consult the Australian people before it considers any further selldown of Telstra.
Those are pretty clear, pretty unambiguous and honest commitments at the time. What has changed? The good old minister for communications and the arts—

talk.start.para: —The doormat.
—Yes, some call him doormat.
—Order! I ask you to withdraw that.
—I withdraw. He actually read out Liberal Party or coalition government policy. He said:

speech.para: To give Australians a direct stake in one of Australia's major companies, the coalition will offer by way of a share float, if necessary in two tranches depending on market conditions, one third of the Commonwealth's equity in Telstra. There will be no sale beyond the one third . . . without an explicit mandate.
That is fairly clear and forthright stuff. He went on further to say:
. . . our position is crystal clear. I am telling you the truth now—
The truth!
I was telling the truth then. Our policy is that we will sell one-third and no more, unless the matter is put before the public at election.
What has happened to the truth? What has happened to honesty? What has happened to integrity?

That is something I know is very near and dear to the heart of one senator who is not in the chamber at the moment: Senator Harradine. I know he has been praised as a man of honesty and integrity and I guess, on the face of it, I would have to accept that. But I want to go to some words that he said on the full sale of Telstra. I hope, Senator Harradine, you listen to these words because the question will come to you, and you will have to address yourself to the Australian public on a commitment that you made. Senator Harradine, on 9 December 1996, said in relation to the first one-third sale:

The simple position is that the government in fact did take the issue to the electorate. The electorate made its decision to support the government. I do not know how many would have voted on the basis of a sale of a third of Telstra for the redemption of debt and for the establishment of a natural heritage trust. But, nevertheless, there was a mandate. My view about mandates of popularly elected governments is that the Senate should not simply be obstructionist about them.
He said further:

. . . but the Senate should apply certain principles which if those principles and values conflict with the government's legislation in the discharge of its mandate then those principles should prevail. On this particular matter I would have voted very strenuously against the total sale of Telstra.
I note that in another debate, with regard to the Wik legislation, Senator Harradine had a lot to say about double dissolutions. Back in December 1996 he said:
One had to make a judgment as to what the government would have done had we blocked the third sale of Telstra. My judgment was that the government would have used it as a double dissolution trigger.
Very interesting.

And if that occurred, if they pulled that trigger, then in the current climate you would have a total sale of Telstra. The only other way that the government can get through a total sale of Telstra during this Senate is to gain the numbers in the Senate.
I ask Senator Harradine: has he given the government the numbers? If he has not, why are we debating this piece of legislation? He went on to say:
As I read the numbers they are not there for the total sale of Telstra. I would certainly vote against a total sale of Telstra.

This was in December 1996, and I hope Senator Harradine remembers the statement that he made to the public of Australia at that time. With regard to this proposal for the total sale of Telstra, another interesting aspect of this goes to the question of foreign ownership. Senator Alston said in May 1996:
The usual furphy about foreign ownership has been put to rest. There will be an absolute limit of less than 12 per cent of the company in foreign hands . . .
I don't know. I think about 19 per cent of the one-third is in foreign hands already, so goodness knows what would happen if we got a full sale.

talk.start.para: —There would be a lot more if Parer had not got so many.
—That is true, Senator Ray. If Senator Parer's family had not bought up so many shares, it would probably be about 20 per cent.

speech.para: I want to go to the process that was involved with the one-third sale of Telstra. Senator Harradine supported the government for the sale, as did Senator Colston, on the basis that there would be significant benefits to my state of Tasmania. We were supposed to get some $58 million that would deliver a whole host of things.

talk.start.para: —And we have.

—I notice Senator Abetz, sitting over there interjecting, seems to think that this has been so marvellous. Let me say this to you, Senator Abetz: it has been a long way short of marvellous; in fact it has been a total flop. In fact it has probably been a disaster, and Senator Harradine knows that, because I know Senator Harradine has been harrying Senator Alston to try to get some things done. I want to have a look at what was promised and quote some words that Senator Alston said about Tasmania. He said:

speech.para: There is a world of difference between Tasmania and Victoria or New South Wales, where you are close to capital cities which have world-class telecommunications facilities, where there are enormous incentives by virtue of population size for the carriers to keep on providing world best services. Those states and their citizens are immeasurably better off than those in a place like Tasmania where you are lucky to even be able to make a phone call if you live in some parts of the west coast; even if you are in the capital city of that state you are very much a second-class telecommunications citizen.

That was December 1996. What has changed since then? Let me tell you: not much at all. For $58 million—it was actually supposed to give us something additional—we got zip. We got nothing more than what Telstra had planned all the time. I think that for once in his life Brian Harradine had the pea and thimble trick pulled completely over him.

Senator Sherry was saying that Brian Harradine has been a good negotiator in respect of the trade union movement. He probably has been; in fact, I would have to agree with that comment. Indeed, I would say that he has used that to some degree to benefit himself, because the only thing that was delivered out of the one-third privatisation sale for Telstra was a promotion for Brian Harradine. It has not been forthcoming in terms of benefits to the state.

If we look at what has happened with employment, we were supposed to get more employment in Tasmania. In terms of promised upgrades, some have been brought forward but no additional money has been spent. We have had a bit of a bring forward in the provision of some services, but what has happened with a whole host of other services? We do not even have a business sales office in Tasmania any more. If you are in small business in Tasmania and you want to talk to Telstra about services, you have to ring Melbourne. Likewise, the general commercial consumer sales centre that currently employs around 120 people in Hobart is going to be transferred to Melbourne. The network and design construction unit is going to be sold. It employs eight people who are supposed to be paid for out of the Harradine money. What is the term of their contract? Six months. So what is the long-term benefit for Tasmania in that? Of course we will lose the 50 jobs, in effect, when it is sold because a mainland contract firm will win that business and it will be serviced from the mainland.

The administrative work that was based in Tasmania for Telstra has gone. It has been transferred to Waverley, Melbourne. As I said, commercial sales have gone to Footscray. We got $58 million, but we paid for everything to be transferred to Melbourne.

talk.start.para: —You are wrong.

—That is what we have done with the money, Senator Abetz, and you ought to do something about it as part of the government. With the relocation of the service activation services, another 10 jobs are going from Tasmania to Ballarat. You cannot blame me for drawing the conclusion that the $58 million could not have been used for anything else other than transport costs for all of the services we did have in Tasmania across to Victoria. Senator Ray might not be unhappy about that, but I am. I do not know what Brian Harradine proposes to do with regard to the full sale deal that he might be—
—Senator, to you.
—Senator Murphy, you should refer correctly to Senator Harradine.

—On the question of the full sale, Senator Harradine said previously that he would have voted against it. Why are we debating the full sale? He must be seeking a deal. If he is seeking a deal, what is it? I hope it is better than the first one, if that is what he is going to do. But, if he really wants to act in the interests of Tasmania, he should vote against it.
—For all of us? That will be the day.
—You are right, Senator Ray, for all Australians he should vote against any further sale.
—But he won't. He has done a deal.

—If he has done a deal, then I hope that he has the honesty and integrity to come in here and tell us what it is so that we can make a judgment about that. Of course, the old Nationals think they have done a deal for the bush—
—They have done a deal, but they got well and truly short-changed.

—Yes, they have been short-changed all right. They think they have done a deal. I watched Senator Boswell yesterday. He had his head in his hands on the bench. He must have been watching the pea and thimble, with Richard `Tricky Dicky' Alston shifting the pea and thimble around and saying—
—Order! Please refer to the senator in the appropriate way.

—Senator Alston was shifting the pea and thimble around, and Senator Boswell, trying to watch it, had no hope. They did not even invite Tim Fischer along to the game; they knew he would have no hope. They gave him a mobile phone, which was a pretend one, at some announcement that he and the minister attended.
—Just a pretend one?

—That is right, a pretend phone. Much of this is covered in an article in the Financial Review today in Chanticleer. It talks about this deal that supposedly has been done and makes some very pertinent points about the announcement by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, and the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. The article says:

speech.para: There is no doubt, however, that the minister has got a little over-enthusiastic on the total spend involved.

Alston told reporters that Telstra would spend $426 million upgrading its mobile phone network for the bush. He said $176 million was being spent on the 800 megahertz spectrum and $250 million on the network upgrade. What was not said was that Telstra had already spent the $176 million and that was for both the 800 megahertz and the 1800 megahertz spectrum. What was also not made clear was that the spectrum for remote areas, those which the government was targeting with its announcement, was only a small portion of the total spend. Analysts estimate it to be $5 million to $6 million of the total $176 million.

I say to the Nationals up in the corner there: by gee, you didn't get too much out of that. The poor old bush did not get serviced too well—it did not even get 10 per cent. The article goes on further:

The $250 million spend on the bush analog network is also apparently a bit of a furphy. Telstra will spend around that amount on its total AMPS mobile network across Australia and, in fact, it will upgrade the metropolitan centres first so that the rural and remote customers can enjoy seamless transmission when they visit the cities after 2000 when the AMPS network is shut down.
Goodness, gracious me, that sounds like a real good deal for the bush.

talk.start.para: —It is your legislation that is causing the problem in the first place.

—No wonder they did not invite old Tim Fizzer in the other place to the pea and thimble game; they knew he could not play. Let us go back to this pretend phone that Mr Fischer was given. I will quote again from the article:

speech.para: Alston yesterday told reporters that over time, he expected the CDMA handsets to come down to $350.
It appears so. It continues:
If you believe Telstra, the CDMA handsets will be comparably priced to digital handsets, which are now getting down to an average of $99 before connection charges.

I think Mr Fischer got a $5 handset. You have to make a judgment about the deal he has done for the bush thus far. With this whole process, the weights of honesty and integrity are on Senator Harradine. He is the one that made the commitments back in 1996, and he has to stand up and be seen—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It should always be remembered that this Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 is a consequence of the breaking of a categoric promise by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). John Howard said that there would be no move to fully privatise Telstra in the first term of his government. In introducing this bill, he has broken his word, and he has dishonoured himself yet again. It is not possible to debate this legislation without considering the processes by which the government, and others conspiring with them, forced this upon the Senate—several of whom, I might add, could not have legally driven home last night.

speech.para: Last night, the government gagged all the procedural motions moved in association with this bill. It is true that the Labor Party often moved procedural motions when in government, but we always allowed them to be debated. In 13 years of government, Labor never moved the gag concurrently with the procedural motion. Contrast this with the current government—a government that does not even have the courage to allow its procedural motions to be debated. The opposition would have appreciated the opportunity to have made some comments on the appropriate way in which to manage the legislative agenda in the Senate. Our comments would not have reflected the hypocritical rantings that the current government made when it was in opposition. We would not have argued, as Senator Hill did on countless occasions, that corralling debate was always intrinsically wrong. We would have examined Senator Dr Herron's extensive comments from the opposition benches on the health effects of late sittings. He always prefaced those remarks by saying that he was speaking as a doctor, not as a politician. But last night, as on other occasions, he just sat mute—other than uttering last night the most disgraceful comment I have ever heard in this Senate and we will never forget that that comment was made across the chamber.

We also would have brought Senator Ian Campbell to account for his previous comments when in opposition about the effect of late night sittings on the staff of this building. But, of course, we were never given the opportunity. At least we got one first last night. We saw Senator Harradine voting for the gag. In fact, we got the trifecta. He voted for the gag three times. One senator, representing 30,000 voters, was effectively able to gag 28 senators representing four million voters so that we could have no say at all.

Finally, we had an `Independent' from Queensland voting to make us all sit long hours in the full knowledge that he was to return home this morning for what I am led to believe are legitimate reasons. If, of course, he was returning home to Brisbane for health reasons and is returning here later in the day, I would know he was serious about it because he would not have been travelling on parliamentary business and he would have paid the return business airfare himself.

In the 30 minutes allocated for debate on the suspension of standing orders, the Labor Party was given one five-minute slot to express its views courtesy of an agreement between management and presiding bias. The fate of this legislation in all probability will not be determined by Senator Harradine. Here I must disagree with my colleague from Tasmania. Just as the Wik legislation was not determined by Senator Harradine—

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I heard Senator Ray use the words `presiding bias'. That is a reflection on the President, who was in the chair at the time.

—On the point of order: Senator Ferguson might like to reflect on how the normal presiding officer, acting on the roster, was removed. The President was brought in. Only one person from our side, in spite of people jumping up, was chosen in that debate. There was constant conversation between the manager and the President right throughout that process.
—If you did you say that, Senator Ray, it is a reflection on the President. I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw. I was saying to my colleague that this vote does not depend on Senator Harradine. It will be determined by that act of gross political treachery which occurred in August 1996.

speech.para: Given that the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens oppose the privatisation of Telstra, the will of the electorate, as properly delivered in the Senate, would have been 38 votes against the government proposal. Therefore, if the government is victorious on this proposal, it will be through the delivery of a Labor vote from Queensland. Hence, venality will triumph over principle and self-interest will triumph over loyalty. A career marked by time serving, place seeking and insatiable greed will reach its culmination in the vote on this legislation this week.

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Ray, that is a reflection on another senator. I ask you to withdraw it.
—In what respect?
—It is a reflection on a sitting senator. I ask you to withdraw.
—What part of it was a reflection?
—The three comments you made. I think you should withdraw them.

—I rise on a point of order: I do not believe any of the descriptions that Senator Ray has used are unparliamentary, whether they relate to another member of the Senate or the other House or anyone else. They are quite clear.
—Not for you are they unparliamentary, but for the Senate they are.
—They are not unparliamentary for me or anyone else. That is the point I am making, Madam Acting Deputy President. They are not unparliamentary. They have never been ruled unparliamentary before.
—Do not debate this, Senator Faulkner.
—Before you make a courageous ruling to establish new ground in this regard, I ask you to check with the Clerk before you give some consideration to the ruling you made.
—Senator Ray, you were impugning a sitting senator. I ask you to withdraw.
—That was absolutely my intention, so I withdraw. But I stand by everything I say in that regard.
—An unconditional withdrawal would be preferable, but I accept that.

—I withdraw. I do feel sympathy for those coalition senators who are rostered on to ingratiate and cajole Senator Colston. It must be the lowest imaginable job there is in politics. But what I find passing strange is that Senator Colston's recent submission to the magistrates court asserted that he could not concentrate for more than 10 minutes at a time in instructing his defence counsel. Yet he seems to have no problem trading in Telstra shares following his previous enthusiastic support for the government's privatisation. For years, Senator Colston issued press releases and attended rallies defending the public ownership of Telstra. It took a mere $16,000 a year and a job conferring some degree of formal honour and prestige for the convictions of a lifetime to be abandoned.

speech.para: The government will exploit Senator Colston's defection while tacitly acknowledging his murky past by refusing, belatedly, to accept his vote because of the political embarrassment it would bring it. If this legislation passes, senators who listen carefully might hear a noise from Queensland. It will be Senator Colston's father turning in his grave knowing that his son has stabbed the Labor Party in the back, a Labor Party that his father loved. Like father, like son? Never! Having previously voted to privatise one-third of Telstra, one would have thought Senator Colston would leave well enough alone. But no. In spite of his claimed mental enfeeblement, we find that he has become, as I said earlier, an active share trader in Telstra shares.

We know that Malcolm Arthur Colston and Dawn Patricia Colston sold one parcel of Telstra shares on 23 December 1997. Another parcel, also held in their joint names, was sold by the Janfern nominee company on 19 December 1997. Yet another parcel, held by the Janfern superannuation fund account and registered in both their names, was sold on 23 December 1997. Yet another parcel, in the sole name of Dr Malcolm Arthur Colston, was also sold on 23 December 1997. At present, Mrs Dawn Colston holds 2,000 shares and one son holds 600 Telstra shares. The profit from the sale of these Telstra shares is, of course, far in excess of the additional $16,000 that attaches to the salary of the Deputy President of the Senate.

Before anyone accuses me of the politics of envy, let me make one thing perfectly clear: there is absolutely nothing about Senator Colston that I envy. Of course, we know that Senator Colston is not the only individual to acquire Telstra shares. The opposition has now learnt that a spouse of a senior coalition frontbencher managed to purchase 10,000 shares through an investment company in which she has a controlling interest. These were purchased at the time of the float in two separate parcels. In addition, this spouse purchased two parcels personally. Guess when these were disposed of and came off the register? It was on 6 July 1998, the very day the opposition raised questions about the purchase of Telstra shares by ministers and their families.

The Senate has already heard of the existence and extraordinary share acquisitions of the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. We know that Investment Management Pty Ltd, a holding company for the Warwick Parer family trust and a company in which Senator Parer held eight of the nine shares, acquired a parcel of 2,600 Telstra shares on 25 November 1997. This was despite a prohibition on ministers and their staff acquiring shares within 90 days of the Telstra float. This ban, provided in writing to all ministers last August, extends to trusts, nominees and other proxy style arrangements.

But Senator Parer, running true to form, decided that the ban did not apply to him. What was he thinking when, as he now claims, he brought this issue to the attention of his staff at a meeting and then put it to his staff in writing? How ironic it is that, at the very time Senator Parer was warning his staff off acquiring Telstra shares, he and his wife acquired one parcel through IMPL of 2,600 units; one parcel in the name of Kathleen Parer of 2,200 units; one parcel in Gashbah Pty Ltd of 3,000 units; a parcel in Spanlex Pty Ltd via the Rutherglen superannuation trust of 5,000 units; and one parcel in the name of the Warwick Parer family trust No. 2 account of 2,200 units. That is right: 15,000 shares to the minister and his spouse were tied up in this purchase either through controlling companies or from being bought individually.

That, of course, does not include the rest of the shares held by the rest of his immediate family either directly in their own names or through an investment vehicle called White Rhinos Pty Ltd, which is a new holding company for the Warwick Parer family trust. These arrangements now account for 8,900 units of Telstra shares and represent at least 18 different parcels of shares at the time of the float.

We now know that, at the same time Senator Parer was helping himself to a large parcel of shares in defiance of the Prime Minister's directive, Mr Bob Baudino, his media adviser, was also investing in Telstra. Bob Baudino acquired 1,600 units on the day of the float. Two days later, these shares were transferred to the joint names of him and his wife, Olive, at their home address in a Brisbane suburb. Yet Mr Baudino now expects us to believe that he was unaware that these shares were purchased on behalf of him and his wife. No explanation, of course, was given as to why the spouse got an additional parcel of 5,200 shares. They probably did not know about it at all.

Mr Baudino tells us that he instructed his broker not to purchase Telstra shares. He must have been surprised when he received in the mail at his home address the issuer sponsored statement advising him of his Telstra shareholding. He would have been stunned and outraged when in early April he received again at home a statement advising him of his Telstra dividend. What did Mr Baudino think when he received these statements? We will not know until Mr Whitrow's report is complete and Senator Parer explains to this chamber how these extraordinary events occurred.

The contemptuous disregard of the Prime Minister's directive did not end with Mr Baudino. We now know that Mr Geoff Cousins, a consultant to the Prime Minister, also purchased Telstra shares. He sold his two parcels on 30 December 1997. The explanation from the Prime Minister's office is that Mr Cousins did not advise on telecommunications matters, had no access to price sensitive information and was only a part-time consultant anyway. However, like the Guide on the key elements of ministerial responsibility, it now appears that the Prime Minister's Telstra directive is headed for the scrap heap. The directive was categorical. It instructed ministers to inform all their staff not to purchase Telstra shares within 90 days. If you happened to be a part-time consultant earning $44,000 for one day's work a week, you were not suddenly exempted from it. But especially for ministers with an ongoing involvement with Telstra—the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts and the Prime Minister—there was a total prohibition, not just a 90-day one. Nevertheless, they managed to buy these shares.

We also know that Mr Howard's senior economic adviser holds Telstra shares, bought before he took the job—we have always said that—but there are clear guidelines in the handbook and in the employment handbook about how owning shares can involve a conflict of interest. Has he ever had anything to do with this particular piece of legislation or cabinet decisions that derive from it? However, this government will not answer that fundamental question. It will just go up to the gallery, put the line out and then disappear without proper questioning. What we need to do in these matters and what our job is in opposition—in spite of what those opposite might say—is to take the Prime Minister's standards as he says them and see if they are properly applied. And let me say, the search will go on; there are many more staffers whose records in terms of Telstra purchases are yet to be revealed.

The final point I want to make here today, and returning to the point made earlier, is this legislation can pass only with the coalition voting for it—and thereby breaking the Prime Minister's word—with Senator Harradine voting for it—and basically breaching undertakings he has made in the past—and with Senator Colston's corrupted vote in this chamber. But there is one other group that really has a lot to answer for in this regard. I will give the Liberal Party this: they have some brownie points for consistency. They have considered the issue; they have evaluated it; they will take their electoral risks and they will make their decision. I accept that. But what we have seen from the National Party has been nothing short of pathetic.

We have seen the big statements in the papers by Senator Boswell and Senator Sandy Macdonald that they do not really believe that Telstra should be privatised. We did not take any notice of that. We knew they would roll over. We knew they would sell out the bush. We knew they would not have the intestinal fortitude to stand up to the Prime Minister. We knew they would get rolled right out. The National Party of Australia today is full of intellectual dwarfs. It is nothing like the National Party of 25 or 30 years ago when the Jack McEwens, the Doug Anthonys, the Ian Sinclairs and the Nixons—hard men but effective men in politics, men of intellect, men of gravitas—ruled in the National Party. What have they been replaced with? Absolute flim-flam; they have been replaced by people who will not stand up for their own constituency.

That is why, when you look at the results in the Queensland state election, you will find some booths where they got 85 per cent of the vote historically but they are down to 30 per cent of the vote. The National Party just do not know which way to jump. They suffer from all forms of conflict of disloyalty on these sorts of issues. Do they represent their bush interests or should they continue their subservience to their coalition masters who just tell them what to do?

Nothing could have been clearer in this regard than the recent fracas over preferences. You have the Queensland state branch of the Nationals in which their most prominent federal member, Senator Ron Boswell, advocates taking the fight to One Nation on their ground and taking them on. What does he get from the rear echelon, the David Russells of this world? He gets, `We'll continue to send preferences to One Nation. By the way, let's get rid of our policy on guns. Let's get rid of our competition policy. Let's dump all those things off the sled so One Nation can feed on them and maybe, just maybe, our miserable hide can be saved.' It does not work like that. Basically, David Russell and the Queensland National Party are saying, `Senator Boswell, you're an irrelevancy. You don't matter. You can't have a say in policy formulation, strategy, tactics or any other matter. You are not going, in fact, to influence the policies of the National Party in Queensland.'

The National Party elsewhere in Australia continues to decline in a much weakened state. Take my own state of Victoria, where they hold two lower house seats: one with a crippled ex-minister who has been absolutely marginalised and the other in the north of the state whose member has never been heard of in his life and never will be—maybe his two-day trip to the US for a prayer breakfast is the best he will ever do in terms of publicity. So they are basically finished there.

What the bush was relying on was the New South Wales National Party—traditionally the strongest, traditionally the most decent—to put their hands up and defend their constituents' interests: missing in action—all of them, not to be sighted, gave in to the Liberal Party, gave in to the Prime Minister and sold out their own constituents. Basically, this legislation is the longest suicide note in Australian political history and it is from the National Party of Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —A debate about the future of Telstra must encompass and give serious consideration to the needs of people in regional and remote Australia. Let me start by saying that I have heard last night and today the words `regional', `rural' and `bush' roll off the tongues of many senators here. Let us pause for a moment and really think about that. Let us think about outstations that are four hours drive from Gupuwiyak at the top of the Australian north coast. Let us think about people who live at Mutujullu or along the Borroloola Highway. If we really think about them for a moment, we might really get a sense of not just remote and bush people in this country but people who actually live in isolation.

speech.para: I am aware of the numerous articles on, and coverage of, this issue over the last week. It is important that, in standing here and representing Territorians, I ensure their concerns are known and that the impact of this bill is fully understood and appreciated. In the Australian on Monday, 6 July, Wendy Craik, the Executive Director of the National Farmers Federation, was quoted as saying:
The ownership of Telstra is not the issue. . . Rather, it is the price and quality of telecommunications services for the bush that are the key issues.

Her reference to the price and quality of services to the bush is important but I believe ownership, contrary to her view, is just as crucial because, when you are talking about isolated and remote communities in the Northern Territory, the two are linked.

The needs of the bush and regional Australia cannot be ignored or disadvantaged com pared with urban areas. The National Party have known this and they should be concerned. They know that the bush will suffer if Telstra is fully privatised. The latest edition of the Telstra journal, Our Future, has a three-page spread titled `Unique People, Unique Challenges'. This article says:

Meeting the needs of customers in the main cities is one thing. Providing customer service over Australia's vast distances and diverse landscape—from snowfields to the outback—has presented Telstra with challenges that few telecommunications companies face.

These challenges are indeed unique; they are challenges for the people working in rural and remote areas, usually in the most difficult and extreme conditions. The same article goes on to describe the work of one Telstra employee at Tennant Creek. That person is responsible for 13 technicians and line staff and an area of 500 kilometres—and let us just try to picture that again when we are talking about regional and rural places—ranging from Tennant Creek to Alice Springs. These people are called upon to change DRSC batteries at places such as Epenarra, which is 350 kilometres south-east of Tennant Creek, or to work on data services, television and radio transmitters, optical fibre jointing and underground PABX systems.

Telstra plays a crucial role in providing a quality and reliable service to the bush in the Northern Territory, especially to pastoral properties, schools, health clinics in remote communities and Aboriginal homelands. Under a fully privatised Telstra, the best guarantee that this government can give to rural and especially remote communities through the universal service obligations is that they will receive a standard telephone service. This standard telephone service is not going to deliver a broadband and on-line service to regional communities, and there is no guarantee that their services would keep up with the latest developments in telecommunications. That is, I might add, if you do have a standard on-line telephone service, and I will get to that in a moment. People in the Northern Territory understand and comprehend that if the service they obtain does not permit them to use the sorts of on-line services that people can use in the metropolitan area, then they are competitively at a massive disadvantage.

Unlike the subjects of privatisation in the past, Telstra operates as a monopoly with extensive community service obligations. Telstra is the communications network for the nation. It is an essential service and a virtual public monopoly. Telstra is currently required to provide subsidised telephone connections to the bush, which would otherwise cost upwards of $10,000. For most customers, the standard new residential telephone connection fee is about $200, but in many parts of regional and rural Australia, the real cost of providing that service can be hundreds even thousands of dollars more.

Under the current system of cross-subsidies, customers pay the same amount regardless of the real cost, and that means that all Australians have equal access to telephone services. Under the cross-subsidy arrangements that operate at the moment, loss making infrastructure in rural and regional Australia is supported by profits made in other parts of Telstra. That means that in the Northern Territory the cross-subsidy can be over $1,000 a line and, in the remote parts, the cross-subsidy can be as high as $4,000 to $6,000.

At the Alice Springs show last weekend, I met a person employed by Telstra to install public payphones in remote Aborignal communities. There are many communities waiting for this commodity because very few families in these areas can afford to maintain a line into their homes. These payphones are installed at a cost of nearly $100,000 each, and the money on the installations is never really recovered. This is due to faults, vandalism and problems with general maintenance.

Once Telstra is sold, it will be gone for good. It will be impossible to get it back. It will also be impossible for any government to force a privately owned Telstra to meet these needs—to meet the needs by putting payphones into the remote communities I was talking about, to meet its current service obligations, particularly in rural and regional Australia. A privately owned Telstra's first responsibility will be to maximise profits to its shareholders. It will be under intense pressure from shareholders to shed its non- profitable operations, and those services in the bush are untimed local calls, directory assistance and general services to remote areas. They will all be obvious targets.

Let us have a look at the real issues for rural and regional Australia, particularly in the Northern Territory. Besides the cost of service and maintenance, there is also the standards of service, including the response times for installation and maintenance. The Telecommunications Performance Monitoring Bulletin: Issue 4—March 1998 Quarter, released by the Australian Communications Authority, shows that the national performance figures for faults cleared within rural areas—calculated within two full working days after being notified of a fault—declined by three percentage points to 81 per cent during the March quarter. For the urban areas in the Northern Territory, there was a decrease from 54 per cent for the December quarter to 45 per cent for the March quarter. Rural fault restoration in the Northern Territory improved though from 61 per cent to 68 per cent, because these figures included the unusually intense wet season that we had this year and the massive effort by Telstra to respond to the damage caused through floods in many parts of the Northern Territory, particularly in Katherine and the Daly River region.

That is something in this debate that people have forgotten about—the intense flooding that we have been subjected to this year in Katherine and the Daly River region and the intense electrical storms that we get during the period of November to April right across the Top End that in one fell swoop have the capacity to wipe out your telephone or electrical systems. In fact we are warned many times that, when there is such an intense storm happening and hovering overhead, we should get off the telephone.

Telstra addressed the situation in Katherine this year by mobilising aircraft and additional resources. Telstra made a number of arrangements to assist the people in Katherine during this flood period. The mobile net circuits were expanded to cater for the influx of volunteers and workers. Special billing extensions were provided as well as advice and consideration for people in the flood affected areas on a case by case basis for both mobile and fixed phone users.

There was a temporary Telstra shop set up at the Telstra depot in Katherine, and the Telstra equipment was there for the use of removing and burying rubbish. So it is appropriate that the community service obligation that Telstra displayed during these times is recognised, but the impact on the Territory to date with the partial sale of Telstra has been detrimental.

In the Territory, staff numbers have been slashed with no regard for customer demand, the seasonal factors I talked about such as the wet season or the population growth. Many Telstra operations have been stripped out of the Territory and relocated in southern capitals. Decision making has been taken out of the hands of local management. Permanent full-time jobs are increasingly being converted to part-time and casual positions up there. Workers are being made redundant and are leaving the Territory with their families. This is having an enormous impact on our regional economies.

Since the partial privatisation of Telstra, the triple 0 emergency service has gone. I am personally aware, through my involvement in the Women's Advisory Council, of the enormous difficulty this has created. If I have a need for an emergency service and I live in a place such as Anula, which is a suburb of Darwin, and I dial triple 0, I get an operator in Adelaide. The time it takes for me to actually tell the person in Adelaide where exactly Anula is in a Darwin suburb is wasting precious seconds that could well be put towards saving a life.

Previously, this service was operated out of a telephone exchange at Casuarina, only some half a kilometre from the suburb of Anula, which I have mentioned. We do not now have local people taking our triple 0 calls, people who understand where these places are. Therefore, we do not have the quick turnaround time that is needed.

The cable assigning has gone from the Territory. Fault management has gone. The mobile phone centre has shut down. SOLAS, which is the Safety of Life at Sea, maritime safety centre has also shut down. The fault reporting function and the assigning of installation and maintenance are under threat and are likely to survive only another year. The training of staff has all but stopped, causing erosion of the skills base. I gave an example before of how someone working out of Tennant Creek not only needs to know one area of the communications industry but needs to be multiskilled.

The Territory is rapidly becoming Telstra's poor relation, and nothing in this discussion about the full privatisation has convinced me that things will improve. The full privatisation of Telstra would see an escalation of the rationalisation process. The new owners of Telstra, non-Australian conglomerates, would demand ever increasing profits, which would result in the user pays principle becoming the norm. Such an outcome would be catastrophic for remote areas of the Territory, areas where telecommunications services are a matter of life and death and where most disadvantaged people are to be found.

The Howard government's blithe assurances that the bush would be looked after are predicated on a short-term solution—that is, its rural infrastructure fund. Once that fund is exhausted, we can look forward to some taxpayer funded solution which would demand increased contributions from those who can least afford it, rural and remote subscribers—in Territory terms, that means everyone.

Women and the telephone in Australia: a study prepared for Telecom Australia in 1989, provides an interesting insight into the views of Australian women, particularly those women in country and rural areas. The conclusion of this survey states:

Evidence from the Australian survey, hence, opens up an arena of `private sphere' social organisation and activity that has, politically, been overlooked. The nature of this activity has altered importantly in the past two to three decades. Historically, women's telephone communication has moved a long way from its major instrumental uses of 40-50 years ago to its present concentration on protracted intrinsic calling.

Both country men and women in Australia have benefited from the conquest of distance and the part played by telecommunications technology in bringing people closer and closer. Again, the survey states:

Data retrieved indicated the enormous importance of the telephone to country women. "The telephone is top priority", said one woman from a . . . rural centre, "We'd be absolutely lost without it". Many farmers' wives were alone during the day, and "would be very vulnerable to dangers without the telephone". Much ordering was done by phone, the phone was vital for keeping in touch with family and, for rural women, "the phone is a substitute for contact face-to-face".

That is another important aspect of the Territory that has been left unsaid here. There are very few extended families living in any of the parts of the Territory, particularly in the remote areas, or even in Alice Springs and Darwin. For us, the telephone is a vital link, almost weekly, to our families in the rest of this country.

Some 66 per cent of the total remote area population comprises Aboriginal people. While an increasing number of communities and some outstations now have good telephone connections, there are still significant gaps and problems across the country. The lack of a telephone in many Northern Territory outstations, the want of adequate public phones, the vandalism and inoperation of many public phone boxes and the restricted access to the council and community phones in some centres and communities leave a large number of Aboriginal women among Australia's telephone poor.

In the full privatisation of Telstra, there will be winners and losers. Who are these people? Who fits into each of these categories? The winners are the merchant bankers, the stockbrokers, the financial institutions and the Telstra executive and board members. The financial industry loves privatisations because there is plenty of money to be made. The merchant bankers and stockbrokers who worked on the sale of the first one-third of Telstra made over $200 million in management and coordination fees. But that was only part of their earnings.

After the float, stockbrokers made further huge commissions. As people bought and sold Telstra instalments receipts, brokers did particularly well because most of the shares traded have been in small quantities, which attract high commission rates. Although Telstra now has 1.6 million shareholders, the top 20 investors already own 40 per cent of the shares that have been issued, and these investors are big financial institutions such as banks and insurance funds.

The biggest single shareholder is Westpac Corporation, which owns 8.4 per cent of the partly paid shares issued last November. This pattern of ownership is similar to that in most privatised companies. Small shareholders are gradually squeezed out by the big players in the market. Members of the Telstra board also did nicely out of last year's one-third float. While most shareholders, ordinary Australians, received between 600 and 2,000 shares, the 11 member board received a total of 804,114 shares between them. That represents a profit of over $1 million to these Telstra insiders.

But let us look at the losers—the small low spend customers. In a big telecommunications company such a Telstra, the top 20 per cent of customers provide 80 per cent of the profits. Privatisation increases the company's focus on those customers. Residential companies are already getting the rough end of the telecommunications deal when it comes to service quality. For instance, last year barely half of the metropolitan residential customers had faults fixed within 24 hours. The rate for business was 80 per cent.

I have spoken at length about the effect of this bill on regional and rural Australia. Expert reports have shown that Telstra already underspends in the bush. Naturally a privatised company will want to concentrate even more on the profitable areas such as the cities along the eastern seaboard. But how will the government ensure that there is investment in regional areas once its influence over Telstra is gone? Full privatisation means that the government loses the power to direct Telstra to act in the public interest. The present government is trying to reassure country residents by putting part of the Telstra sale money into a special rural infrastructure fund, but where will the money come from in the future once this Telstra piggy bank is empty?

Another loser in this scheme is the employees of Telstra. Telstra's commercial and consumer business unit, which looks after small business and residential customers, has shed 10,000 staff over the last two years as part of the privatisation process, and nearly 20,000 jobs have gone since 1996. While some of those employees have been transferred to other companies, the great majority have simply lost their jobs. These huge job losses affect everyone. In the Northern Territory work is scarce, and this inevitably leads to less money being put into the Territory economy.

The sale of Telstra affects everyone. While it might add to the government's budget surplus, in the long run privatisation will leave the Australian community poorer. Although many Australians bought Telstra shares, these shareholders are still only a small minority of the whole community. Before any of Telstra was sold, all of Australia's 18 million people had `shares' in the company. Every year Telstra paid a dividend to the Australian government and that money could and should be spent on hospitals, schools and the environment. If Telstra is sold off, that money will all go into the pockets of private investors. A lot of it will not be re-invested or spent in Australia or in the Northern Territory, because it will go overseas to foreign shareholders. The biggest loser in all of this debate is the Australian community now and in the future.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate today because the government have once again broken another promise. They have gone about this in a very sneaky way to try to get people to see that the sale of the other two-thirds of Telstra is but a fait accompli given that they have this belief that they will be re-elected at the next election, which is just around the corner. What they are doing, in my view, is very contemptuous of the electorate at the very best. What is at issue in this bill is a fundamental principle of the right of people to be able to communicate, because it is of such great importance.

speech.para: With the technological advances that are being made today, one sees that the services need to be delivered in the rural and regional areas in particular.
