If one were to look at the recent report by the Australian Communications Authority, one would see that there are headlines floating around such as `Telstra lets the bush down'. There was a whole spate of those around the time that the March quarter report for 1998 was released. It showed that Telstra, after one-third privatisation, has let the bush down.

Fundamental under the one-third privatisation was the fact that there was a guarantee to the bush that there could be a ministerial power to direct Telstra in the national interest to save those areas. Under total privatisation, as my colleague Senator Crossin has just said, there is no such guarantee whatsoever. In other words, the safety net which was of great importance to the people in rural and regional areas is being removed. This measure will see those people living with the scepticism of the coalition forces that they showed and enunciated quite clearly at the most recent state election in Queensland, and I will come to that.

We also see an attempt by the National Party to try to win back some of the massive vote that they lost in Queensland by stitching up a deal which, on the surface, they will say protects the interests of rural and regional Queensland, but all it does is provide a short-term bandaid approach to the issue—it gives people in the country no long-term confidence. Why should the people in the country be concerned? If one looks at appendix 8 of the report Telstra: to sell or not to sell?, one will see the effect of cross-subsidisation on rural and regional areas in Australia.

The last figures that we have been able to get were those for 1994-95 based on a federal electorate basis. At that time a total of $225.965 million was used to cross-subsidise services to rural and regional Australia. In my state of Queensland, some $50.974 million or 22.55 per cent of the total cross-subsidisation occurred. It is in large states, such as Queensland, that we see a great need for subsidisation. The interests of the major telecommunications operators in the longer term, and particularly a privatised Telstra, will be to their shareholders.

No matter what undertakings are given here now, those undertakings will in due course mean nought if the shareholders erupt in major disbelief that the company is not delivering them a profit. They will pressure Telstra or other telecom operators to somehow weasel out of their community service obligations. In the longer term, the ultimate effect will be on the service that can be delivered to rural and regional areas.

If one looks at some of the seats in Queensland, one can understand why the National Party in Queensland have been so interested in the 13 June election in Queensland and its result. Let us look at the cross-subsidisation figures that I have for 1994-95. Out of the $50 million for Queensland, $4.1 million went to Capricornia, $2.76 million went to the federal seat of Dawson and $10.7 million—nearly $11 million—went to the seat of Kennedy. No wonder Mr Katter was upset! Nearly $5 million went to Leichhardt and $16.485 million went to the seat of Maranoa—the so-called heartland of the National Party in Queensland. The fact is that, after the 13 June election, the Liberal Party in Queensland was reduced to less than a cricket team—nine seats—and the National Party was decimated and reduced to 23 seats, whilst One Nation has proven to be the big winner.

One can understand why there is a great deal of concern in the National Party, even though it is too little too late. They have deserted the country, deserted the rural and regional people, over a long period of time. In that state election the people of Queensland reacted. They will not be fooled in any way by the attempted pork-barrelling that we are now seeing under this privatisation deal which will come about with the further two-thirds sale of Telstra.

If you look at the effect on the National Party you will start to understand why we are seeing what we are seeing in this chamber today: this bill that seeks to take the two-thirds privatisation and the pork-barrelling that goes with it. Just look at the safe seat of Barambah in Queensland, which in 1995 had a first preference vote for the National Party of 67.21 per cent. The best they could get on the last occasion was 30.96 per cent. Let us look, booth by booth, at some of their so-called safe polling booths—my colleague Senator Ray mentioned this before. You can see how their vote has been decimated and you can see why we have got this grubby deal on now. In Gomerri, for example, the National Party vote in 1995 was 76.18. It has gone down to 34.81—a massive cut. Who was the major winner? One Nation. The Tablelands seat of Barambah was 91.46 per cent but has gone down to 29.33. Tansey has gone from 90.06 down to 36.62. Wondai has gone from 66.38 down to 27.48. The vote has been decimated, so their style is to try to redress the situation, but it is too little too late.

Look at the seat of Crows Nest, which has always been a very safe seat for the National Party in Queensland. In the Esk booth, for example, the vote went from 65.1 down to 29.28. In Highfields, it went from 67.77 down to 44.77. In Oakey, a regional centre in Queensland, it went from 71.83 down to 35.24. These are the sorts of results that are peppered throughout the electorates of Queensland. This is the sort of result that they did not want, but this is the sort of result that they got because of their neglect of Queensland as a state government. They are doing much the same here. Having seen the result, they are now trying to redress it, but it is too little too late.

If the litany of problems for the National Party in Queensland was further elucidated, one would see that there have been massive swings because people do not believe in them. It is as simple as that—people do not believe what the National Party are telling them about the further two-thirds privatisation of Telstra. They have major problems indeed. If one looks briefly at the Courier-Mail of 7 July, this is clearly spelt out. The Queensland Farmers Federation President, Lex Buchanan is quoted as warning the Prime Minister, John Howard of the perils of ignoring bush fears over the sale of Telstra. Mr Buchanan said that the full sale of Telstra policy was a recipe for handing votes to One Nation at the election.

That is Mr Buchanan's opinion. I do not know the gentleman personally, but obviously it is a warning that the National Party have not taken. They obviously have not gone through the results booth by booth and seen the decimation. If they think that they can, in effect, buy back people's votes, they have got something else coming to them—there is no doubt about that.

On the same day an article appeared in the Age by Paul Pickering. I think his article is very relevant to the debate that we are having today on the privatisation of Telstra. His article is about the One Nation Party and its leader. He said:

Surely it did not need Pauline Hanson to remind National Party backbenchers that it is the state that has provided and maintained infrastructure in the bush. They simply needed to look to their own past to understand that the only way to guarantee a continuing cross-subsidy for rural telephone services is through public ownership.
They should heed those words very loudly and very clearly because the path they are heading down today is not only disaster for them but also further disaster for the bush and for Australians.

At the end of the day the consumers out in the bush will not be fooled by the pork-barrelling that is being envisaged under this current privatisation deal between the National Party and the Liberal Party. Those who deserted the National Party are definitely astute enough to know that a temporary pork barrel does not have an infinite limit, as my colleague Senator Crossin pointed out. When it runs out, what will the country, the rural and the regional people have? Nothing; absolutely nothing at all. They will have no powers for the minister to intervene. They will have no safety net.

In the longer term, a fully privatised Telstra will be concerned only about where the telecommunications operators see that they can make real profits. That area, of course, is in the golden triangle—the Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra area—and you can exclude other parts of Australia. Those operators will seek to water down and to weasel out of any commitments that they have had to give to date. They will use classic catchcrys such as, `When we gave that undertaking things were different.' How often do you hear that? How often does one hear that? `This is an unexpected contingency'—they will find any excuse, no doubt, to get out of their commitments, their community service guarantees. They will weasel out of them. So the losers will be the rural and regional people in the longer term. The diamonds might look sparkling from afar now but, once people get to test them, they will see that they are mere glass.

In a world that is becoming more information technology dependent on a daily basis, the rural and regional areas of Australia and in particular my state need some guarantee, not the mealy-mouthed propositions that are coming out of the government at this stage. The government's pork-barrelling in this instance will be only a bandaid approach. It is interesting to look at the West Australian of 9 July. If the other warnings have not been enough for the National Party and the Liberal Party, then they should note the few words of Kevin McMenemy from the Western Australian Farmers Federation. The report says:
Rural WA overwhelmingly opposes Government plans to sell the remaining two-thirds of Telstra and use some of the profits to fund bush infrastructure, says the WA Farmers Federation.

WAFF general president Kevin McMenemy said yesterday that Liberal MPs with country seats would pay at the ballot box if they supported the sale. This could drive farmers into the arms of Pauline Hanson.

Therein lies a lesson in Queensland as well for the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party should well and truly be aware that, where One Nation candidates stood against them, they found themselves in great difficulty—indeed, so much so that, as I have said earlier, they cannot even make up a cricket team in the Queensland parliament. So the warnings are there for the government. Yet, in spite of those warnings, they are not heeding them.

I will look at a couple of other issues which concern me. There will be large job losses out of the privatisation of Telstra. We have already seen in the order of 25,000 jobs go, with another 2,000 more to go. There are spurious claims that these jobs are transferred to the private sector, and that cannot be substantiated in any way. This government should be about job creation, not about job destruction. There are two more issues that I wish to address.

There is no need for this sale. It will generate an estimated $800 million in service fees to stockbrokers. This has already been addressed by some of my colleagues, but it is completely obscene and immoral that we are passing $800 million to stockbrokers and the like when this money could be otherwise used to great purpose and great intent out there in the community at large on a wide range of issues. There is no doubt in my mind that this is one of the real obscene parts of this proposed privatisation.
Last but not least, I want to quote Hansard of 9 December 1996. In response to a question from Senator Mackay about the then one-third sale, Senator Alston said:

Can I just get to this other major issue—that somehow selling one-third means you inevitably sell the lot? Just for your information, NTT, Nippon Telephone and Telegraph, sold 35 per cent in 1984. They have not gone further since that time. There is no inevitability about anything in this life or in this field.

talk.start.para: —Obviously not!

—No, but it gets better as we go on. The impression he was trying to create there was: whilst we are selling one-third, there is undoubtedly no inevitability that we will go beyond one-third. The response continues:

speech.para: The fact is that unless you somehow think this parliament is about to change beyond recognition, and I do not think it is, it would mean that the Democrats or the Labor Party would have to change their position in order to repeal a provision of this very bill that is before us because this bill does not allow the parliament to go beyond the sale of one-third of Telstra. That is a fact. You know our commitment.
Senator Alston went on to say:

If you are about to propose that, I would be very surprised. I have not seen any sign of it. You can run that argument as much as you like, but the fact is that there is no inevitability about it at all. It would require a conscious vote in favour by a majority of both houses of parliament. I do not see that in the Senate in the foreseeable future, and I do not think you do either.
Then there was an interjection—and I think Senator Bourne will enjoy this—by Senator Kernot:
What's the foreseeable future?
Senator Alston replied:
The foreseeable future for me would probably be six years—probably longer than you and I will be here . . .
You have to give credit where credit is due. He got one out of two right. The rest he got wrong, and he was the minister. So what hope do Australians have in putting faith in these people?

talk.start.para: —It is worth remembering that we are here today—and we will be here for quite a bit longer, I suspect—to debate a bill, which I am sure the government hopes to pass, which will put into effect something which was not mentioned at the last election and which will not be proclaimed until after the next election. Obviously there is no urgency in this whatsoever. Putting that aside, there are two fundamental problems with the government's current approach.

speech.para: Senator Kemp interjecting—
Senator Hill interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Kemp, it would be more appropriate if you ceased interjecting. Senator Hill, it is inappropriate for you to interject and it is even more inappropriate to interject when you are not in your own seat.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The first problem is that passing this legislation has nothing to do with a mandate. The government obviously never had a mandate to sell any of Telstra. We all know that our constituents vote for a myriad of reasons. People simply do not vote on one issue. How will the government know, for example, whether they have been voted in or out of office at the next election on the basis of their decision to sell Telstra, funding cuts to the ABC, funding cuts to education, funding cuts to health, the way they have handled nursing home funding, native title or a host of other reasons? Of course they will not.

speech.para: Secondly, the government says they have stuck to their promise not to sell all of Telstra because they intend not to proclaim this legislation until after the next election. Why are we debating it now and why is there an open-ended commencement clause in the bill? This kind of open-ended commencement hands a blanket cheque to the executive to determine whether legislation passed by the parliament will ever come into effect.

Accordingly, the government should now abandon this bill and campaign on the sale of Telstra—the sale of Telstra alone—not on taxes or anything else. If they are re-elected, they can debate this bill in the session of parliament after the next election. This is a fairer and a more honest approach to the community and to parliamentary procedure. If they make their arguments well enough, they will get more than 50 per cent of the Senate and they can do absolutely anything they like.

The other problem behind the government's decision to sell Telstra relates to the basic assumption with the privatisation agenda of successive Australian governments. Over the past decade and a half the privatisation agendas of both the ALP and the coalition have typically been undertaken with very little consideration given to the alternatives or any medium- to long-term consequences.

The key question we have to ask in this debate is: who is going to gain from the sale of Telstra? Governments had neither the integrity nor the ingenuity to push for alternative ways of expanding their revenue base. They have not had the imagination to devise better ways of improving our national savings. And for largely ideological reasons they have not wanted to formally acknowledge the significant contribution that public investment makes to this country. Instead, it is far easier to sell off public assets and attempt to convince the Australian people that it is in their best interests to do so. The Democrats do not believe that selling Telstra is in this country's best interests. It is not very convincing to be told that just because other countries are privatising their national communication carriers Australia should do likewise.

The government also seeks to convince us, without adequate evidence, that we will be better off with a privatised Telstra. If `we' are the taxpayers and the general public, I do not think we will be better off. If `we' are the big end of town—the stockbrokers and the lawyers who will sell Telstra, or the overseas investors who will buy it—certainly, we will be better off. But that is not an argument. That is just a pressure tactic and one which lacks any intellectual credibility. It is nothing more than appeal to fashion and one which seeks to deny Australians the right to make up their own minds whether partial or full privatisation of our national communications carrier is in our best interests.

There is no intrinsic merit in blindly following what the UK or New Zealand have done, let alone—as Senator Alston was so fond of reminding me—what Cuba or Albania have done. Every country has its own unique geographical, historical, political, social and cultural circumstances. It is simply ridiculous to compare Australia with countries like Cuba and Albania in terms of privatisation issues.

What we have with Telstra is a privatisation agenda which, like privatisation in general, is being largely driven by two key concerns. The first is that privatisation provides an immediate source of large amounts of revenue for the government. The government claims it will use the revenue it expects to generate from the sale to reduce net debt, thereby saving money on interest repayments. The government also says it will use a proportion of the sale to fund new social bonus packages. But, apart from rumours about spending on a major regional development package on roads and rural health initiatives, the government has not announced where, or on what, it actually intends to spend this money. The questions of whether the proposed expenditure and the regulation of the industry are desirable are independent of the sale of Telstra.

Secondly, the sale is being driven by the belief that private enterprise is inherently more efficient and more accountable than the public sector. But, generally speaking, the history of privatisation in Australia and overseas has not got a good track record. Companies tend to be sold too cheaply and they do not deliver the goods after they are privatised to the extent that they have promised beforehand.

Let us look very closely at these two concerns. I do not believe they provide sufficient justification for turning our most profitable public enterprise into Australia's second biggest private corporation. First of all, let us look at the financial implications. Not surprisingly, it has been proven to be very difficult to get a clear indication of the full financial implications of this sale. Of course, this may not be unrelated to the large number of players with a vested interest in not telling the Australian public just who the big winners and losers might be.

This is one of the reasons why parliamentary scrutiny of the proposed sale was so necessary. What a pity the government insisted on such a short committee inquiry. The bill was referred to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee on 1 April 1998—somewhat symbolic—and reported on 26 May 1998, after the Senate agreed to a two-week extension. So four weeks went out to six weeks and that was all the time the government permitted the Senate to investigate and report on these issues.

It is not unreasonable for the federal parliament, on behalf of the Australian public, to take a close look into the sale of the government's most profitable business enterprise. However, the short time frame for the inquiry—something this government appears to be very keen on lately, although they were not when they were in opposition—has not allowed the federal parliament to do that adequately. But, even during that short time, the expert evidence presented to the inquiry indicated that the sale of Telstra would significantly reduce the net worth of the public sector as a result of the interest saving in public debt being less than the future profit stream forgone.

John Quiggin, Professor of Economics at James Cook University, and Dr Allan Brown from the Economics Department of Griffith University have argued strongly that this is most likely to be the case. They believe the privatisation of Telstra will result in a substantial loss to the net worth of the public sector and will represent a bad deal for taxpayers. In his submission to the first Senate Telstra inquiry in 1996, Professor Quiggin estimated that the value of Telstra in public ownership was $54.4 billion. This estimate was based on Telstra's after tax profits compared with the net sale proceeds required to generate similar savings in public debt interest. Fifty-four billion dollars is more than twice the market price that analysts believe Telstra will realise if sold. One of the reasons for this, he argues, is that private equity holders demand a far greater rate of return on their investment than the real rate of return on government debt.

According to Professor Quiggin, only under the most unrealistically pessimistic profit scenarios would the government's partial privatisation scenario appear attractive. In his opinion, the partial privatisation of Telstra has so far resulted in forgone earnings of $520 million, as against interest savings of $450 million. That gives us a net loss of $70 million—and that is just so far. The loss to the public sector is expected to increase over time because earnings are expected to grow while interest savings remain constant.

But let us consider for a moment the situation where the interest saving in public debt from selling Telstra is equal to the future profit stream forgone. What then? For a start, the government would not be any better off; it would simply have realised the value in cash terms of an asset valued at that amount. The net worth of the public sector would remain totally unchanged.

If the government uses the proceeds from Telstra's sale to retire public sector debt, the debt would fall and so would assets. Again, public sector net worth would remain unchanged. The government would simply have reduced the stream of future interest payments on the debt by the same amount as the income flow from the enterprise which would have been used to pay the interest on the debt. Where is the value to the nation in that? It can surely be argued just as legitimately that it is better to retain Telstra in full public ownership and use the cash flow generated to repay public debt and fund existing programs or new ventures from consolidated revenue than from promises of one-off grants.

When assessing the impact of privatisation on the net worth of the public sector, we also have to look at the transaction costs involved. We have to look at the fees paid to the lawyers, to the accountants, to the bankers, to the stockbrokers, and to the marketing and the advertising agents. These costs are often conveniently overlooked in public discussion about this privatisation. The partial privatisation of Telstra cost $260 million—what sort of social bonus programs could that have funded?

Moreover, underpricing of public assets is one of the hallmarks of privatisation in this country—it happened with the Commonwealth Bank, it happened with Qantas, it happened with the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and it happened with the first third sale of Telstra. That means that a relatively small number of people—the new shareholders and those administering the transaction—make a gain at the expense of all the taxpayers of Australia. There are simply no guarantees that this will not happen again with the sale of the remaining two-thirds of Telstra.

This all adds up to the sale of Telstra involving selling off our highest income earning public asset for no net economic gain. In fact, on John Quiggin's figures, Australian taxpayers could be paying for the sale for many years to come. That is just not good public policy.

Let us have a look at the government's claim that the privatisation of Telstra will result in overall efficiency gains. If taxpayers are to be sufficiently compensated for the potential loss in public sector net worth, then spectacularly large efficiency gains or improvements in customer service need to occur as a direct consequence of a change in ownership. I see no reason to anticipate efficiency gains beyond those that would have occurred without a change in ownership.

The most recent figures from the Australian Communications Authority indicate that Telstra's efficiency has fallen in the last two quarters since partial privatisation. Even Mr Frank Blount, before he became an advocate for the government's privatisation agenda, said that it was the marketplace, not who owns the company, that is the real reformer.

A significant amount of research has been undertaken which indicates that efficiency and consumer responsiveness are not inherently dependent on ownership but, rather, on a combination of good management, effective competition, technological progress, regulation and consumer pressure. There is no direct or inevitable association between economic performance and the type of ownership. The fact is that the performance and efficiency of government owned enterprises can and have been extensively improved under public ownership—look at Australia Post.

A 1995 study by the Industry Commission found that Telstra had reduced its prices since 1989-90 by 16 per cent in real terms while doubling labour productivity and increasing payments to government by over 60 per cent since 1990-91. Remember, that was in 1995. It is simply propaganda to claim that privatisation offers some magic recipe by which Telstra will automatically make significant efficiency gains. Efficiency is not about privatisation; it is about management; it is about a commitment to service provision. Australians should be seriously questioning the government's commitment and the capacity of Telstra's management to deliver the sort of service that we want, irrespective of whether or not Telstra is sold.

Moreover, even if efficiency gains are made under private ownership, there is no reason to assume that they will be passed on to consumers in the form of lower prices, rather than being captured as profits by shareholders. In fact, if the partial privatisation is anything to go by, all that we are likely to see after full privatisation is a sharp rise in the salaries of Telstra's senior executives, efficiency measured in terms of the number of job losses, and no great increase in customer service outcomes.

The ideological basis which claims that private enterprise is inherently more efficient than public enterprise fails to take into account the fact that government enterprises have more objectives than just maximising profits. Government enterprises are charged with social objectives, or community service obligations, which are equally as important as profit making but which successive governments have portrayed as sources of economic inefficiency. Their importance for promoting the national interest should never be underestimated.

I acknowledge that the provision of the universal service obligation is not directly related to the issue of privatisation. The universal service obligation can be continued under legislative direction, irrespective of Telstra's ownership. I am concerned, though, that privatisation will inevitably place the provision of the USO under increasing pressure, along with other regulations, such as price capping, which are presently imposed on Telstra.

There is also much debate about the optimal means for delivering the universal service obligation. This issue is not directly related to privatisation, but this should not mean that we avoid discussion on a very critical issue at this time. The importance of the USO is reflected by the number of submissions to the Senate Telstra inquiry which have commented on this issue from a range of perspectives.

The Democrats will continue to advocate that the USO be funded from carriers themselves rather than from consolidated revenue. As soon as the payment for the USO is transferred from those who are responsible for delivering it, to the budget, it is far more vulnerable to elimination or reduction in effectiveness. As soon as governments start looking for an area in which to save a few extra dollars, you can be sure that the USO will come up for review. But, if the ownership of carriers is an important issue for delivering efficient service, carriers should also be responsible for funding the delivery of the USO, as that is, in effect, their contribution to the good governance of this industry.

The community has a legitimate expectation that the government will pursue social objectives in the provision of telecommunication services. This inherent tension will only be exacerbated by privatisation. A privatised Telstra will be governed by a board of directors acting not in the national interest, not in the interests of remote communities whose services are largely subsidised, but in the interests of the company and its shareholders—a company which will be one of Australia's largest, wielding tremendous economic and political clout.

A privatised Telstra means a high risk of losing our ability to set, maintain and deliver community service obligations in the national interest. If the government were serious about the USO, it would have ensured that the bill's preamble, at the very least, reflected all three tiers of the universal service obligation; at the moment it only has two.

We also recommended that regular reviews of the USO be enshrined in legislation. That would enable it to be amended if it were seen to be ineffective and not dynamic enough. Even the government acknowledges that it cannot simply give a privatised Telstra free rein to do whatever it likes. The very existence of a customer service guarantee acknowledges that a liberalised, privatised telecommunications market will not, of itself, deliver adequate levels of service to all Australians.

The customer service guarantee sets mandatory service levels in a number of areas. We note the minister's recent media release concerning increased penalties for failures to meet the customer service guarantee standards in non-metropolitan areas. Of course, customer service is important; no-one would deny that. But the only way to ensure that the service provider complies with the standard is through tougher regulation and enforcement—not merely increasing the scale of charges. The scale of charges should reflect the lack of service provided, not just a geographical area.

The crunch will, of course, come when the government is called upon to impose customer service guarantees on Telstra. It claims that a lack of service can result in a carrier being fined $10 million—a drop in the huge telecommunications ocean in any case.

The only other argument the government has put forward to justify the sale of Telstra is the one that is the most intellectually bankrupt and economically irresponsible of all: the attempt to link the sale with funding of so-called social bonus programs. Consider the precedent that this sets: government funding for programs which all parties and a vast majority of the electorate deem desirable being made conditional on Telstra's sale—a highly contentious policy still opposed by the majority of the electorate; that majority do not want Telstra sold.

Social programs deserve to be funded in their own right from the federal budget. Imagine the outcry if the government stated that ongoing funding for schools, hospitals, nursing homes or employment programs were all dependent on the sale of Telstra. The simple fact is that the sale of assets has no bearing on the government's capacity to afford current expenditure programs. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) knows this, and I can remember many occasions when the coalition pointed this out to previous Labor governments, chastising them for attempting to use asset sales to conceal budget deficits. The importance of this point should not be lost, and Australians should not be misled into believing that the government will not be able to afford to meet its obligations if it does not sell Telstra.

The government's inclusion of the proceeds from the sale of Telstra in the latest budget figures is arrogant and misleading. The Democrats are joined by the majority of Australians who oppose the sale of Telstra. Clever accounting will not detract from the fact that debt reduction through the sale of public assets is not in the national interest. The Democrats believe that the opponents of Telstra's sale have at least as compelling a case as those in favour of it. That is because the sale of such a vital public asset comes down to principles and values, not just to the government's economic imperatives. There are sound social, economic and political arguments for not selling Telstra—and I will be voting against its sale.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise to speak—
—He speaks! He speaks!
—I suppose, Senator Carr, you have come in especially to hear me speak this afternoon.
—Senator McGauran, please direct your remarks through the chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Since the senator has invoked my name in his address, could I ask that he be given the opportunity to explain whether or not he will be standing down to allow Jeff Kennett to enter the Senate in his place.
—There is no point of order. Senator Kemp, there is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to raise a point of order. We have heard many opposition speakers. No points of order were taken on those senators, thus allowing them to speak and complete their remarks.
—Constant interruption!
—Senator Carr seems to have forgotten that—and, Senator Carr, if this is the way you wish to run it, so be it, but we will remember it.
—Order! There is no point of order in either case.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I can assure you that I will not be further provoked by Senator Carr during my speech, and I will get on with the matter at hand. The Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 provides legislation for the final two-thirds sale of Telstra, following the success of the initial one-third sale in October 1997.

speech.para: The first Telstra share offer opened on 15 October 1997 and, by the close of applications, over 1.8 million Australians had applied for shares. This resulted in the float being five times oversubscribed. Over 92 per cent of Telstra's employees took up the offer at the time. The one-third float of Telstra was the largest in the history of the Australian Stock Exchange, raising—well over budget estimates—$14.2 billion. At the close of the first day's trade—and since, may I add—the average investor who purchased over 900 shares was about $650 better off.

I make that point to indicate the demand for and the popularity of—at least the popularity of it with the 1.8 million Australians who took up the share offer—the one-third sale of Telstra. Just as the mandate was sought by this government for the one-third sale of Telstra prior to the last election, the government is seeking a mandate now for the two-thirds sale of Telstra prior to the next election. If we are given that mandate at the next election, we will have the political authority and the legislative ability to trigger the final two-thirds sale of Telstra.

It is fair to say that there are four main concerns raised with regard to the sale of Telstra, and privatisation as an issue as a whole: firstly, `Why sell the family silver?' is the most commonly asked question; secondly, the rural and regional areas will lose out; thirdly, and it is the most popular concern, the foreign corporations will buy up this key Australian asset; and, fourthly, there is the concern that the sale of Telstra will lead to job losses.

Each concern can be answered. Firstly, with regard to the sale of the family silver: it is true that a full sale of Telstra does follow this government's strategy of selling major government utilities, like the Federal Airports Corporation, raising well over $4 billion; the Australian National rail network; and the Australian shipping service, ANL. It is also true to say that Telstra is the largest privatisation undertaken in Australia and ranks highly on the world scale.

Privatisation is not unique to Australia. There has been a movement over the last decade for governments worldwide to sell government owned assets, and there are two primary reasons put forward to explain this economic strategy. The first is that governments should not be in the business of running a business, that private enterprise does it better. Inevitably, the government assets are a monopoly having the dual evils of monopoly pricing, which is always far too high, and monopoly customer service, which is always far too poor.

Therefore, the sale of a government monopoly, along with allowing new entrants into the market, opens up the sector to competition and market forces, which in the long run brings improved customer service and improved pricing. Telstra is the perfect example of this. As a monopoly, it overcharged and underserviced. Ask anyone who tried to ring through to Telstra when it was a monopoly.
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —What a difference competition has made to Telstra. Today, competition, primarily from Optus, has given a choice to the consumer which has led to the fall in phone call prices and in particular a fall in the cost of an international call.

speech.para: The second reason advanced for the argument of privatisation is to reduce government debt. Throughout the 1980s and 1990s governments across the world have racked up high levels of debt, burdening their budgets with interest payment commitments. It is worth noting that the legacy this government was left in regard to debt was $100 billion. Incredibly, that figure jumped in the last four years of the previous government. From a manageable $32 billion in 1992, by 1996—coincidentally, the Keating years—the debt had jumped to $100 billion. Governments have a choice in meeting their debt commitments. Either they increase taxes or they sell their assets. Given that many countries have reached the zenith of their tax raising abilities, the sale of a government asset is the best choice. In the case of Telstra, it is estimated that some $40 billion will be raised, which will go towards reducing the government's debt legacy.

The benefits of the debt legacy are obvious. Firstly, a government with a low debt ratio to GDP or with a debt reduction strategy of some sort in place gains the confidence of the market towards its currency and, moreover, it secures a high credit rating. Let me give the Victorian example, Senator Carr.

talk.start.para: —How many jobs have been lost in Victoria?
—By improving their credit rating back to a AAA rating, their borrowings are taken out at a lower interest rate, saving the Treasury billions of dollars.
—Jeff Kennett was right!

—Secondly, it will free up government expenditure for other initiatives. While it is true that the government receives a dividend from Telstra each year, which also can be used towards budgetary purposes, it does not match the $1.5 billion saving on interest payments through the debt reduction program.

speech.para: An example of how some capital and interest savings can be directed as a social bonus can be seen in the funds resulting from the one-third sale of Telstra where they were directed. The highly successful $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust was a result of the one-third sale of Telstra. The Natural Heritage Trust is the largest environmental rescue effort ever undertaken by an Australian government. Furthermore, the Natural Heritage Trust allocated $163 million for one of Australia's most important agricultural regions, the Murray-Darling Basin.

The second major question people ask in regard to the sale of Telstra is whether the selling of a government owned asset would be detrimental to the rural and regional areas of Australia, because privately owned companies will not undertake to uphold certain social responsibilities. The answer to this is as follows: the government is not only genuinely committed to the rural and regional areas of Australia but we have enshrined that commitment in legislation. The government has legislated in two areas: the universal service obligation, the community service obligation—
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —In fact, this government has strengthened these obligations prior to full privatisation.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Interjections, as we all know, are a contravention of the standing orders. Sustained interjections, Senator Carr, are unacceptable and I would ask that each senator be given the opportunity to be heard in reasonable silence.

—The USOs ensure that all Australians have access to a standard telephone service and pay phones, regardless of where they live. Where Telstra incurs a loss in complying with the USO, it is entitled to recoup that loss. The amount is recouped by imposing a levy on all the other carriers, like Optus, in proportion to their share of the market.

speech.para: The cost to install a new residential telephone connection is capped. This was done prior to privatisation. By law, the average residential connection cost must decrease in every year by one per cent in real terms. This means that the amount paid by regional customers to connect to Telstra's network is capped even when the real cost of connection is many times higher. Further to this, the coalition government has introduced a special scheme to ensure that local call prices in regional areas do not exceed the average local call price in major capital cities. This protection stays regardless of who owns Telstra.

Perhaps the strongest response to concerns from the rural and regional areas that they may miss out as a result of privatisation is the enshrining and the strengthening of the community service guarantee. This CSG was introduced by the coalition government and took effect in January this year. Under the Telecommunications Act 1997, the guarantee means that telephone companies are legally required to meet service standards on things such as the time taken to connect a new phone service, the time taken to repair a faulty service and turning up for an appointment on time. If the service falls below the CSG performance standard, customers are eligible to compensation from the telecommunications company. An example of this is the $40 penalty that will be applied each day after five working days of delay in rectifying faults within a standard telephone service. What is more, that fine goes to the aggrieved customer.

Furthermore, in support of the rural and regional areas, the coalition government last year introduced the $250 million innovation scheme named the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund. This fund ensures that rural and regional phone users have access to the latest technologies and infrastructure agreements. To date, 96 rural and regional projects worth over $57 million have been approved. Of late, the government has also announced a dramatic upgrading in relation to the regional mobile phone services and also in regard to untimed pastoral calls. Those two announcements have been made in the last two days.

In relation to the third concern, that foreign companies will buy up this key asset, in short, this simply cannot happen. The rules of foreign ownership have been enshrined in legislation. Telstra will remain majority Australian owned with no more than 35 per cent foreign ownership, and no single foreign owner is allowed to have more than five per cent of Telstra. The chairman and the majority of the board will be Australian.

The fourth concern relates to the impact privatisation will have on employment. However, the moving to full private ownership will not in itself impact on Telstra's employment levels. Telstra is two years into a downsizing program which has reduced total staff numbers from almost 77,000 in 1995 to 59,000 in early 1998. The announced target of around 51,000 will be reached by the year 2000.

talk.start.para: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senators are not supposed to read their speeches verbatim, and I would have thought that Senator McGauran would make some effort to show that he could actually speak occasionally away from his copious notes and perhaps explain to us why 3,000 jobs in Victoria have gone from Telstra while he has been a National Party senator for Victoria.
—Why have you remained silent?

—Senator Carr, as I said before, sustained interjections are unacceptable. With regard to the point of order raised by Senator Schacht, I understand that Senator McGauran does have a number of notes he may be referring to and I would at this time say that there is no point of order with respect to the point raised.

—I am trying to get my speech down pat without interruption, and it has really been hard work. I am convinced of the value of the privatisation of Telstra and I would like to be able to convince my electorate.
—Why don't you quote from yesterday's Herald Sun ?

—I will be responding to the Herald Sun , Senator Schacht. I have a right of reply and I shall be responding. I made a commitment to Senator Murphy when he was in the chair not to be provoked by these people so I can just get my case argument down, but it has indeed been very hard work to plough through it. You think I am reading from a speech, but I am simply keeping my eyes down not to be distracted by the other side. There was a moment there when I could have been distracted to mention the AAA rating of the state of Victoria and how that has saved billions of dollars to the Victorian government and its Treasury and through them to the Victorian people. How did they come to that situation, Senator Carr? You should know, because you were in the previous government that racked up the debt that sent that state broke. I can read all about it from former Premier Cain, about how you went about that business of wrecking the state of Victoria for your own personal and absurd political reason. You have ruined my speech now, Senator Carr, so I might as well go off my notes and make my retort in the Herald Sun .
—Jeff Kennett has got the measure of you!

—I am going to bring that book in and quote just what John Cain said. You often come back at me about what Jeff Kennett says about me, and we all know he has a lot to say about a lot of people. I do not know how he retains half of his comments against people; he must write them down. I am but one, Senator Carr. But I will tell you what: no-one despises another more than John Cain despises you, because you not only wrecked the government, you wrecked the state. Senator Cooney, you know this to be true. Do not slink away.
—Senator McGauran, direct your marks through the chair, if you don't mind.

—I will finish the point in regard to employment because it is an important point, if not the most important point, in regard to the privatisation of Telstra. The downsizing is driven not by the ownership—whether it is privatised—but by the combined effects of new technology, improved productivity and competitive pressures, as shown by the fact that it began while Telstra was still 100 per cent owned by the government. It was necessary to meet the new entrants to the market, like Optus, on a competitive footing. But it is worthy of note that the employees have been picked up, probably by Optus. It is an industry that is growing by greater than 14 per cent. That is the employment figure. Most have been picked up; some have even got better jobs.

speech.para: In conclusion, given the enormity of the full sale of Telstra and the importance of the industry it represents—an industry affecting every person in Australian society—it is little wonder that there is so much debate and interest in this issue. I have outlined the four main concerns, to which the government has responded in full, and I am confident that the answers given will ensure a mandate from the Australian people in the forthcoming election. To this end, I urge the Senate to support the legislation.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 . As is known from the register of interests, I have Telstra shares.

speech.para: This bill proposes the full privatisation of the rest of Telstra. I am utterly opposed to this, and I am appalled that the details of the deal—the buy-off of the National Party—are not even known to this parliament. Why is there such unseemly haste? Why is there such a claimed urgency to push this bill through this place? We know why. It is because there is an election coming very soon indeed, so it is necessary to settle this package to buy off the necessary votes. A lot of people have been complaining about the way this government has not been listening to people, particularly in rural and regional Australia. We know about that because of an inquiry on regional unemployment that we are doing at the moment, and I will come back to that shortly.

I do not believe that the majority of Australians will be fooled by this very cynical little exercise. Why would a package whose details are not known convince people that they should trust this government when it is clearly understood to be nothing more than a very cynical exercise to buy off the National Party votes? Those votes were very much threatened because the National Party knows two things: it knows that it is very seriously under threat in the forthcoming election because of the recent ballot in Queensland, and it knows more than many people just how important Telstra is to people in rural and regional Australia.

It also knows that, despite its mistakes or insufficiencies, a public Telstra is better by far than a privatised one. In any polling, well over 60 per cent of Australians are totally opposed to the privatisation of the rest of Telstra. They are concerned about that because they know what will happen when Telstra is privatised. The services will fall off and the prices will rise. It is a very simple equation.

The other interesting thing about the benefits that have been wrung out of the Prime Minister through this package of between $400 million and $800 million—paid for by the rest of the taxpayers of this country—is that the services that are provided now could be provided with a public Telstra if there were a directive from the government. There is absolutely no need to privatise Telstra to achieve what the government is proposing to achieve.

This legislation and these decisions are not about policy, they are about politics. They are about the politics of cynicism and fear and it is something that will not be lost on the people of this country. They have made it very clear to us, particularly through the poll in Queensland, that they will not be taken for fools and they will not be taken to not understand the insufficiency of this government. They know about broken promises, they know about core promises and non-core promises, and they know that once Telstra is sold, it is sold forever. It is gone.

I want to read a couple of quotes that I think are very important, from a transcript of today's interview with Lex Buchanan from the Queensland Farmers Federation, who was being interviewed on ABC Radio's AM program. The journalist asked:
Do you think the Federal Government should hold off on its plans to sell off the rest of Telstra and implement new mobile phone technology and these other things that they've promised first?
Mr Buchanan replied:

That would probably be our preferred position. We have not been impressed, particularly by Senator Alston making the comment publicly that when certain politicians were coming to him to put the case that they were wasting their time. We would point out in return that these are the very things that have led to the change in the political structure here in Queensland.

This is not a paid-up member of the Labor Party making this point. This is a member of the Queensland Farmers Federation saying that they have been very disappointed and very unimpressed by Senator Alston's publicly dismissing their attempt to persuade him about their point of view in terms of Telstra and the requirements of people in rural and regional Queensland. In another interview from the same ABC Radio AM program of today, the interviewer, Ms Kirk, is talking to De-Anne Kelly, a National Party member:
Ms Kirk: Dee-Anne Kelly, the Government is promising untimed local calls for an extra 3,000 to 40,000 people—
I would have to say a pretty imprecise figure—
in isolated areas and much, much more, because Telstra is to be sold. How could you knock that back?

Ms Kelly: I certainly wouldn't knock that back at all. It's a very welcome initiative. It's a pity that it had to be delivered under pressure from the bush over the sale of Telstra. I mean, that's one of the services that should be given as part of a fair go for all Australians. But very welcome. However, I would just point out that you don't need to sell Telstra, 100 per cent of Telstra to do that. Yesterday we had an announcement on CDMA upgrades for mobile phones in rural and regional areas, $250 million that Telstra could do for people in the bush and it is still in 66 per cent Government control. So, it can be done. You don't need to sell Telstra.
That is a member of the National Party in this parliament. The interviewer went on:

Ms Kirk: But your own National Party President pointed out the other day it's better to have privately owned Telstra with real benefits for rural customers that they'd not dreamed about 30 years ago . . .
I think there must be an error in this type, so I will end the quote there. Mrs Kelly went on:

Ms Kelly: Well, I respect my President but I'd have to say that the view amongst my constituency very much is that once Telstra is privatised and there's a one-off upgrade, such as untimed local calls, what happens next when there's another technological leap forward, bearing in mind that we don't even have in many areas, access to the Internet as yet. But next time there's a big technological leap forward who pays for the upgrade for rural and regional Australians? I mean, Frank Blount has said last week that Telstra would only upgrade regional and rural services in an affordable and efficient way.

There is a great need for concern. The Labor Party has described, and will continue to describe, that concern. But it is very interesting when the concern could not be described better than it has been by a National Party member of Mr Howard's own government, the member for Dawson, Mrs De-Anne Kelly. It will be interesting to see whether she does hold to her threat to cross the floor when and if this bill is ever returned to the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: —It won't make any difference anyway, will it?

—Quite true. I want to talk about an area that I think is a very big concern, and it has not been particularly developed in this debate—that is, the impact of the privatisation of Telstra on women. It is interesting how women have very much dropped off the political agenda with the advent of a Howard government, despite the fact that, of course, he has a very significant number of women in his parliament. In fact, the Howard government boasted about the number of women. But time and time again we have seen those women vote for policies or programs that have disadvantaged women. They have voted for changes in Medicare, for increasing the costs of child care, for the need to sell your home before you can get into a nursing home, and for significant changes in industrial relations that have enormously disadvantaged women. Now they are going to vote for the privatisation of Telstra when they know, if they talked to just a very few women in the rural and regional areas of this country, that women will be principally disadvantaged by the telephone cut-off—the changes.

speech.para: Many years ago when I was not too long elected—I think it was after I became a senator, but certainly back then—the women of South Australia organised a `Labor Party women listen to people in rural South Australia' forum. We held that forum in Port Augusta. We asked many women to come along who were certainly anything but members of the Labor Party. We were concerned to know what were the principal issues for them.

The first issue, and the answer certainly surprised everyone there, went to the question of what is the highest priority issue for women in rural and regional Australia. It was water. The second highest priority was communications—the telephone. The women were particularly interested in the telephone as a way of maintaining friendships and contact with family, when they lived so much of their lives in pretty isolated and distant areas. They were very concerned about simply being able to maintain a community of contact by the telephone.

They particularly talked about the importance of the telephone for emergencies. It is one thing for us to be able to quickly get in contact with an ambulance for emergencies; it is another altogether when you are living in rural and regional Australia. They were concerned about the importance of the telephone in terms of dealing with emergencies or accidents but also for finding out about how to manage things safely.

I know about this, too, because of the concern many rural families have about child care, to assist families when they are under pressure of work and to make sure that their children are safe from the hazards of living on a farm where, indeed, more children are killed by accident per year than anywhere else in this country. The telephone is critical for advice about safety and advice about what to do should an accident happen.

We saw not too long ago the launch of a further package in the campaign against domestic violence in this country. While I certainly acknowledge the critical importance of that contribution by the current government to the domestic violence issue, I also point out that it builds on the considerable program and policies established under the previous Labor government.

There is no doubt, though, that if you are a victim of domestic violence in rural and regional Australia, the need of the telephone, and indeed a specifically established tele phone hotline, to assist people who are dealing with the difficulties of domestic violence is just the sort of thing that is at risk. These women now may find that the costs of the telephone and their calls are significantly increased.

There is another point that I was pleased to pick up on from the Hansard of evidence provided to the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee by Mrs Smith giving evidence on behalf of the Country Women's Association. She said:
I guess another of the reasons why the quality of the service is very important—
not only, first of all, that there is a service, but that it is of reasonable quality—
is that telemedicine is becoming so much more prominent in remote areas now, too. If you were having your ECG sent down the telephone, you would want the quality to be pretty good, wouldn't you?

I cannot think of a better example, unless perhaps you are halfway through a telemedicine operation when the line jacks out or has some interference. These are points that I think are being brought to the government's attention by members of the Country Women's Association and that certainly were raised at the hearings of the ERCA committee.
They are very important points. People are concerned, first of all, that they have a service, secondly, that that service is of good quality and, thirdly, and most importantly, that it is affordable.

It is interesting to consider another factor that is not being told to people about the consequences of a privatised Telstra. I have mentioned that, on any evidence, once a major service of that sort is privatised, the service quality falls and the costs rise. But in this case, Mr Howard has a bonus issue for the people of Australia, particularly regional and rural Australia, and that is the GST. Every time your telephone is connected, the GST will be added to it. Every time your phone is reconnected, that service will enjoy a GST. Every time you have cable television connections made, that will enjoy the extra GST.

talk.start.para: —How do you know this?
—You haven't got a policy, then?
—She doesn't know.
—Every time your tax bill comes, that will have a GST. Every time you buy a phone from a phone supply shop, that will also enjoy the benefit of an extra GST.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senators opposite are shouting for the first time in my speech, which means that we must have suddenly landed a punch. We must have landed a bit of an injury to them. It is very concerning for those of us who have bothered to go out and listen to and talk with people in rural and regional Australia about their concerns, to learn that most people do not want Telstra privatised and to know that neither do so many on the coalition backbenches. Yet they have bowed to pressure from their Liberal coalition colleagues. They have been forced into this and then bought off at a considerable price to be paid by the taxpayers of Australia.

speech.para: It is very clear that Australians have never minded about assisting our colleagues and our families in rural and regional Australia. There has always been the cross-subsidy impact. In my own state, under the cross-subsidy arrangements that operate at the moment, loss making infrastructure in rural and regional areas is supported by profits made in other parts of Telstra. That means that, for instance, throughout northern Queensland the average cross-subsidy is up to $1,000 a line, and in regions like north-west New South Wales it can be up to $4,000 a line. Up through remote parts of Western Australia, the cross-subsidy can be over $5,000 a line. In far western areas of South Australia—my own state—like Ceduna, for example, lines can be worth more than $6,000. Most citizens understand that when we pay our telephone bill, we are also chipping in to make telephones affordable for people in rural and regional Australia, because we have a fairly large commitment to fairness in this country.
But is it fair that, in the privatising of Telstra, one large chunk of the community will benefit enormously at a cost to the taxpayers of the rest of the Australia?

talk.start.para: —Have you heard today's announcement?
—It's called equity.
—We do not mind paying, if it is fair, but we object to paying for what is no more than a buy-off, a very big bribe.

speech.para: Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Stand up and say something. Stand up and make a speech.

—It is a very sad day if we see the total privatisation of Telstra. My colleagues opposite are carrying on somewhat, but I urge them, if they have any doubts about this, to read an excellent debate—I do not have time to go into it, but I wish I could. It is a perfectly splendid speech dated 27 March 1946 by the then Premier Tom Playford about the need to buy the private electricity company in South Australia back into public ownership because of the failure of a privatised service to deliver on behalf of the people of that state. That is what we have done in delivering Telstra and that is what some of us will fight to maintain. We know that privatised services do not care about community obligations. They care much more about profits.

speech.para: In the remaining minutes available to me I foreshadow that I will move a second reading amendment on behalf of the opposition. The government's amendments are about competition issues. They are not to do with the central issue of privatisation. The opposition believes that these amendments should be referred back to the ERCA committee for consideration and report back by 2 November. This will give the industry the opportunity to also put forward further amendments on competition issues. The opposition is not necessarily opposed to these amendments but wants to give them more careful consideration. The amendment has been circulated.

In the last minute remaining, it is important to say once again that this decision—this privatising of the rest of Telstra—is a feeble effort at policy on the run. It is not about policy; it is about rescuing Senator Parer. It is about politics and nothing else but. It is a complete breaking of the promise given by Prime Minister Howard that this would not happen. This is yet another of Mr Howard's broken promises. It is against the wish of a huge majority of the Australian people who time and time again in polling have opposed any further privatisation of Telstra. They know that privatising means a drop in services and an increase in costs. When you add the GST to all those services, the Australian people will suffer terribly if this legislation is passed and at any stage proclaimed. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today in complete and utter opposition to the sale of Telstra, obviously. Before I get into the debate, I think it might be salutary to look at how many government speakers there are on the speakers list.
—How many?
—There are three out of 17.
—That includes the minister.

—That includes the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston); that is absolutely correct. Two of the three are Nationals. Not one Tasmanian Liberal senator has uttered a word in relation to this debate other than Senator Abetz, who is not here, unfortunately. I am sure he will come racing down once he hears his name on the monitor; he has been continuously interjecting. Senator Abetz did not have the courage to come in here and make a contribution, which is very unusual for him because you usually cannot shut him up.

speech.para: This does not surprise the people on this side of the chamber. The Tasmanian Liberal Senate team has simply given up the fight for Tasmania, from our perspective, with a couple of exceptions. I will not name them, but, Mr Acting Deputy President Calvert, you are one. It does not include Senator Abetz and it does not include the senator who actually does not live in Tasmania any more and who is very rarely there, and we all know who that is.

If this new deal is so stunning for Tasmania, where is it? We had an announcement yesterday and a small announcement today. The rest will be drip fed out as we move into the election. We do not have the deal until we even discuss whether the legislation is worth passing. Why are the Tasmanian government senators not prepared to get up, tell us what the deal is, laud it, explain why it is such a good deal for Tasmania, shout it from the rooftops and possibly enlighten us along the way? Where are they?

I can tell you where they are. They are in the same place they were when their government slashed $50 million from Tasmania in labour market programs. They are in the same place they were when their government slashed the child-care subsidy for community based child-care centres. They are in the same place they were when their government slashed funding to health. They are in the same place they were when up-front fees were imposed for universities. They are in the same place they were when CESs were closed and the community based providers were thrown out of jobs. They are in the same place they were when cuts were instituted to legal aid and when education funding was slashed for Tasmania and so on. You could not do a better job if you sat down and strategically decided to wreck a state's economy in terms of what this federal government has done. Where were they all this time? They were missing in action, as usual.
Let us turn to the two National Party senators who have had the gumption—I will give them that credit—to front in this debate.

talk.start.para: —Wait till Bozzie gets into you.
—Tell us about it.

—The first one was Senator McGauran. Senator McGauran had more courage than other members of the coalition. He got up and defended the position. He was fifth last on the speakers list, allowing at least some scrutiny from opposition senators, which I will give him brownie points for. He may be fifth last on a very long speakers list, but he is right up there in the coalition speakers. In fact, he was the first coalition speaker to make a speech with regard to what is an incredibly important initiative and what this government is touting as a major win with regard to regional Australia. Where are the rest of them?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am very loath to interrupt my colleague in this eloquent and well reasoned debate, but Senator Macdonald and Senator Brownhill do not have the courage to get up and make speeches on this debate. It also appears that they do not have the intelligence to sit in their own seats when they interject.
—What is the point of order?
—The point of order is that they are interjecting continuously and they are out of their seats.

—I take your point. They were out of their seats. However, there have been continual interjections from both sides. I recall very well when Senator McGauran was on his feet that five people were interjecting at once on this side. So it happens on both sides. I take your point. Senator Brownhill, in future, when you wish to interject, would you do so from your own place.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I am now in my place.
—There is no point of order.

—As I was saying, Senator McGauran was the first coalition speaker. Where were the rest of them? Why are they not in here defending this deal and the sale of Telstra and explaining to the people of Australia, particularly those in Tasmania, why it is such a good thing? Because they do not have the gumption.

speech.para: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As Senator Bolkus says, they are embarrassed and ashamed. Where are they? Like the Tasmanian senators, they are missing in action.
—We're in here now.
—You may be in here now, but you have not spoken and you obviously do not intend to speak.

speech.para: Senator Brownhill interjecting—

talk.start.para: —In relation to the speech that Senator Faulkner made earlier, I understand that you have made 10 contributions since you have been here. Perhaps if you did get up on your feet and make a speech, it would illuminate the Senate. Let us turn to Senator Boswell.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is absolutely and completely incorrect. I have spoken on all the legislation pertaining to my portfolio area.
—What is your point of order?
—The fact that Senator Mackay is misleading the Senate.
—It is not a point of order. I ask senators on my right and on my left to cease interjecting because I want to hear my colleague from Tasmania.

—Let us turn to Senator Boswell. I am glad that he is here. One would think that, having brokered this so-called rescue package for rural and regional Australia, he would have been at least one of the first speakers leading from the front in supporting his constituents in rural and regional Australia. But where is he on the speakers list? I pay him the tribute of at least having the gumption to come in here and defend this deal. He is second last, leading from behind. The only remaining speaker on the speakers list is the minister, who has no choice. He has to come here and defend the deal.

speech.para: What outstanding political courage from the government! Three people from the government have the gumption to come in here and defend a major initiative that people in regional and rural Australia are concerned about.
Senator Ian Macdonald interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They obviously think this is terribly amusing. I can tell you that it is not. It is not terribly amusing if you come from Tasmania. It is utterly beyond belief that we are debating this bill—for three reasons. First, this is utter political suicide for the coalition. This is utterly crazy, utterly stupid and utterly beyond belief. I cannot believe that the coalition is doing it. From a straight, base political motivation, it is unbelievable. I cannot believe it. This government will lose swags and swags of seats over the sale of Telstra.
—What are you worried about?
—In relation to base political motivation, it is unbelievable. Second, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave his word.
—Senator Ian Macdonald, you have been continually interjecting. I ask you to come to order.

—The Prime Minister gave his word that this would not happen, so did Senator Hill. In fact the whole of the government—hand on heart—got up and said, `Trust us on the one-third sale. We will never, ever sell the remaining two-thirds.' The third reason why it is unbelievable that we are here debating this is that it is the wrong thing to do by Australia and it is the wrong thing to do by regional and rural Australia. In terms of principle and of actually serving the people that we are here to represent, it is the wrong thing to do.

speech.para: This government has no mandate to do this—no mandate at all—and the government said it would not do it. Again, hand on heart, they said, `If we were to do it, we'd wait until after the election until we had a mandate, so the people can actually have a say with regard to this initiative.' That is pretty novel from this government, but laudable. Fair enough—you go to the people, you have a policy, you wait until you get elected then you institute it because you have a mandate—but, no, this government does it the other way around.

talk.start.para: —At least John Hewson was honest in 1993.

—That is correct. That would be fine but they have not done it. They have broken their promise. Obviously it is a non-core promise, something—interestingly—which has gone into the vernacular of Australians. If you walk into any pub or supermarket it is `non-core', `core' and so on in terms of almost everything you talk about. That is why we find ourselves here today. This is an utter travesty; we do not believe it should be happening.

speech.para: John Howard's only mandate for the term of this government was to sell one-third of Telstra. If he wants to sell the rest, he should—as he promised—firstly gain the support of the Australian people at the next election. It is for this reason that the opposition will be moving an amendment in the second reading debate which, if successful, will have the effect of deferring further debate on this bill until the first day of sittings next year. I foreshadow that Senator Faulkner will be moving the amendment, which I understand has been circulated in his name. This amendment will give all senators the opportunity to hold Mr Howard to his word.

Let us briefly go through what happened for Tasmania with the one-third sale of Telstra. As Senator Murphy so eloquently pointed out, the $58 million that was parish-pumped into Tasmania was already in the Telstra business plan. All it was doing was bringing a number of those initiatives forward, and I think Senator Murphy made that case. As I said, Mr Howard vowed and declared, hand on heart—and we are not sure that he has got one, Senator Bolkus—that he would never, ever sell the remaining two-thirds of Telstra and at that point he gloated about making Australia the greatest nation of shareholders in the world.

What an aspiration to have—making Australia the greatest shareholding nation in the world. Maybe he meant the greatest cabinet of shareholders in the world. Maybe that is what he meant because he is certainly on the way there. Irrespective of that, what an aspiration for a government to have: to make the greatest nation of shareholders in the world. It is absolutely outrageous.

What about people? Forget shareholders; I know shareholders are people but we have to look after people first. This bill is actually going to adversely affect people in regional and rural Australia—and this government knows it. That is why none of those opposite—with three exceptions—have had the gumption to get up here and defend it. That is why, because you know it is the wrong thing to do. But you sit here in a cowardly way and continually interject as we get up and put ourselves on the line and indicate what our position is. You do not have the gumption to get up and defend your own position. I think that says a lot.

Let us turn to Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine also said he would never, ever agree to the further sale of two-thirds of Telstra. He said that to the people of Australia. He said that to the people of Tasmania, and the people of Tasmania believed him. He was also saying, `I will never, ever support the further two-thirds sale of Telstra.' The people of Tasmania look like they were wrong and the people of Australia look like they were wrong. I must say I thought he would not do this. I genuinely thought that Senator Harradine would not support this. I was wrong.

I have to say that in my dealings with Senator Harradine in the portfolios that I have responsibility for, which are industrial relations and employment, I have found him a very honourable person. I have found him to be a person of principle with regard to those two portfolios. I have found him to be a person who actually genuinely cares about the people of Tasmania. I thought that, when he made that commitment, he would keep his word. I thought he was genuine; I thought he was telling the truth, and so did the people of Tasmania. But I was wrong and the people of Tasmania were wrong.

I was on talkback radio with Senator Gibson the other day and we had a number of calls. I think there was one caller who was equivocal about the sale of Telstra—this is in Tasmania—and everybody else was implacably opposed to it. A lot of the people who rang up were shareholders. They said, `We bought shares in Telstra on the premise that only one-third of it would be sold, but we don't want Telstra sold.' This government is denying the people the opportunity of having a say whilst seeking a mandate. They are doing it the wrong way around. It is absolutely lacking in intestinal fortitude.
I notice today that Senator Harradine says he is `leaning' towards a further two-thirds sale of Telstra. Senator Harradine says:
