I've got a list . . . against and for . . . in actual words, the against is stronger but it gets down to the issue, can the government deliver a cheaper and more efficient telecommunications service than can a commercially-oriented or private organisation.

The answer is no. He knows that. He was active in the labour movement for a long time. As I said, he has done nothing but the right thing with regard to industrial relations. He knows that it is wrong. He knows that it is the wrong thing to do.

The people of Tasmania do not want Telstra sold. They have already had millions and millions ripped out of the state. They know that, once the telco is sold, it can never be bought back. This is not about quick fixes for grubby, short-term political gains—well, it is for the government—but for those of us who live in Tasmania, who are paid to come here and represent this state, it is about future generations. It is about state of the art technology for future generations of Tasmanians. That is what it is about, and we will be behind the eight ball. It is outrageous that one person can actually make a decision for future generations of Australians—and it looks like he is going to make the wrong decision.

The government has already ratted on the deal with Senator Harradine because the 170 jobs that they committed themselves to have not been created. When Senator Alston, who has been repeatedly asked about this, was reminded about that commitment for the 170 jobs, he said, `Don't ask me. That was Telstra's commitment.'

talk.start.para: —Like the ABC funding commitment.

—That does not augur very well for the full privatisation of Telstra, does it? If we do not win government at the next election—which is unlikely I would have to say; after the passage of this bill, it is more likely that we will win government—we will be in here in opposition and the minister will again be saying, `Don't ask me. I'm only the minister.'
—`I'm only the doormat.'

—`I'm only the doormat. Don't ask me. I'm only the minister. Go and ask Telstra about this.' What about the future? How is the minister going to ensure that these commitments are given? Senator Harradine asked a question of the minister, and he stated:

speech.para: Minister, can you confirm that Telstra's message bank facility is available free of charge to all capital cities in Australia except Hobart? Is it a fact that all Tasmanian users, including Hobart users, have to pay at STD rates to Melbourne in order to leave a message or to retrieve a message? If the facility is available free of charge to those users in the other capital cities, why is it not available to users in Hobart? Why is it not available free of charge right throughout Australia?
The answer from Senator Alston:
It is obviously a commercial service that Telstra operates.
He was then interrupted by an interjection, but continued:
I see, so everything that Telstra does should be made available to everyone?
This is his response to a question from Senator Harradine. He went on:
Is that what you are arguing?
That is what he asked Senator Harradine. He continued:
This is the ultimate in socialisation, isn't it?

The minister absolutely mocked Senator Harradine for a genuine question, a question which I thought was very illustrative of how this government perceives Telstra will be run in a full privatised model. The minister said all of this to Senator Harradine, and I am amazed that he has not got the message. Senator Alston went on:

This is not only having the shares in the company but your approach would be that you have the capacity to go in and tell them everything you want them to do—you would tell them how to run the business and which services ought to be made available across the board.
He continued:
But that is a very different proposition to saying that they ought to be forced to provide it wherever you think it ought to be introduced.

I think that response to a question from Senator Harradine says it all. There is absolutely no way this government is going to be able to honour its commitment. Senator Harradine knows it and I hope he reconsiders his position.

In regard to Senator Harradine, as I said, we heard this morning that he is leaning towards the further two-thirds privatisation of Telstra. I must admit—and I have had a lot of calls into my office at home about this—that people are getting pretty sick of this tactic of Senator Harradine's. Now you see him, now you don't; maybe he will, maybe he won't; and so on. If Senator Harradine does make this decision—and I hope he does not—he will have made it without consulting the people of Tasmania, the people who pay his salary and who he purports to represent.

We talk about the CSO that the government is lauding. This is the same government that were prepared to accept the recommendation from the National Competition Council for the abolition of the cross-subsidy on Australia Post. You cannot trust the government. You could not trust them on that. The Hanson phenomenon happened, so they reversed the decision on that. It was a knee-jerk reaction. The Hanson phenomenon happened, so they changed their minds on that. You cannot trust this government on the issue of the CSO.

What I want to know from Senator Harradine—and I do not know whether he is coming in here or not; I certainly hope he does come in—is why on earth he is doing this. It is actually beyond me. I cannot understand why he is doing this. With regard to Wik, whilst I completely disagreed with what he did, I could see that there was some symmetry to it. I could see that there was some logic to it. I could see that he was genuinely concerned about a race based double dissolution election. I disagreed with what he did, but at least I could understand it. Here, for the life of me, I cannot understand it. Given that Senator Harradine was one of the people who said he would never ever vote for the full sale of Telstra, I do not think the people of Tasmania or Australia can trust him anymore either. Not only can we not trust the Prime Minister, Mr Howard; we cannot trust Senator Harradine anymore either.

If this bill goes through, the only way the privatisation of Telstra will be stopped is by voting this government out. I think this government has got some kind of a death wish, because I think that is precisely what is going to happen. As I said before, it is politically loopy to do this. As far as this government is concerned and as far as Senator Harradine is concerned, the people of Australia and the people of Tasmania will judge them, and history will judge them, harshly. If Senator Harradine supports this, as far as I am concerned, he will not have a shred of principle left.

talk.start.para: —Senator Mackay, you have to actually foreshadow the amendment.
—I have.
—No, you said `on behalf of Senator Faulkner'. You actually have to foreshadow it yourself. I thought I would remind you before you finished.

—Thank you, I appreciate that. Let me finish with the never ever which will never ever really happen. The people of Australia will never ever forgive this government if this bill goes through and, if Senator Harradine supports it, the people of Tasmania will never ever forgive him for what he is doing. I foreshadow that the opposition will be moving an amendment to the motion for the second reading in the following terms:

speech.para: Omit all words after "That", substitute:
"further consideration of the bill be postponed and be an order of the day for the first day of sittings in 1999".

talk.start.para: —Since the sale of Telstra was first announced, I have been on the record as saying that I would not support the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 unless it had absolute, ironclad guarantees for rural and regional Australia. My National Party colleagues in the Senate and I have been to see the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on two or three occasions—some of us on three occasions, others on two occasions.
—Which one did you roll over on?
—In actual fact, I did not roll over, and I want to refer to your press release, which says:

speech.para: Why doesn't the National Party explain how it will guarantee a world-class telecommunications network to regional and rural Australia into the next century and beyond?
I think that is a very, very good question, and the answer to that question is that you can only do it with the return of the sale of the network.

talk.start.para: —Turn it up!
—That will give money, and we have guarantees from the Prime Minister that that money will guarantee everything that rural Australia wants.
—What's next?

—Order! During the last speech, I asked the interjectors on my right to cease interjecting. I would now say to senators on my left that they should keep their interjections to a minimum. I call Senator Boswell.

—Thank you. Senator Schacht has hit it right on the head. The only way you can get rural and regional Australia up to speed with a decent telecommunications system that is not steam driven, that is not 2.4 kilobits when everyone else has got 64 kilobits, is by using the money from the sale, and that is where we are coming from.

speech.para: Regional and remote Australia has always been the poor relation when it comes to telecommunications services. There has been a large section of Australia which has suffered and been denied all the benefits that access to modern telecommunications can deliver.

The National Party, the NFF and the Isolated Children's Parents Association have all spoken out about the difficulties in their lives in conducting their day-to-day business, in carrying on their major export industries and in educating their children by correspondence because of these deficiencies. The National Party, the NFF and the ICPA have all been united in their call for better and equal telecommunications for the bush.

A fax takes nearly two minutes to transmit an A4 page—that is, if you can get a fax to work or if you can get an Internet connection. You have to be very lucky to get that. Of course, if the day is not sunny and the towers are not working properly, you cannot even get a fax. It takes so long to get it through.

Remote people have only 2.4 kilobits when the rest of Australia has 64 kilobits, and access to the Internet is impossible for some regional and remote Australians. The only way we are going to get this up is by the injection of that money. Many remote Australians cannot make one local call from their home because they do not have a local 25c call area. There are families out there without access to their nearest local town who do not have a local call rate to that small community centre, despite it being their lifeline. Today, we removed the pastoral rate from the zones so people can have a chat with each other. This is the first time ever.

talk.start.para: —They're still paying timed calls.
—Senator Schacht, you will have plenty of time to make a contribution later, I suspect.
—You fell for it hook, line and sinker on that one.
—No, I did not fall for it hook, line and sinker. It is being raised from 25c for four minutes to 25c for 12 minutes—a 300 per cent increase. That is a huge breakthrough.

speech.para: I have had many people call me, but I can tell you of just one who cannot access their local town to transact business, to access their stock and station agent, to do normal day-to-day business—as normal as that can be with the few services and facilities in these small western towns—when their nearest local town is not a local call. This family, on a smaller than average station with about 7,000 sheep, doing their essential local business had a telephone bill last year of $3,200. That is a lot to ask country Australia.

talk.start.para: —It costs a lot more under a privatised company.

—Country Australia is asked to continue to return the enormous export earnings that support the whole nation. Our rural industries are world leaders. They are efficient. They are internationally competitive. To continue on this path, they need up-to-date telecommunications to access world prices, to forward sell their products—gone are the days when you just sent your product down to the local abattoirs and hoped for the best—to deal with the futures market.
—He doesn't believe a word of this.

—They have to have faxes that work. They have to have Internet access and at affordable prices, not chugging away at 2.4 kilobits that takes an hour to get an Internet call whereas in the cities they can whiz it through in five minutes. That is why we have had to do this. We have to get those people up to speed on their telecommunications.
—How pitiful.

—They need high-speed digital access so they can have affordable education for their kids, the isolated children. Those are the things that are required out there. The National Party knows this. We know our rural industries. We know what people want. We continually talk to them all the time.
—Are you into self-humiliation?
—Order! Senator Carr, I am getting sick and tired of your continual interjections. If you do not cease, I will get the President in here to deal with you.

—Our people have to be internationally competitive. They have to have the latest telecommunications. This is the only chance—it is probably one chance in a million—that they can get there. We have to drive the bush forward. We cannot just go back to the 1960s. We are an exporting country. There is no solution in pretending we can live in the 1950s or 1960s again.

speech.para: The National Party has always kept advancing the agenda for rural Australia, and the new telecommunications package was hard won by our people. We were continually in the office of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston). We were continually in the Prime Minister's office. We had Wendy Craik and her negotiator up in Alston's office. The benefits to rural Australia are vast and will never be known until they are announced, and then the people will appreciate them.

We are an exporting nation. We need every means available to keep that edge on our trade competitors. You simply cannot ask rural Australians to be internationally competitive, to lead the way, and not give them the tools of the trade to do that. The National Party has listened to the people out there who need these services. We have a conference resolution nominating what we require. Our party has been guided by the NFF, by the Isolated Children's Parents Association—

talk.start.para: —What about the CWA?
—By the CWA, and all those sorts of people who want these things, who want to be able to educate their kids in distant education.
—And they don't want to sell.

—The National Party and the Prime Minister have really got to know each other over the last couple of days. We have been in his office continually. My National Party senators have been rock solid in their determination for their constituents. We presented our case not only to the Prime Minister but also to Minister Alston. We have had Wendy Craik in the office as well as technical advisers. We have done our job. I believe that we have also delivered. We now have a three-pronged package that will move rural Australia into a new era of telecommunications services.
—What are the three prongs, Ron?
—Today the first plank of the National Party demands, as expressed by the ICPA and NFF, was the extension of untimed local calls and the abolition of pastoral calls.
—You sound like a militant trade unionist.

—On a point of order: I hear Senator Schacht calling Senator Boswell by his first name, which is clearly against standing orders. I hear the castrato voice of Senator Carr defying your direction to keep quiet. I hear Senator Sherry interjecting when he is not in his seat. I find that absolutely deplorable. I ask you to bring those three to order.

—There is no point of order, but I make the point that during the 10 minutes that Senator Boswell has been speaking Senator Carr has interjected 24 times and Senator Schacht 19 times. I think it is about time you gave him a fair go.

—I can handle them, but please do not take my time up because my time is running out. People in remote areas will now be placed on the same footing as city people with local calls in their local area—37,000 households in remote areas will get the same benefits as their city cousins. That is because we have fought for it. We fought for the 25c pastoral calls to be removed. We fought for the timed call to the community centres to increase from 4.5 minutes to 12 minutes—a 300 per cent increase. That is an achievement out in the west. You only have to ask these people who have had to pay timed local calls, not timed local calls to a neighbour 20 miles down the track but a call from their house to a worker in a cottage or to their son's house on the same property. They are the achievements that we have made.

speech.para: The federal government will spend $150 million upgrading infrastructure, so all local calls in an extended zone will receive untimed local calls. There is a new preferential call rate to a larger area, to cover the community service town, set at 25c for 12 minutes. That is three times what we had before. The current pastoral call rebate of $160 will be maintained. Many people living in isolated and remote Australia will for the first time be able to call their neighbours without watching the clock. The upgrade in capacity in these areas will commence as soon as this bill is passed. The new untimed services would be available next year.

The National Party has always been determined that the opportunities from a fully privatised Telstra should flow back to the bush. It is the only way we are going to get them—$1 billion does not come from anywhere; you have to have something. We have made our demands clearly heard for untimed calls for remote areas and for the abolition of pastoral calls. This announcement today will meet this need. The federal government has delivered these strong National Party demands. It has delivered untimed local calls and the abolition of pastoral calls to the bush.

Yesterday Tim Fischer and Richard Alston announced that the dilemma with the phasing out of analog mobile services created by the Labor government will be solved, and they will give remote and regional Australia a superior mobile phone service. That will not affect the people right out in the western areas that will get picked up by the removal of the pastoral calls. But anyone east of Roma will get great benefits from that. People in rural Australia will be able to cross between the old analog system and the new digital phone network.

talk.start.para: —They've got to buy a new phone for that, Ron.

—Of course they have to buy a phone. The phones do not last forever. You have to replace them, you know. The new CDMA mobile phones will be able to use the analog network in country areas and the digital network in the cities. That is a huge benefit.

speech.para: Today's announcement on untimed calls is the first down payment of the great benefits for rural Australians from the Telstra sale. The National Party has always called for much more for country people, and the social bonus that will be delivered is going to be great. Country people must have improved customer service guarantees for repairs and installations: $40 a day is some incentive to go out and get your phone fixed if it comes off your bill. But if they cannot fix it immediately a satellite phone will be let, and that will be charged at normal rates.

The most recent telecommunications performance monitoring bulletin shows a rapid decline in new service connections, in faults being cleared and payphone faults being cleared. In country areas from December 1996 to March 1998 new services meeting commitment dates fell by 11 per cent to 64 per cent. Fault clearance within one day fell by nine per cent to 59 per cent. Faults cleared within two days fell by nine per cent to 77 per cent. Payphone faults cleared within one day fell to 43 per cent.

On these figures, important services are being denied to rural and remote Australians on an ever increasing basis. There is no consolation when you receive back a bit of your rental or the provider is fined. It offers no remedy to a loss of service. It is often said out there, `You couldn't get any worse service from Telstra than you get now.' Rural Australia asks that digital data be available to the outback and that satellite phones be available when repairs and service are delayed. The needs of rural Australia have been clearly spelt out.

With an upgrade to ISDN, it could deliver services to the outback that would eliminate the tyranny of distance for remote and rural people. Services such as online banking, crop information and forward sales information and weather reports—all those things—are going to be available. The social bonus from the sale of Telstra will provide a tremendous boost for remote and rural areas. There is to be a further announcement from the government how this social bonus will be further spent on benefits for country people to bring essential and up-to-date telecommunication services and to give country people what city people now enjoy.

The National Party has always been resolute that this must be the outcome from any sale of Telstra. We have stuck to our guns for rural Australia. We have taken our representa tion to the Prime Minister and we fought for this with the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Yesterday and today the coalition government has delivered, and rural and remote Australia can look forward to much more with further announcements to come. Today's announcement on untimed local calls is a $150 million down payment on the package, with all telephone calls within an extended zone being untimed local calls.

Senator Schacht hit the nail on the head when he asked, `Where is this going to come from?' I say to him again that that was a very perceptive question. It is coming from the sale of Telstra. It is the only way—

talk.start.para: —Tell us how much.
—I know how much it is, but I am not going to breach a confidence.
—You know, but the parliament doesn't and your voters don't. Tell us.
—Order! Senator Schacht!
—It is a very, very strong package, and it is one that I would be very proud to be—
—Tell us the truth.
—Senator Boswell, resume your seat.

—Mr Acting Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. You just called Senator Schacht to order. He completely ignored you. He flouted your ruling. He has continued to yell all the way through this speech. I know that Senator Schacht may not want his ignorance repaired, but he at least might show the decency to Senator Boswell to listen in silence, as honourable senators on this side have been forced to listen in silence—
—All day.
—All day to the sorts of comments that have been coming from the other side.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: it is true that I interjected on a number of occasions to help Senator Boswell explain to the Senate what the deal was. He finally admitted there is a secret deal and an amount of money. I think that is a very useful public exposure.
—Senator Schacht, what is your point of order?
—My point of order is that I have helped Senator Boswell in his presentation.
—No, there is no point of order. Senator Boswell, before you resume, on Senator O'Chee's point of order, there has been a fair bit of—
—Provocation.

—No. There has been a fair bit of exchange between both sides. I remind both sides that order should be maintained during Senator Boswell's address. Senator Boswell has three minutes 35 seconds remaining and he should be heard in silence.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Rural people have a choice. They can choose to wind the clock back or move forward. The National Party has taken the latter path and seized this opportunity to give to rural Australians the same share of world-class telecommunications as people in the city. No industry can work without world-class telecommunications. When you are a world leading export industry with world leading exporters, you have to be up to speed; you have to have these tools or you fall behind. The National Party is delivering these vastly improved services to rural Australia.

—I thought I should make this intervention on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 . In between various negotiations today, I have been able to hear some of the speeches from the opposition. Some have been very worth while listening to, and indeed I note Senator Murray's observations this morning. Senator Murray's speech was of particular help and interest. But I felt that some of the contributions were simply personal attacks on me, blaming me for unemployment and the next tornado.

speech.para: I feel that I should briefly address those comments. Let us take the employment situation in Telstra. Why has that declined? The ignorant suggestion being made from some people on the Labor side is that it is the result of the one-third sale of Telstra. How ridiculous can you get? Everyone knows that the cause of the restructuring in Telstra, which started before the one-third sale, is the deregulation environment, which was promoted and supported by the Labor Party and the government. The cause of the restructuring and the consequence of job losses in Telstra has been that deregulated environment and the forthcoming competition. Also, much of it is the result of technological change not associated with the one-third sale. So let us get that right. That has been the refrain that has been going around the place for months and months and months. It is time you people were honest and accepted the blame—if it is blame—and accepted the situation that it was your doing that there would be deregulation in the telecommunications industry.

The Labor Party has been flogging off a number of organisations and instrumentalities, including the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas and a number of others that I cannot think of offhand. The fact of the matter is that those who are `in the know' knew that you were preparing to sell off Telstra. You were preparing to sell off Telstra, and you know that. I have a good memory for some things, and I remember a number of the conversations at the time.

talk.start.para: —But this is 1998, Brian; this is not 1993 or 1990. This is different altogether.

—Then one gets criticised all around Tasmania for trying to hold the line. Let us see what has happened to employment since the one-third sale. Employment in Tasmania in Telstra has declined by only eight per cent. By the end of June it will be—
—That's not right.
—As if you would know.
—Order! Senator Carr and Senator Alston!

—Compare that with the national average of over 20 per cent. And you sneak around Tasmania trying to blame me for that. If Telstra had been frozen in total public ownership, the loss in jobs caused by the restructuring, caused by your policy, would have still occurred to the same extent as on the mainland—over 20 per cent.

speech.para: Some members of the opposition have not even the courtesy to acknowledge some of the things that have gone Tasmania's way because of my intervention. I rarely comment about what I have done in certain areas. I rarely comment about the money I have been instrumental in getting flow to Tasmania, because I believe that if you do that, if you boast about it, then you are not likely to get the same deal next time. If you do not say anything about it, you are likely to get more next time for the interests of the state.

There is no acknowledgment of even the publicly known flow of money to the Natural Heritage Trust and to the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund—in total $185 million or $190 million. There has been no reference to the formula for the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund which gives Tasmania the lion's share of it.

talk.start.para: —What about the jobs lost?

—`What about the jobs lost?' There he is; he has not been listening. The cause of the jobs lost—and you know what it was—was deregulation and that was the Labor Party. I see Senator Mackay has been talking about message bank. She is pretty late on the scene for that. I am not going to tell her what is happening. It is about time she got her ear to the ground.

speech.para: The position is, as I have always said, that the government is elected to govern and the role of the Senate is to audit and control executive government actions and also to protect the rights of individuals and the rights of the state. I have attempted to do this for the 23 years that I have been in this place. I need to examine this matter on its merits, divorced from the nostalgia that I have for Telstra or, more particularly, for its predecessor the Engineering Division of the Postmaster-General's Department.

Somebody from the opposition said, `Brian, we are living in the late 1990s.' Yes, we are. I mentioned previously that I was opposed to, and would not support, the full sale of Telstra. I said that, `The principle in this case is that, if Telstra is a natural monopoly, then it should not be sold.' That is the context in which I made that comment. Telstra, as you know, is no longer a natural monopoly. One could argue one way or the other about that, but that is the fact of the situation.

One of the questions that must exercise our minds is: is the government able to deliver cheaper and more effective telecommunication services to customers than a part privatised or fully privatised Telstra? That is one of the questions we need to ask. What is in place to ensure that this is delivered effectively and efficiently in regional Australia? That is a matter that is exercising my mind and about which discussions have been taking place. Some people are concerned that, if Telstra is privatised, there would not be an ability of legislatures or government to ensure that the universal service obligations are adhered to. In fact, you do that through the legislation, through executive government decision and through audit by this parliament.

The other thing, of course, which is a bit difficult for me to assess—and I have asked various economists about it—is what the ultimate benefit to Australia will be if substantial amounts of the proceeds are spent on redeeming debt. That is one of the things about which I have had various pieces of advice. There is, of course, as the government said, a social bonus and I am sure as the years go by that it will be recognised that the government is prepared to deliver the social bonus.

This legislation does not mandate the full sale of Telstra. It allows the full sale of Telstra; it does not mandate the full sale of Telstra. A future government could sell another tranche of Telstra if, for example, the people of Australia expressed themselves accordingly. As the government has said, it is not going to have this measure proclaimed until after the next election.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you leave it to the people?

—Leave it to the people! The people will have their opportunity. If this is a major question in their minds, they will have their opportunity to vote against the government. That is available to the people, if they feel that is a major question. There are a number of other matters that I would like to raise now, but I do not want to delay the consideration of this bill. There are, for me, a few more hurdles to jump, but I am prepared to support this legislation into committee.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I think this is a very unfortunate time in the history of this parliament because what we have witnessed—
—I do too!

—Ever since you came in, it took a new turn for the worse, I have to say. On this legislation, all we have had is not a tissue of lies, because that would be too generous, but the most blatant misrepresentations and distortions of a policy which you espoused with unbridled enthusiasm in government. There can be no doubt about that at all. In government, when Kim Beazley was finance minister and communications minister, he was the most enthusiastic advocate you could ever come across. That is why people like Kenneth Davidson and Tom Burton say he does not have a shred of credibility, because privatisation has been something that the Labor Party took to like a duck to water. They saw privatisation as the panacea. It solved all their budgetary problems—none of this concern that somehow it was a capital item and it ought to go to repaying debt or to rebuilding the capital infrastructure of the country. No, it was simply a bottomless pit that you were prepared to dip into on a regular basis in order to meet all the black holes that you had otherwise created.

speech.para: It is very disappointing that we have reached this stage in Australia. Having had 13 years of enthusiasm for privatisation, if you look around the world, what do you find? The Prime Minister of Estonia was out here about 10 days ago. One of the first things he said to me was, `Do you know what we are doing? We are privatising our telecommunications carrier.' He almost apologised for being late on the scene, because he knows that Cuba and Albania and the African National Congress and every man and his dog have gone down that path and the only crowd that is left is North Korea. And, of course, their great mate Kim Il Beazley. That, of course, makes the Labor Party an absolute laughing-stock on this issue.

talk.start.para: —That is unparliamentary, Mr Acting Deputy Speaker.
—Senator Alston, I think you should withdraw that and rephrase it. I think you are aware of the—

—I am prepared to withdraw that, Mr Acting Deputy President. Of course, the great tragedy is that this is not only naked opportunism but also disgraceful and dishonest politics. There is a huge cultural divide between this side of the chamber and the other, and this debate brings it all together. The opposition have gone from being the great privatisers in government—there is hardly anything left, I might say, and given the cast-iron guarantee that we have given not to privatise Australia Post, there is nothing left except Telstra—to the situation where less than six months ago they were out there wanting to sell another 16 per cent of Telstra; that is what they wanted.
—That's a lie.

—No, it is not, and you know it. The draft document—the platform for Tasmania—made it abundantly plain that you are only in favour of majority public ownership. Of course, poor old Senator Schacht was at it again only a couple of weeks ago. There was none of this, `We will not sell any more of Telstra,' he was simply running the line that they were in favour of majority public ownership. So it is the height of hypocrisy to believe that somehow this Labor Party could have a shred of credibility on the issue. The debate has sunk to new depths today. I want to remind those opposite of what this great leader of theirs, Mr Sleazley, had to say on radio today.
—Minister—
—I withdraw that. I will substitute Mr Beazley. It does not make any difference. This is what happened on radio—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order: I do not usually take objection to robust remarks and I do not really take points of order on what people say, you have to take it—there is give and take in this place—but you ruled on what he said about Mr Beazley as unparliamentary. The minister then said, `Well, it still means the same thing.' I think that is still unparliamentary on the basis of your first ruling, and he should withdraw.
—Withdraw unconditionally, thank you.
—I withdraw unconditionally. What was said by Mr Beazley was this:

speech.para: They are directing Telstra to produce cross-subsidised services in the bush. Now why can they direct Telstra to produce cross-subsidised services in the bush? Because they own it. If they don't own it, they can't do it. So what you see now is the last thing you'll see.

That is an absolutely outrageous and preposterously dishonest statement—and you know it, Senator Schacht, as well as I do. Senator Harradine referred to it once again in passing. The universal service obligation is a mechanism that delivers cross-subsidies to rural and remote areas.
Senator Carr interjecting—
Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr and Senator Schacht! Order! The minister is entitled to be heard.

—The universal service obligation is enshrined in a separate and distinct piece of legislation, the Telecommunications Act. That is the basis on which services to the bush, which would otherwise be uneconomic, are cross-subsidised by a levy on the industry to which Telstra is a major contributor. That has been the case for very many years in this country.

speech.para: We are not proposing to change it. I do not imagine that you are either. So what possible basis can there be for Mr Beazley to get out there and say that the government can direct Telstra to produce cross-subsidised services to the bush. The fact is that no direction has ever been given to Telstra. The power of direction to Telstra came in at the very same time, the very year, that the minister for communications was requiring Telstra to operate commercially. Here it is—I am holding up the Beazley act—the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act 1991. Who was the minister between April 1990 and December 1991? Mr Beazley. Who was the minister that required Telstra to operate commercially? Mr Beazley. Who introduced competition into the telecommunications sector? Mr Beazley.

Just to pick up on a point Senator Harradine made that, somehow, the Labor Party was responsible by deregulating the market, it is actually worse than that. The Labor Party were responsible for Telstra being substantially inefficient. If you look at what Mr Blount has had to say on many occasions, the fact is they were 30 per cent off world's best practice because of very substantial overmanning and very poor productivity levels. It was necessary for them to slim down the work force, contract out more services and generally become more competitive—all your own work. You introduced competition, you introduced deregulation, you required Telstra to operate commercially and you put the universal service obligation in place.

Just to demonstrate once again the depths to which those who seek to smear and distort will stoop, the act makes it abundantly plain—this bill—that you cannot sell off more than one-third and you cannot sell more than five per cent to any one strategic shareholder. That is the basis on which there were no telecommunications carriers from offshore who bought a stake. They were not interested in being passive players, and the limits were such that it did not make it in any shape or form attractive for them to buy into Telstra.

What do we find? We find this creature, Mr Beazley, going around and encouraging his other acolytes. I don't know that you have done it, Senator Schacht, but I have seen career backbenchers—I forget his name from somewhere down in the sticks in Victoria—getting out there and saying, `This is going to mean that Telstra will be sold off to foreign telecommunications carriers.' That is what Mr Beazley said.

Do you want to know how weak and sneaky the operation is? Mr Beazley has been on radio today peddling these sorts of distortions, but he has not boxed any of the transcripts. No, this is a narrowcast message. Unfortunately, he has been caught red-handed saying these sorts of things which are absolutely and demonstrably untrue. You do not need to take my word for it. All you need to do is look at the legislation. The legislation enshrines universal service obligations, it enshrines price caps and it enshrines and builds on the customer service guarantee which we introduced—in other words, all of those social safeguards are in place in quite separate legislation than the legislation we are considering.
We have never, ever contemplated changes, but you will not make commitment to support those protections. So you are the only party on the record—
Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Collins!

—There is only one party that is not prepared to give the guarantees that those consumer protections will remain in place, because the moment that you give that undertaking you are conceding that it is already enshrined in legislation and that it cannot be changed except by a vote of both houses of this parliament. We are not proposing to change it. So, if you are not, what basis does Mr Beazley therefore have for running around with these monumental, Hansonite scare campaigns? That is why you have such a cultural divide in this country.

speech.para: We are not prepared to go to the people and say, `We will not privatise,' but when we win government we change our minds. But you have no compunction about saying, `We will give you tax cuts. We will enshrine them in l-a-w, law,' but once you get to government you change your mind. You have no compunction about putting out a prospectus saying that you have no intention of any further sell-down of the Commonwealth Bank, and you are doing it as soon as you get the opportunity to do it later. You are the ones who get up at platform discussions—what do they call them, national conferences—and everyone strikes these pious platitudes when everyone knows full well, even the Left, that you will roll over.

talk.start.para: —You're just signing the death warrant of the Liberal Party. You're a doormat. You're just John Howard's doormat.
—Order on my left!

—Look at the great defenders in the Labor Party of values in the public sector: was there ever a single squeal from the likes of Senator Faulkner when Mr Beazley was privatising his head off? Certainly not. He went along with it, up to his armpits in it and loved every moment of it, because it dug Labor out of that horrible budget hole that they seem to have on a recurring basis.

speech.para: What did they go to the last election saying? `Budget was in shape. Budget was in balance.' Once again, it is only after the election that we discover the enormity of the deception that is practised on the Australian electorate on a regular basis by the Australian Labor Party. To think that Mr Beazley, who professes to be interested in parliamentary standards, can be going around sneakily broadcasting narrowcast messages saying that all the cross-subsidies will go because they are only there as a result of a direction from the government, he knows that he put that power of direction in and that it has never been used in seven years.

Mr Beazley was the one who introduced deregulation. He was the one who wanted competition. He was the one who privatised most other government business enterprises. It is a preposterous proposition. You will get your just deserts in due course because the electorate simply will not fall for it. They know what a track record you have. I just want to reflect on a few of the other contributions in this debate.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order on my left!

—Those on the other side—who last night wasted another couple of hours on one of the most blatant filibusters that has ever been seen in this chamber, plus about two hours, before our being able to extend the sitting times of this parliament to enable vital legislation to be debated—are the ones who now maintain that this debate is not urgent, despite the fact that it has always been a very important issue because it does provide the basis for a social bonus, it does provide the basis for a retirement of debt and it does provide the basis for really getting Telstra into a—

—Order! Senator Alston, just resume your seat for a moment, please. It is impossible to hear Senator Alston because of exchanges that are taking place across the chamber. When you are called to order, you are expected to adhere to that so that the minister can be heard.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. There are a number of very important reasons why this bill should go through, and should go through as soon as possible. As far as the government is concerned, it has always been a major piece of legislation, Yet from the other side I think—I do not know—Senator Cook might be about the only Labor senator who is currently in Australia who has not spoken in the second reading stage.
—He's sick.
—He is sick. Wonderful! In other words, everyone who is available has been wheeled out by the union movement to get up there and perform.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —A couple have not. It is only about 24 or 25, is it? So what we have been watching—
—Why don't you deal with the substance of the bill?
—I saw, I think, 26 on the speakers list. If you have taken a few off, good luck to you and thank you very much.

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I apologise profusely; thank you very much for speeding up the debate to the best of your ability and for wanting to really ensure that this bill is able to be processed in the most expeditious manner! Mr Acting Deputy President, the truth is quite to the contrary. They have done absolutely everything in their power to delay debate on vital legislation and to come into this chamber time and again—in between bucketing Senator Harradine in almost every speech and then, of course, kicking Senator Colston whenever you get half a chance—and pretend to claim that this is somehow not an urgent debate and it is not consistent with government commitments.
—Senator Alston, it may help if you address your remarks through the chair rather than using the word `you' all the time.
—Yes, I accept that admonition, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—That may well stop some of the interjections.
—Indeed, it may.
—You keep sliming up to them.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, it does not seem to be stopping them, but we will do our best.
—You continue.

—Senator Murray at least gave some thought to his contribution, and I am sure we will have more to say on the matters that he addressed in the committee stage. But certainly there were some aspects of corporate governance that I think are worthy of further consideration. Certainly, if we had had a few more contributions along those lines, we might have been able to shed a bit more light on some subjects. I think Senator Cooney, to his credit, also raised some concerns about open-ended proclamation. But, apart from those instances, this debate has simply been an unadulterated diatribe. It has been the most ideologically based and, of course, election motivated campaign of dishonesty and distortion that one could ever imagine.

speech.para: You look around the world and you find that the African National Congress thinks that privatisation is a good idea. So who is getting it wrong? This is ideological on our part, is it? Are you saying that we are to the left of the African National Congress? Why do you think Cuba and Albania do it? Why do you think every country in the Western world has gone down this path? Why do you think they all enshrine universal service obligations? Because it makes overwhelming sense, both in an economic and social context.

You know that, because if there is one thing that Mr Beazley will be remembered for it is that he was the most enthusiastic exponent of privatisation in the 13 years of Labor government. Until he came along, there were still a few things left in public ownership. But what did he do? Basically, everything he could get his hands on—

talk.start.para: —Like Telstra.
—Like Telstra?
—Yes.
—You know what Mr Beazley wanted to do, don't you.
—Go outside and say that.
—I have said it, and I will say it again: Mr Beazley was prepared to make representations on the basis that—
—Now we are qualifying ourselves, are we?
—Do you want to know what happened?
—Order! Through the chair.
—Mr Beazley promised Telstra that it would be privatised—
—Promised whom?
—He promised Frank Blount—right, okay?
—Senator Alston, it will help if you address the chair.
—He promised him because presumably he was acting on instructions from the Prime Minister of the day.
—You won't say that outside.

—And Mr Beazley has never ever been game enough to go into the chamber of the House of Representatives and deny the proposition—never, ever been game enough to do it. He has called press conferences, tried to change the subject—
—Prove it.

—It does not need to be proven. I am telling you that is the fact. If he wants to deny it, it is the simplest thing in the world to deny it in the place where it counts. You go in and you tell your story in the parliament, don't you? Because everyone knows that if you mislead the parliament then you are guilty of a political hanging offence—and that is, of course, why Mr Beazley simply will not do it. That does not mean that he would baulk for an instant at going on radio all around Australia, telling the most appalling lies about cross-subsidies and foreign ownership, and anything else you like.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. That was quite out of order, and Senator Alston should withdraw it.
—Yes, it is out of order. You should withdraw it.
—All right. The most appalling untruths, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—Will you withdraw?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, can I be clear on this? If Mr Beazley is saying something that does not have a scintilla of truth about it, how would you prefer that I describe it?
—Are you prepared to withdraw the statement you made?
—I always understood that an untruth was an acceptable expression in this chamber, but if you now decide that it is not, all I can say is that there must be plenty of—
—The issue is that you have not withdrawn the word `lies'.
—I thought I replaced it with `untruths'. I will replace it with `untruths'.
—But you didn't withdraw first.
—Order! I will run this chamber. Senator Alston, it was not clear from what you said that it was withdrawn.

—Let us be clear. We do not need me to make a judgment on it. Let the words speak for themselves. This is Mr Beazley: `They are directing Telstra to produce cross-subsidised services in the bush.' Is that true? Of course it is not true, and you know it. No-one is directing Telstra to produce cross-subsidised services to the bush. You know it. There is an act of parliament that requires it. Telstra has always undertaken its statutory obligations, and so have others in this industry. And why wouldn't they, because otherwise they would be prosecuted.

speech.para: So what possible justification can there be for a politician to go out there and say that on radio? We know why he is saying it. He is saying it because he wants people in rural and remote areas to think that somehow the universal service obligation—the cross-subsidy—disappears if Telstra is privatised when, of course, that is a preposterous proposition. It does not. All of those obligations remain in separate legislation. You know that as well as I do. You cannot possibly be that thick, Senator Schacht. I know you do not pay a great deal of attention in this chamber. I must have said it so many times it is not funny. But you must on occasions have read the legislation. You must have asked for briefings. You must have attended estimates committees. You know the facts. But, tragically, even if you do not, a former communications minister does. A leader of the opposition also has an obligation to get out there and tell it as it is.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —And I am. And to think—

speech.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —To think that Mr Beazley can—
—Stop lying.
—Can stoop so low as to go out and say that they can direct Telstra to produce cross-subsidised services in the bush—
—Senator Faulkner, that last comment should be withdrawn.
—I am happy to withdraw it, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I think that I said, `Stop lying'. I do not think that is unparliamentary. I did not call him a liar. I could have, but I did not.
—It should be withdrawn.
—I will withdraw.

—We have just about reached the end of this debate. I think all Australians know that what the government is doing in this regard is honouring an election commitment but, more importantly, putting in place a structure that will result in overwhelming community benefits that will make Telstra a more efficient organisation, that will enable it to be much responsive to its shareholders and not leave it in no-man's-land, where it is at the moment. The legislation will enable it to get on with delivering quality telecommunications services to the bush and to the metropolitan areas.

speech.para: I think Mr Blount and Telstra have done a very good job. I think they could do even better. Mr Blount has performed a great national service in this country and it is a pity that those opposite could not bring themselves to acknowledge it.(Time expired)
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

debate.para: Amendment (by Senator Murray) proposed:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate:

(a) notes that the following information, requested of the Office of Asset Sales and IT Outsourcing at the hearing of the Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee on 4 June 1998, has not been provided:

(i) a comprehensive balance sheet, or assessment of net present worth, which compares the net Commonwealth financial position, under the two scenarios of selling Telstra and not selling Telstra, including all relevant financial flows, such as, but not necessarily limited to:
(A) the value of Telstra dividends to government forgone;
(B) the value of retained earnings by Telstra;
(C) reduced government debt interest payments;
(D) the costs of the sale of Telstra, such as stockbroker and agents fees, and the costs of government administration of the sale;
(E) the effect of increased taxation foregone, due to the passing of franking credits from government to private ownership;
(ii) separate analyses for the sale of the first third of Telstra and the sale of the remaining two thirds of Telstra; and

(b) resolves that the information identified in paragraph (a) be laid on the table by no later than immediately after Questions Without Notice on the first day of the Spring sittings 1998, unless it is sooner provided to the Committee".

talk.start.para: —It has been brought to my notice that the amendments which have been submitted have not yet been put onto a running sheet. I suggest to the Senate that it may be worth while to adjourn now until 7.30 p.m. to give some opportunity for that to be done. We will proceed to the committee stage at 7.30 p.m.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.20 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats oppose the preamble as follows:

speech.para: (1) Preamble, page 1 (line 12) to page 3 (line 10).

I will explain this briefly. As we stand now at the beginning of the committee stage, I will also say that I will pursue, as briefly as possible, all the amendments that we have listed. Regardless of what some might say is the likelihood of any of them getting through, I want to make sure that I place on the record for the future my opposition, section by section, to what we are doing here tonight. I think that when we look back in five to 10 years time it will be one of the greatest acts of economic vandalism this country would have seen.

To begin with, I do not believe that the preamble can be supported because it simply is not true. Let us begin by taking the second paragraph and the allegation that government ownership inhibits flexibility. Nonsense. There has been a series of extensive studies by the World Bank, by the OECD, by Monash University and so forth, and the key message from all of them is: it makes little difference who owns the company; the key is the quality of the management, competition and, of course, regulation. I do not believe that we should put patent untruths into a preamble. Indeed, why let the totally unproven assertion that public ownership is somehow second best actually be incorporated into law? It is simply a lie and should not be there.

The next paragraph is just as fallacious. Plenty of countries around the world have publicly owned telecommunications companies. In fact, one of the most efficient in the world, one of the best telcos, is publicly owned—and that is the Swiss telco. Again, this paragraph is a nonsense.

The fourth paragraph is the biggest lie of all. It says that Australia will receive a social bonus to the budget bottom line from the Telstra sale. This is absolutely and patently untrue. Within seven years the sale of the rest of Telstra will leave the budget a full $4 billion worse off than it would have been, even after taking into account the interest savings. That is certainly no social bonus in any terms that I would agree with.

Let us remember that the sale of the first third of Telstra resulted in windfall gains of $11 billion to the wealthiest 10 per cent of Australians at the expense of the other 90 per cent. The sale of the rest of it will again deliver a windfall gain for the wealthy few. I do not believe that the rest of us should be facing increased taxes to make up that $4 billion black hole.

The next paragraph reminds us that the legislation only takes effect after the next election. Why are we even considering the bill now? I think that point was made last night. Why is it only the cabinet of the day that decides what the people's mandate was? That is something that we will develop later as we come to other amendments.

talk.start.para: —We rise to support the Democrat amendment. I agree fully with the remarks of Senator Lees.
—Really?

—Of course we agree. To put the preamble into law—for economic assertions, and that is all they are, from some ideological bent out of a Liberal Party policy document to become the law of the land—is really absurd. Of course, if you asked any court to try to interpret those three or four clauses, if it got any challenge, any judge worth their salt would say that this has noth ing to do with the actual working clauses of the bill. It is just rhetoric that a parliamentary majority carried. It is put there as a political explanation. This Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) can wander around the country at any time saying, `It is in the law, it is in the bill, that all these wonderful advantages will come from the full privatisation of Telstra.'

speech.para: Senator Lees correctly pointed out that the preamble mentions that they will deliver a `social bonus' of an undeclared size, but there is no mention anywhere else in the bill of the detail of that social bonus. By asserting that government ownership is in no way appropriate in the `highly competitive, global communications environment', the minister, as usual, confuses competition issues with ownership. They are separate issues.

The Labor Party has always separated those issues. That is why we supported the introduction of competition into the Australian telecommunications market in 1991-92. We believed that that would get a better outcome for Australian consumers. At the same time, we also recognised that then and for the foreseeable future Telstra would provide over 85 to 90 per cent and, in many areas of Australia, 100 per cent of the telecommunications services to ordinary Australians.

At some time or other, most of those competitive companies that may come in—other carriers, other service providers—will have to use the Telstra network to make the connection between their customers. We have always recognised that, and that will be the case for the foreseeable future.

The minister forgot to mention in his ludicrous wind-up speech, or second reading closure speech, that the evidence that was given to the Senate legislation committee of inquiry into this bill from even the great devotees of competition—those fully privatised companies like AAPT and many others—all said, `The worst thing you can do is privatise Telstra and let it loose against us. With its market dominance, it will wipe us out.' In this case, the representative of AAPT, who made it clear that his position was that he generally supports privatisation, said, `Even if you fully privatise Telstra, for goodness sake, leave the power of the minister to direct in the act. We know that, with the dominance of, as the minister once described it, "the 600 pound gorilla", only as a last resort will we get some protection by knowing that we can go to a minister, to the parliament, and raise political and broader social and economic issues.' It is a joke to put in this preamble. I had a look at the preamble earlier on and thought, `Should we move an amendment to delete the first three pages?'

This leads me to the point of this whole committee stage. The Labor Party will be supporting many amendments—our own and other amendments of the Democrats and the Greens. The government will move some amendments on competition issues that at the moment we are agnostic about. We think they would be better dealt with as a separate bill, not tied into a privatisation bill. We take the view that, in the committee stage, our principal position is to oppose the privatisation of Telstra—full stop.

It is true, as people say—Senator Harradine said it and Senator Alston has repeated it ad nauseam—that the Labor Party privatised a number of other instrumentalities. The difference with Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank was that they did not have 90 per cent of the Australian telecommunications market. The Commonwealth Bank had, at best, 20 per cent of the market. In the case of Qantas, less than 10 per cent of Australians fly regularly and half the airline market was provided by another carrier. No-one can remember the last time Qantas paid a dividend. It was always calling for more government guarantees to buy more equipment, et cetera. The Commonwealth Bank did pay a regular dividend, although it was not a brilliant dividend compared to what Telstra has been paying. There is a world of difference, and that is the distinction the Labor Party made when it made the decision. Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank were not near all-encompassing monopolies, even with competition. That is the difference.

I know others in the political debate will keep throwing it up at us and saying, `In the end, you'll do the same to Telstra.' The Labor Party has never equivocated in its national platform. In our policy statements for each election we have always said: `We'll keep Telstra in full public ownership, and we'll keep Australia Post in full public ownership.' There is an important message that we want to give the people of Australia at the beginning of the committee stage, now that the second reading has been carried. After talking with our parliamentary leader, Kim Beazley, we give a commitment that if we win the next election—and I am sure the government's privatisation proposal will help us win the next election—one of the first pieces of legislation presented to the parliament in the first week of sitting of the new Beazley Labor government will be legislation to repeal this bill.

The Labor Party will make a commitment in its election campaign that, on election, in the first week of the first sitting of the first Beazley Labor government, we will repeal this legislation if it has passed through its final stages in this place. That is a statement we will not walk away from. We will go around Australia making that very clear. We look forward to putting this proposition clearly and in stark terms all over Australia—not only in the cities, of course, but in the country areas, the regional areas.

We look forward to seeing the National Party squirming, given what they outlined to us today. I have to say that I have, on many occasions, admired Senator Boswell because of the courageous speeches he has made in this place opposing mad right-wing lunatics, including infiltrators of One Nation. He has stood up in his own party against competition policy. He has stood up in his own party against a whole range of what he would call `economic rationalist statements'. But today's performance was the most pathetic performance that Senator Boswell has put in as he tried to explain how he sold out the bush for not billions of dollars, not even hundreds of millions of dollars and not even approaching $1 billion, but at best a couple of hundred dollars.

I want to go to the issue of what has so far been announced and how already it is being exposed. If the National Party have bought this as a package, they have already been sold short. I will give an example. The minister yesterday announced that the new CDMA network would involve expenditure of some $400 million plus—$450 is, I think, the round figure. He said there would be $176 million for the spectrum and a further $200 million for the provision of the capital equipment to make it work. As was pointed out by Telstra today, the $176 million has already been spent. The National Party have bought a promise that they will get $176 million as part of the social bonus, but that was spent by Telstra several months ago when they bid for the spectrum. Finally, we find that Telstra has spent the grand sum of $6 million to $7 million to buy the spectrum that will be used to provide this system in rural areas. The minister said there would be $176 million to spend on the spectrum to get this network running, but it will be $6 million to $7 million. The National Party should scratch $170 million off their expected pot. They have been dudded $170 million already.

The next thing that happened is that Telstra said this is a commercial decision of theirs; they were going to do it anyway. If they were going to do it anyway, why did the National Party claim it as a victory, as part of their pressure? Senator Boswell said today he and his members rolled into parliament, met with John Howard two or three times and that one of their great victories was the new mobile phone network when Telstra put out a statement saying: `This is a commercial decision.' Apparently, they were going to do it anyway. This Liberal-National Party government cannot have it both ways. They cannot say, `This is a special deal we got for the bush with $420 million,' when Telstra is saying, `It's a commercial decision we were going to make.'

If it is not a commercial decision and it was part of the deal, it means that Telstra was lent on and, after discussions with the minister, had to make this decision. Why? Because the minister represented the two-thirds public ownership. The good old Country Party with `Black Jack' McEwen would not have fallen for this. He would have rattled the coalition to the very end. Did the minister either lean on or direct Telstra or is it a totally commercial decision to establish the CDMA? It cannot be both. Either he lent on them to get this deal for the National Party or it is a straight commercial decision. I think it shows the hypocrisy of this arrangement.

There is a first series of questions we would like to get answers to about this CDMA proposal. I think Senator Boswell said that it was one of three prongs. He mentioned this one and he mentioned the new call charges for remote areas. He said that he is not at liberty to describe the third prong at the moment because it is a secret deal with the minister after his meeting with John Howard. I notice that Senator Harradine, in response to an interjection, said he is not at liberty to divulge the full deal.

This is showing this place in contempt. A deal is being done to provide money for regional and rural telecommunications, yet this government and the National Party are not even willing to tell their own supporters what the deal is. Senator Harradine says, `There is a deal, but I cannot tell you either.' I am surprised that Senator Harradine takes that attitude, because he has always been such a stickler for Senate arrangements.

talk.start.para: —Madam Chair, I raise a point of order. We are dealing with an amendment moved by Senator Lees to delete the preamble. I am just wondering how Senator Schacht's remarks apply to that. I indicate to the chamber that my current view is to support the amendment.
—Senator Schacht, I am sure that you will tie your discussion and arguments into the amendment before the committee.

—I am pleased to hear that Senator Harradine is thinking of supporting the amendment. He knows that it does not mean anything either way. It does not change the thrust of the bill, which still gives the government the guts of what it wants.

speech.para: As the issues raised in the preamble seem to cover everything under the sun about telecommunications, I do not think there is any problem in my speaking on some of the issues that have come up. Until we get more detail of the deal, what justifies this bill being carried by this parliament, for the rest of the committee stage I am going to keep asking a whole range of questions for the sake of the people of Australia. I want to find out exactly what the government has given them and what has persuaded Senator Harradine to vote for the government's basic proposition. If we cannot get that in the parliament, what is the use of having a parliamentary debate or a committee stage? They are some of the questions I raise about the CDMA proposal. There are many more to come. During the rest of this committee stage debate, I will raise them and others. I hope the minister can provide some information. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to indicate that the Greens (WA) will be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 1 on sheet 1124 to oppose the preamble. We had a debate just a couple of days ago about truth in advertising. This is probably a really good example of legislation staying on the table for as long as it is going to last and which basically says what it purports to do, yet in reality deals with ideological claptrap.

speech.para: During the second reading debate, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) said that a minister who comes into this chamber and says things that are untrue will be—I cannot remember the exact term; this is basically what he said—a goner. It seems to me that you might be able to put ideological claptrap in a bill and get away with it. However, the Senate is saying, `No. You can't and you shouldn't.' This isn't what should be happening in legislation. Quite a lot of the elements within the preamble can be proven to be patently untrue. Therefore, they ought not be in the legislation.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, in commenting on this amendment and the matter before the Senate regarding the preamble, I want to go back to some of the closing remarks of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) in the second reading debate. During his speech the minister accused the opposition of being engaged in some extensive delaying tactic. The supposed evidence for this was all the members of the opposition, with the exception of one, having spoken in the debate in an attempt to drag it out.

speech.para: Firstly, in order to correct that, let me say that I was one who did not speak, even though I was on the list. I and a number of other opposition senators took ourselves off the list of speakers today in order to allow the process to at least be kept on track, as it were. I would dearly love to have had my 20 minutes worth in the second reading debate and been able to spend as much time as I could in the committee proceedings putting my points of view. But, in the interests of getting that second reading debate out of the way and getting into the committee stage, a number of opposition senators took themselves off the list. If I had had that opportunity, I would have said a lot of things. I want to make a couple of points, and they relate to the preamble. Firstly, I note that Senator Harradine has indicated that he is of a mind to support the preamble.

talk.start.para: —No.

—Sorry, to support the amendment to delete the preamble. I appreciate that, but it is well known as a matter of statutory interpretation that a preamble to any law or act of parliament is really only ever an aid in the most extreme and very rare situations where some ambiguity arises within the main body of the legislation and the court has to turn to the preamble or the second reading speeches to ascertain what may have been parliament's real intention. Whether the preamble remains in or is taken out—and we clearly support it being taken out because it is largely a statement of ideological claptrap, adopting Senator Margetts's words—it clearly does not matter at the end of the day because a future conservative government, and I am confident there will not be one, could take steps to amend other important sections of the legislation as well as the preamble. If anybody thinks anything here is set in stone or is cast iron, as the minister is wont to say all the time, then they should have another think.

speech.para: Let me make a couple of other points, and I want to address this comment to Senator Harradine. I know Senator Harradine has been the target, if you like, of a lot of the speeches made today. He is a well-intended target, because what the opposition is clearly putting before the chamber and endeavouring to remind Senator Harradine of—as he is in this unique position of having almost the casting vote on this matter—is those commitments he has given in the past. It appears that there is no point reminding the government of the commitments they gave in the past because they long ago gave up any semblance of wanting to adhere to any of their commitments. This was a government which promised to make all Australians relaxed and comfortable, and then scared the living daylights out of the aged community with their attempts to force people to sell their homes to get decent aged accommodation. This is the government that told workers of this country that they would be no worse off, and then brought in draconian workplace relations legislation. Even in its watered-down form as a result of the agreement with the Democrats, they still nevertheless endeavoured to use that to beat-up on the maritime workers union.

I remind Senator Harradine—although I am sure he does not need any reminding—that he supported the Labor opposition in opposing the workplace relations legislation. Senator Harradine's support for the opposition on that occasion did not help us because the Democrats had reached an agreement with the government. I remind the chamber and Senator Harradine that the government claimed a mandate for their workplace relations legislation and, on at least one theory—having won the election and achieved a majority in the House of Representatives—it could be argued that they had a mandate to bring in their workplace relations reforms. We do not believe they had the mandate to bring in the reforms they did; nevertheless, it is arguable that they had a mandate to bring them in. Notwithstanding what could clearly be said at least on that occasion was a government mandate for workplace relations reform, Senator Harradine did not vote to let the government govern on that issue. He voted with us.

However, when it came to Telstra, there was a slight change, I would suggest, in the logic to the argument. After negotiating agreements with the government—which in his view were to be to the betterment of the state of Tasmania but which in our view have not been proven and have not been carried out—Senator Harradine voted with the government to support the sale of one-third of Telstra. Again, Senator Harradine and the government argued that they had a mandate to sell one-third of Telstra because they had gone to the people before the election indicating that they supported the sale of one-third of Telstra.

I have produced some figures in this chamber before—although I do not have them with me tonight—that interestingly enough show that, in the last federal election when the issue of the sale was clearly on the table and the Labor Party, the Greens and the Democrats had all made it clear that they were opposed to it, those parties in the Senate actually received a majority of votes in the election. My argument is this, and I would ask Senator Harradine to consider it: this debate has already been had in this parliament.

talk.start.para: —Let's go home.

—Yes, let's go home. Move the adjournment and let's go home, Senator Heffernan. This debate has been had because, when we debated the government's proposition to sell only one-third of Telstra and the Prime Minister gave his solemn promise that he would not seek to sell any more of Telstra, implicit in the decision of this parliament and this chamber to allow that bill to go through was the rejection of the sale of the other two-thirds of Telstra. It is not just an argument in terms of logic or semantics even; it is quite clearly the case that the reason Senator Harradine and indeed Senator Colston supported the sale of one-third of Telstra on that occasion was that guarantee and that commitment that no more was going to be sold, certainly within the life of this parliament, and that there would be no attempt by the government to introduce any further legislation to sell off the remaining two-thirds.

speech.para: So the debate has been had. The Senate has made the decision, in giving its approval to the sale of the first one-third of Telstra. Clearly, implicit in that decision was its rejection of the further sale of any more of Telstra. I make this final point, as has been argued and put by my colleagues throughout this debate: why the sudden urgency for this legislation? Why didn't the minister and the Prime Minister announce after the float of the first one-third of Telstra, which they said was so successful when all the mums and dads in Australia went out and bought Telstra shares, `We think this has been such a tremendous success. We're going to sell the rest of the two-thirds'? Why didn't they say it then?

What has happened is they have got down to the 11th hour, they know they are in trouble electorally and they are trying to push this bill through this parliament now because they know that, whether they win or lose the next election—and it is becoming increasingly obvious that they will not win it—the composition of this Senate will change in June next year and there will be more senators in this chamber who are opposed to the sale of Telstra than there appear to be now.

The government knows that, if it can get the vote of Senator Colston, the vote that rightly belongs to the Labor Party and rightly should be a vote against the sale of Telstra, and if it can get Senator Harradine's support, it can get this bill through now. But, if it were to leave this legislation, if it were to allow the people to have their say at the next election, it knows that the composition of this chamber will change and it will not get that legislation through the new Senate because a number of government senators who currently sit in this chamber will not be back here. There will be more of us, and I am sure we will be sitting over there.

That is the reason for this haste. The government is, firstly, relying upon the vote that rightly belongs to the Labor Party and, secondly, relying upon the vote of Senator Harradine. I would just ask Senator Harradine to think of that.
